Question: Which lung has lingula?
Explanation:
Right lung: 3 lobes, oblique & horizontal fissures
Left lung: 2 lobes, oblique fissure, cardiac notch, lingula

Question: This group of muscles is innervated by the nerve, which if injured can lead to winging of the scapula.
Explanation: The most common etiology of a winged scapula is usually due to damage or impaired innervation to the serratus anterior muscle. The nerve that innervates this muscle is the long thoracic nerve.

Question: Where should intramuscular injection be performed on the buttocks (dorsogluteal region)?
Explanation: IM injection outside of upper quadrant of buttock is a major cause of sciatic nerve injection injury with the nerve being more prone to damage when the injection site is more medial and/or inferior.

Question: Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is caused by a problem in which of the following
Explanation: Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is an inherited disorder that damages the immune system and causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

Question: 3-ketoacyl-coa thiolase and HMG-CoA lyase deficiency can affect the degradation of what AA?
Explanation: Deficiency 3-ketoacyl-coa thiolase and HMG-CoA lyase can affect the degradation of LEUCINE

Question: The efferent lymphatic vessels from the left gastric lymph nodes mainly drain into:
What nerve is damaged when one is unable to climb?
This nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the arm.
Pes anserinus consists of the following muscles except:
Which of the ff. is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve?
Complete oxidation of palmitate generates _____ net ATP.
Explanation: Complete oxidation of palmitate generates 108 mol of ATP. 2 mol of ATP are used in the activation step. Thus, complete oxidation of palmitate gives a net of 106 mol of ATP.

Question: Spontaneous decarboxylation of acetoacetate yields:
What is the primer used for the synthesis of long-chain fatty acids with an odd number of carbon atoms?
Rate-limiting step for De Novo Fatty Acid Synthesis
Which enzyme is the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle?
Explanation: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 is a liver-specific, intramitochondrial, rate-limiting enzyme that acts as a ligase between ammonium and bicarbonate ions.

Question: In which organelle does the regulation of urea synthesis happen?
Explanation: The CPS-1 reaction between bicarbonate and ammonium happens in the mitochondrial matrix.

Question: Amino acids can be classified based on the molecules produced by the catabolism of their carbon skeletons. Which of the following amino acids, when catabolized, produces acetoacetyl CoA/acetyl CoA?
Explanation: The exclusively ketogenic amino acids in humans in leucine and lysine. Amino acids that are both glucogenic acnd ketogenic are tryptophan, isoleucine, phenylalanine, threonine, and tyrosine.

Question: Which of the following biomolecules are tyrosine derivatives?
Explanation: Norepinephrine is three steps away from L-tyrosine: Tyr > L-DOPA > Dopamine > Noradrenaline

Question: Which is the safest place to perform a lumbar tap?
Explanation: The spinal needle can be safely inserted into the subarachnoid space at the L3-4 or L4-5 interspace, since this is well below the termination of the spinal cord in most patients.

Question: Which hemisphere is dominant in the majority of the population?
Explanation: Many studies have shown that the left hemisphere is dominant for language in 90% of cases, as it is for motor behavior.

Question: Which receptor is responsive to insulin?
Explanation: GLUT4 is insulin-responsive glucose transporter responsible for postprandial glucose clearance. In muscle & adipose cell, GLUT4 is packaged in vesicles released upon stimulation of insulin receptor.

Question: Which of the following can be heard during the "DUB" (S2) sound near the right 2nd ICS along the parasternal border?
Explanation: Heart sounds with chronic Aortic regurgitation include a sharp or slapping 2nd heart sound (S2). The aortic valve can be heard in the 2nd intercostal space along the edge of the sternum.

Question: A 5 yr old boy was playing with a small toy with his nose and accidentally inhaled it. Where is the foreign body likely be lodged?
Explanation: The right main bronchus has a predilection for foreign body impaction because it is wider than the left and the right main bronchus has more direct extension of the trachea than the left main bronchus

Question: Which of the cell below is the first line of defense against pathogens?
Explanation: The young neutrophil (3) shows a lobulated nucleus, while the cytoplasm reveals very faintly small azurophilic (primary) granules. 1 is basophilic erythroblast, 2 is lymphocyte.

Question: This muscle is innervated by
Explanation: The flexor carpi ulnaris is innervated by the ulnar nerve. The corresponding spinal nerves are C8 and T1.

Question: In Type 1 diabetes patients, these cells are destroyed leading to uncontrolled blood sugar levels.
Explanation: Type 1diabetes mellitus is believed to result from destruction of insulin-producing β-cells in pancreatic islets. The classic view is that autoreactive T cells destroy healthy β-cell. Alpha - glucagon

Question: Which nerve in the brachial plexus that when damaged leads to wrist drop?
Explanation: Wrist drop is a disorder caused by radial nerve palsy. Because of the radial nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits. Remember the MARMU arrangement of the nerve branches.

Question: Which of the following is the last part of the conducting portion of the respiratory system?
Explanation: Terminal bronchiole is the last part of the conducting portion of the respiratory system, and has the smallest diameter of all (less than 1mm). There is no cartilage, or glands, no goblet cells.

Question: At which artery in the Circle of Willis do the anterior and posterior streams of blood come together? In this artery, the pressure of the two streams is equal and they do not mix
Explanation: The posterior communicating artery connects the internal carotid with the posterior cerebral arteries, thus, connecting the anterior and posterior cerebral circulations.

Question: Which structure passes through this foramen?
Explanation: The foramen spinosum permits the passage of the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and the meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve.
Option 1: CN V2 (Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve)
Option 2: CN V3 (Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve)

Question: Which of the structures pointed will enlarge when there is an atrial septal defect?
Explanation: Atrial septal defect is located between the right and left atria. Blood gets pushed from left to right due to pressure. This may cause the right atrium to become enlarged.

Question: Which is not an essential amino acid?
Explanation: Tyrosine is a nonessential amino acid the body makes from another amino acid called phenylalanine. Remember: PVT TIM HALL Never Tyr

Question: Which of the following happens during repolarization?
Explanation: The repolarization or falling phase is caused by the slow closing of Na channels and the opening of voltage-gated K channels. As a result, the membrane permeability to Na declines to resting levels.

Question: A typical med student is crying at 2 AM because she has 3 exams to study for the next day. Her tears drain into ___.
Explanation: Tears are drained down from the conjunctival sac through lacrimal pathways to the inferior nasal meatus and then to the nasopharynx.

Question: Which of the following is correctly paired in terms of overall charge?
Explanation: Histones carry + charge because they have an abundance of basic proteins arginine and lysine. The - charged DNA (due to phosphate group) is wrapped around histone.

Question: Which of the following is the correct sequence of the conduction system of the heart?
Correct Answer: SA node > AV node > Bundle of His > Purkinje Fibers
Explanation: SA node starts by causing the atrial muscles to contract. Next, to AV node, through the bundle of HIS, down the bundle branches, and through the Purkinje fibers, causing the ventricles to contract.
Option 1: SA node > AV node > Purkinje Fibers > Bundle of His
Option 2: SA node > AV node > Bundle of His > Purkinje Fibers
Option 3: AV node > SA node > Purkinje Fibers > Bundle of His
Option 4: AV node > SA node > Purkinje Fibers > Bundle of His

Question: The patient is trying to make a fist but instead this happens. This is caused by which nerve damage?
Explanation: A lesion of median nerve will affect the flexors of the second and third fingers resulting in the benediction sign when trying to make a fist. The MCP joints of the 4th & 5th fingers will be flexed.

Question: This lymphoid tissue specimen is from the?
Explanation: The luminal surface of palatine tonsil is stratified squamous epithelium. The epithelium deeply invaginates into the tonsil, forming tonsillar crypts, which increases SA for antigen sampling.

Question: Cardiac orifice of the stomach is found at the level of _________
Which of the following laryngeal cartilages consist of paired, hyaline cartilages?
Explanation: There are 9 laryngeal cartilages, 3 are single (thyroid, cricoid, epiglottic) and 3 are paired (arytenoid, cuneiform, corniculate). Thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid are hyaline. The rest are elastic.

Question: This happens when this nerve is damaged.
Explanation: Damage to the superior gluteal nerve results in paralysis of the gluteus medius muscle resulting in a characteristic gait on walking and standing known as the Trendelenburg gait.

Question: Which of the following is the most commonly fractured carpal bone?
Explanation: Scaphoid fractures are the most common carpal fractures and tend to occur in younger, active individuals. They account for 2% to 7% of all fractures and 60% to 70% of carpal bone fractures.

Question: Located at the center of a portal lobule (a liver lobule):
Correct Answer: Terminal branches of the hepatic artery
Explanation:
Center of portal lobule - terminal br. Of hepatic A.
Center of classical lobule - terminal br. Hepatic venule
Center of liver acinus - terminal br. Of portal triad
Option 3: Terminal branches of the hepatic artery

Question: Cells in this hepatic zone are first to show ischemic necrosis when perfusion is reduced
Explanation:
Zone 1 first to show morphologic changes after bile duct occlusion; last to die if circulation is impaired
Zone 3 first to show ischemic necrosis in reduced perfusion; first to show fat accumulation

Question: Which of the following are the receptors for umami taste?
Explanation:
BITTER = T2R
SWEET = T1R2 & T1R3
UMAMI = T1R1 & T1R3

Question: This cell type is less numerous in taste buds and they do not synapse with the nerve cells.
Explanation:
⇒ Neuroepithelial cells most numerous and form a synapse with afferent sensory neurons
⇒ Supporting cells less numerous and do not synapse with nerve cells
⇒ Basal cells are stem cells

Question: Which of the following does not drain into the thoracic duct?
Explanation: The right lymphatic duct is responsible for draining the right side of the head and neck, the right side of the thorax & the right upper limb. The thoracic duct drains lymph from the rest of the body.

Question: Sickle cell anemia is caused by which mutation?
Explanation: Sickle cell disease is a missense mutation, the beta-haemoglobin gene converts GAG into a GUG, valine is produced instead of glutamic acid. Nonsense-stop, frameshift-insert/delete, silent - same AA

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched?
Correct Answer: Stapedius (CN VII, stapes); Tensor Tympani (CN V, malleus)
Explanation: Stapedius is attached to stapes; innervated by branch of CN VII. The tensor tympani is attached to malleus; innervated by branch of CN V. They decrease sound transmission through the middle ear.
Option 1: Stapedius (CN VII, malleus); Tensor Tympani (CN V, stapes)
Option 2: Stapedius (CN V, malleus); Tensor Tympani (CN VII, stapes)
Option 3: Stapedius (CN VII, stapes); Tensor Tympani (CN V, malleus)
Option 4: Stapedius (CN V, stapes); Tensor Tympani (CN VII, malleus)

Question: Erb's palsy happens due to a damage in which nerve roots of the brachial plexus?
Explanation: Erb's palsy results from injury to nerve roots C5 and C6, with C7 also affected in 50% of instances. The infant’s arm hangs limply from the shoulder with flexion of the wrist and fingers.

Question: Which of the following is the most commonly injured ligament of the knee?
Explanation: The ACL is the most commonly injured ligament in the knee. Because it's smaller and weaker than the PCL and there is the lack of muscle support for twisting or rotational movements around the joint.

Question: Which of the following will lead to decreased gene expression?
Explanation: Acetylation neutralises the charge, making DNA less tightly coiled and increasing transcription. Methylation maintains the positive charge, making DNA more coiled and reducing transcription.

Question: Which of the following is a characteristic of Type 2A muscle fiber?
Explanation:
Type 1: slow oxidative fibers, aerobic, low power contraction, slow to fatigue. 
Type 2A: Fast oxidative fibers: aerobic, intermediate.
Type 2B: Fast glycolytic fibers: anaerobic, fatigue quickly.
Option 2: Slowest to fatigue among all types of muscle fibers

Question: This cell is responsible for the production of ?
Explanation: Normal megakaryocyte: Note the multilobed nucleus as well as the prominent cytoplasm from which small fragments of cytoplasm will bud off and become platelets. Platelets or thrombocytes.

Question: This is a
Explanation: These vertebrae are characterized by the absence of the foramen transversarium within the transverse process, and by the absence of facets on the sides of the body.

Question: For inserting catheters or Internal jugular vein cannulation, this side is safer and more preferred.
Explanation: Anatomically, the right side provides a direct route to the superior vena cava and is often larger than the left one. Due to the anatomy of the lungs there is a slightly lower risk of pneumothorax.

Question: Which of the following is not stored in the liver?
Explanation: Lipid-soluble vitamins A, D(calciferol),E (tocopherol),K (Phytomenadione) are stored in the liver, as is Vitamin B12 (cobalamin).  B6 - pyridoxine

Question: Which nerve fibers are mainly responsible for the reflex arc that results in the quick pulling away from a hot stove?
Explanation:
A-alpha-muscle spindle & golgi tendon
A-beta-muscle spindle & cutaneous mechanoreceptors
A-delta-pain pressure & temperature A-gamma-motor activation of muscle spindle B-autonomic C-lasting pain

Question: What type of collagen is abundant here (yellow arrow)?
Explanation:
I- bones, tendons, organs
II- found mainly in cartilage
III- found mainly in reticular fibres  Collagen IV- basement membrane of cell membranes (shown here) Collagen V- hair, nails

Question: Which connective tissue is the underlying problem in this syndrome?
Explanation: Classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome: skin hyperelasticity, joint hypermobility, increased bruising, abnormal scarring. Cause: Type V collagen mutation, a type I collagen fibrillogenesis regulator.

Question: Which of the following branches off to become a vertebral artery?
Explanation: The main branches of the subclavian artery include the vertebral artery, the internal thoracic artery, the thyrocervical trunk, the costocervical trunk, and the dorsal scapular artery.

Question: Which structure above can withstand high pressure?
Explanation: Arteries have thick walls so they can handle the high pressure and velocity that expels your blood out of your heart. A - Vein, B - lymphatic vessel, C - artery

Question: Which nerve will be usually injured in this kind of fracture?
Explanation: Midshaft humerus fractures involves injury to the radial nerve. Injury occurs in 18% of closed mid-shaft or distal shaft humerus fractures. In open humerus fractures, radial nerve laceration is 60%.

Question: This is the duct of the gland where the facial nerve courses through to innervate muscles of facial expression.
Explanation: The parotid duct (Stensen's duct) is the main excretory duct of the parotid gland.The facial nerve courses through the parotid gland. Wharton (submandibular), Ducts of Rivinus (sublingual)

Question: Which of the following typically ends at L1 in the average adult?
Explanation: The most distal part of the spinal cord is conus medullaris (level L1), and its tapering end continues as the filum terminale. Distal to this is a collection of nerve roots called the cauda equina.

Question: Which is responsible for finger abduction?
Explanation: The palmar interosseous muscles adduct the fingers towards the middle finger. This is in contrast to the dorsal interossei, which abduct the fingers away from the middle finger.

Question: Which of the following does NOT happen in a healthy adult when blood sugar rises?
Explanation: All are normal effects of insulin, except B because it increases the rate of glycolysis in muscle and adipose tissue. Since there is abundance of glucose, it is used as main source of ATP.
Option 1: Increase glucose transport in skeletal muscles and adipose tissue

Question: Is the human brain plastic?
Explanation: Our brains are famously flexible, or “plastic,” because neurons can do new things by forging new or stronger connections with other neurons. So keep learning, you genius!

Question: Middle cranial fossa is prone to fracture due to the presence of several foramen. Which of the ff. is not found in the middle cranial fossa?
Explanation: Jugular foramen is found in the floor of posterior cranial fossa.

Question: You must do an otoscopic examination on the external auditory meatus of an adult by first…
Correct Answer: Pulling the auricle upward and backward
Explanation: The otoscopic exam is performed by gently pulling the auricle upward and backward. In children, the auricle should be pulled downward and backward. Children have more horizontal EAM than adults have.
Option 1: Pulling the auricle backward and downward
Option 3: Pulling the auricle forward and backward
Option 4: Pulling the auricle upward and backward

Question: Which communicates with the mastoid antrum?
Which of the following if correctly paired?
Explanation: Hyperopia corrected with convex lenses, happens when your eyeball grows too short from front to back. A concave lens is used to correct myopia, commonly the result of abnormal elongation of eyeball.
Option 1: Myopia - eyeball grows short - convex lens

Question: Which is the best site for venipuncture?
Explanation: Cephalic Veins in the lateral thumb side. Basilic veins in the medial little finger side. The median cubital vein is considered the best site for venipuncture, well anchored, large & prominent.

Question: Which statements below correctly describes this tissue specimen?
Correct Answer: Primarily relies on extracellular calcium ions for contraction
Explanation: Smooth muscle have a limited Ca-storing sarcoplasmic reticulum. The influx of extracellular Ca++ ions diffuse into the sarcoplasm to reach calmodulin. A and D -  skeletal muscle, B - cardiac muscle.
Option 3: Primarily relies on extracellular calcium ions for contraction

Question: Why is carbon monoxide dangerous to the body?
Correct Answer: Binds to hemoglobin with a much greater affinity than oxygen
Explanation: Carbon monoxide is harmful when breathed because it displaces oxygen in the blood. A - cyanide poisoning, C - dinitrophenol poisoning
Option 2: Binds to hemoglobin with a much greater affinity than oxygen
Option 3: Separate the flow of electrons and the pumping of H+ ions for ATP synthesis

Question: Which cranial nerve is involved here?
Explanation:
CN 3 Palsy
Ptosis: Levator palpebrae superioris paralysis
Ocular deviation: Unopposed LR and SO, "down and out" eye Dilated Pupil: sphincter pupillae paralysis  Diplopia: Deviation of affected eye

Question: Which of the following does not pass through this structure?
Explanation:
Lazy French Tarts Sit Nakedly In Anticipation 
Lacrimal CN V1
Frontal CN V1 Trochlear CN 4 Superior division of oculomotor CN 3 Nasociliary CN V1 Inferior division of oculomotor CN 3 Abducens CN 6

Question: What is this structure called in a normal, healthy adult?
Explanation: The ligamentum arteriosum is the embryologic remnant of the ductus arteriosus, which serves to shunt blood away from the lungs during fetal development and typically closes near the time of birth.

Question: A person with AIDS will have a low count of these cells. High risk of developing life-threatening conditions happen because these cells are important in ____
Correct Answer: Coordinating the immune response by stimulating other immune cells
Explanation: CD4 T lymphocytes (CD4 cells) help coordinate the immune response by stimulating other immune cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, & CD8 T lymphocytes (CD8 cells). B-B cells, C-CD8 cells, D-macrophage
Option 1: Coordinating the immune response by stimulating other immune cells

Question: If there is blunting of this area, which of the following likely happened?
Explanation: Blunting of costophrenic sulcus is usually indicative of small pleural effusion. ~ 200 mL pleural fluid needs to be present for blunting of costophrenic angle to be visible on lateral chest radiograph

Question: A patient complained to you about his increasing weight. "Why is my fat percentage still high when I shifted from high-fat diet to high-carbs diet?" What do you say to the patient?
Correct Answer: This is normal for a high-carb diet.
Explanation: In healthy individuals, hepatic lipogenesis is activated after ingestion of high-carbs, low-fat diet to generate fat from dietary carbs. Insulin activates lipogenic transcription factor, SREBP-1c.
Option 1: This is a sign of a metabolism problem.
Option 2: This is normal for a high-carb diet.
Option 3: This is a sign to switch back to a high-fat diet.
Option 4: This is normal for people who are shifting diets.

Question: Which connective tissue is primarily affected in this condition?
Explanation: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the Fibrillin1 gene (FBN1) that leads to impaired elastin formation & extracellular matrix homeostasis.

Question: Which follows the correct cerebrospinal fluid flow?
Correct Answer: Lateral Ventricle →Foramen Monroe→Sylvius Aqueduct→ 4th ventricle→ foramen Lushka→Arachnoid Villi
Explanation: Lateral Ventricle → foramen Monroe→Third ventricle → Sylvius Aqueduct→ fourth ventricle→ foramen Magendie (medial) → foramen Lushka (lateral)→Subarachnoid space→Arachnoid Villi→Superior Sagittal Sinus
Option 1: Lateral Ventricle→3rd ventricle→Foramen Monroe→4thventricle→foramen Magendie→Superior Sagittal Sinus
Option 2: Lateral Ventricle →Foramen Monroe→Sylvius Aqueduct→ 4th ventricle→ foramen Lushka→Arachnoid Villi
Option 3: Lateral Ventricle→foramen Monroe→Sylvius Aqueduct→ 4th ventricle→Sagittal Sinus→foramen Lushka
Option 4: Lateral Ventricle→foramen Monroe→4thventricle→Sylvius Aqueduct→3rd ventricle→Superior Sagittal Sinus

Question: Which of the following correctly describes each term?
Correct Answer: Ischemia - diminished blood supply; Infarction - cell death
Explanation: Ischemia denotes diminished volume of perfusion.Infarction is tissue death, the cellular response to lack of perfusion,caused by artery blockage, rupture, mechanical compression, or vasoconstriction.
Option 1: Ischemia - complete loss of blood supply; Infarction - diminished blood supply
Option 2: Ischemia - diminished blood supply; Infarction - complete blood supply
Option 3: Ischemia - cell death; Infarction - diminished blood supply
Option 4: Ischemia - diminished blood supply; Infarction - cell death

Question: Paget's disease of bone disrupts the normal cycle of bone renewal, causing bones to become weakened and possibly deformed. Something goes wrong with these cells and they start to absorb bone at a much faster rate than usual. Which cell is the problem?
Explanation: Paget's disease is primarily a disease of the osteoclast (multiple nuclei), increased bone resorption by the osteoclasts, followed by abundant new bone formation that is of poor quality. B- osteoblast

Question: Because of its large supply of blood, the Kiesselbach plexus is the most common site of nose bleeds. Which of the following is not part of the anastomosing blood vessels?
Explanation: Little's area (Kiesselbach's plexus) is on anterior nasal septum, composed of anterior ethmoidal, posterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, & septal branch of the superior labial artery.

Question: Heme is synthesized from:
Explanation: Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl-CoA catalyzed by mitochondrial and aminolevulinate synthase.

Question: What are the two supplements needed for RBC maturation?
Explanation: Vit. B12 and folic acid are essential for DNA synthesis that leads to nuclear maturation and cell proliferation of erythroblasts. Deficiency of these can produce macrocytes (large RBCs).

Question: Carpal tunnel syndrome involves the compression of which nerve?
Explanation: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by pressure on the median nerve.  When the median nerve is compressed, symptoms can include numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hand and arm.

Question: This can be prevented by taking this vitamin.
Explanation: All people capable of becoming pregnant must consume 400 mcg of folic acid (B9) daily to prevent neural tube defects, like anencephaly and spina bifida (shown here).

Question: Injury or fracture in this area will potentially damage this nerve.
Explanation: The common peroneal nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck. Therefore it is most susceptible to injury at the lateral aspect of the knee.

Question: This cell is known to ?
Explanation: High number of eosinophils most often indicates a parasitic infection, an allergic reaction, or cancer. B - macrophage, C - B cells, D - T cells

Question: Which of the following can cause this?
Explanation: Jugular vein distention:increase pressure of SVC causes EJV to bulge.Cause: Right heart failure,pulmonary hypertension,tricuspid valve stenosis,blocked SVC,constrictive pericarditis,cardiac tamponade

Question: Which is which?
Explanation: Peripheral facial palsy: all facial muscles ipsilateral to side of CN 7 involvement. Central palsy: lower facial muscles contralateral to lesion in brain stem above pons & cerebral hemisphere

Question: Which of the following is not the usual referred pain for heart attack?
Explanation:
Chest discomfort pressure, squeezing, fullness or pain. Pain in one or both arms, the back, neck, jaw or stomach.
Shortness of breath, breaking out in a cold sweat, nausea or lightheadedness.

Question: Tibial fractures are usually ?
Explanation: Because tibia is a subcutaneous bone, tibial fractures are frequently open fractures. Open tibial fractures often resulted in amputation, sepsis, or death due to complication of infection & nonunion.

Question: Which of the following does not describe correctly the difference between type 1 and type 2 diabetes?
Correct Answer: Type 1 - symptoms usually appear at a later age, Type 2 - symptoms appear fast
Explanation:
The symptoms for type 1 appear more quickly. The peak occurs in between 4 and 7 years old and between 10 and 14 years old.
Type 2 symptoms can be easier to miss because they appear more slowly.
Option 1: Type 1 - beta cells are being attacked Type 2 - not enough insulin produced/ does not work properly
Option 2: Type 1 - symptoms usually appear at a later age, Type 2 - symptoms appear fast
Option 3: Type 1 - managed with insulin shots Type 2 - managed with exercise, diet, and medications
Option 4: Type 1 - autoimmune condition, Type 2 - weight and lifestyle are risk factors

Question: Number 2 becomes Number 3 when crossing this border.
Explanation: Axillary artery (2) commences from subclavian artery (1) at outer border of first rib and terminates when it becomes brachial artery (3) at outer border of the teres major muscle. 4-radial 5-ulnar

Question: Which of the following muscles is not always present?
Explanation: The palmaris longus is a degenerating weak flexor muscle in the anterior of the forearm. Its absence across the world ranges between 1.5% and 63.9%. Red - FCU, Green - FCR, Yellow - Pronator Teres

Question: Which of the following does not belong to the group?
Explanation: The obturator nerve (L2–L4) supplies the pectineus; adductor (longus, brevis, and magnus); gracilis; and external obturator muscles. The vastus lateralis muscle is innervated by the femoral nerve.

Question: Where do you make an incision for emergency cricothyrotomy?
Explanation: Cricothyrotomy is performed by inserting a tube through an incision in the cricothyroid membrane. This is final step in emergency airway management in CICO scenario (Cannot Intubate, Cannot Oxygenate)

Question: Which is which?
Explanation:
T1 images – 1 tissue type is bright – FAT
T2 images – 2 tissue types are bright – FAT and WATER

Question: Where is this epithelium found?
Explanation: The transitional epithelium, also known as the urothelium, lines the urethra, ureters, and urinary bladder. Cells that are more cuboidal in a relaxed state but more squamous when stretched.

Question: In the Weber Test, the patient heard the sound better at the unaffected right ear. The Rinne test was positive. Which part of the left ear might be damaged?
Explanation: Sensorineural hearing loss: sound perceived louder in unaffected ear, which has better cochlea in Weber test. Normal/positive Rinne on affected ear. SNHL caused by damage to inner ear/auditory nerve.

Question: In most tuberculosis cases, where does the infection usually develop?
Explanation: A high oxygen pressure induced a higher bacillary growth than a low oxygen pressure, thus explaining why most cases of lung TB develop at the apex of the lungs, where oxygen concentrations are high.

Question: Which gives the highest amount energy?
Explanation: Fat provides the most energy of all the macronutrients, at a whopping 9 calories per gram.

Question: Damage to which space could lead to decreased sensation at the lateral aspect of the arm?
Explanation:
QS contents:
-axillary nerve 
passes through the quadrilateral space on its path to innervate the teres minor and deltoid and provide sensation to the lateral arm -posterior humeral circumflex artery

Question: Which of the choices describe the looping position of the recurrent laryngeal nerve correctly?
Correct Answer: Right - subclavian artery, Left - aortic arch
Explanation: Right and left nerves are not symmetrical, with the left looping under the aortic arch, and right looping under the right subclavian artery then traveling upwards. They both travel alongside trachea.
Option 1: Right - aortic arch, Left - subclavian artery
Option 2: Right - R subclavian artery, Left - L subclavian artery
Option 3: Right - subclavian artery, Left - aortic arch
Option 4: Right - brachiocephalic trunk, Left - aortic arch

Question: Which nerve damage will not lead to this?
Explanation: A lesion of L5 root, lumbar plexus, sciatic nerve, common peroneal, or deep peroneal nerve can potentially lead to foot drop due to weakness of the muscles in the foot that assist in dorsiflexion.

Question: Which is not part of the symptoms of this condition?
Explanation: Tetralogy of Fallot: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, a misplaced aorta and a thickened right ventricular wall (right ventricular hypertrophy). Boot-shaped heart is a radiologic sign.

Question: Which correctly describes active immunity?
Correct Answer: A patient is immune to polio due to polio vaccine.
Explanation: Active immunity is a disease resistance that results from the protection of proteins called antibodies. Active immunity is created by our own immune system. Vaccines provide active immunity to disease
Option 1: A newborn baby acquires immunity from the mother through the placenta.
Option 2: A patient given with antibody-containing blood products.
Option 3: A patient receives immediate protection but only lasts a few weeks or months.
Option 4: A patient is immune to polio due to polio vaccine.

Question: A medical student rushes to class and accidentally bumped their elbow and felt a tingling in their fingers. What nerve was compressed?
Explanation: If you've hit your elbow hard and felt a tingling to your fingers, you've compressed your ulnar nerve. Whenever you bend your elbow, you're forcing the nerve to stretch around the bones in the joint.

Question: Which facial muscle is not innervated by CN VII?
Explanation: The masseter is primarily responsible for the elevation of the mandible and some protraction of the mandible. It receives its motor innervation from the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

Question: Occlusion of this artery can lead to locked-in syndrome.
Explanation: Locked-in syndrome is a consequence of basilar artery occlusion,characterized by quadriplegia and anarthria. This is associated with mid-basilar occlusion, leading to infarction of basis pontis.

Question: This karyotype is an example of?
Explanation: Addition of all/part of chromosome (aneuploidy), Loss of entire set chromosomes (monoploidy), gain one/more complete sets of chromosomes (euploidy). Down Syndrome - chromosomal aneuploidy - trisomy 21

Question: Which of the following is enlarged when this sign is present?
Explanation: The Hoffman-Rigler sign is a sign of left ventricular enlargement inferred from the distance between the IVC and LV.​ On a lateral chest radiograph, if the distance exceeds 1.8 cm between them.

Question: Which is not an atypical vertebrae?
Explanation: The atlas (C1), axis (C2) and vertebra prominens (C7) are considered atypical cervical vertebrae. C1 lacks both a vertebral body and a spinous process. C2 with dens. C7 has vertebra prominence.

Question: Which is not an effect of vitamin C deficiency?
Explanation: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to a disease called scurvy, which causes anemia, bleeding gums, bruising and poor wound healing. Vitamin D deficiency can lead to a loss of bone density. Go take Vit C!

Question: Which is not enclosed in the carotid sheath?
Explanation: Common carotid artery (CC), internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein (IV) vagus nerve (CN X) : ‘I See 10CC’s in the IV’

Question: You should not pop pimples within this area because infection could spread to your brain. Which nerve will not be affected if the infection spreads?
Explanation:
By spread of infection through the dangerous area of face which enters the cavernous sinus these nerves are affected. 
O: CN 3
T: CN 4 O: ophthalmic CN 5 M: maxillary CN 5 C: ICA A: CN 6 T: CN 4

Question: You feel a pulse in this area, which is coming from ?
Explanation:
Anatomical snuffbox contents: 
Cephalic vein, (radial) Artery, Radial nerve (Superficial branch), Tendons of extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis
Mnemonic: CARTs

Question: Which is correcrly paired? Acetylcholine (Ach), Norepi (Norepinephrine)
Correct Answer: Ach - decrease heart rate, Norepi - increase heart rate
Explanation: Norepinephrine, released by sympathetic nerves in heart, and epinephrine, released by the adrenal gland, increase heart rate, whereas acetylcholine, released from parasympathetic nerves decreases it.
Option 1: Ach - increase heart rate, Norepi - increase heart rate
Option 2: Ach - decrease heart rate, Norepi - decrease heart rate
Option 3: Ach - increase heart rate, Norepi - decrease heart rate
Option 4: Ach - decrease heart rate, Norepi - increase heart rate

Question: Which artery is most likely damaged in this fracture?
Explanation: The medial circumflex artery is the main artery that supplies the femoral head and neck and it is usually injured during femoral neck fractures.

Question: Which is which?
Explanation: The main difference between them is that kwashiorkor is predominantly a protein deficiency, while marasmus is a deficiency of all macronutrients — protein, carbohydrates and fats.

Question: A patient came to the ER with a stab wound  in the lower part of the chest wall. He experieenced sharp and localized pain because the stabbing object penetrated this layer.
Explanation: The parietal pleurae are highly sensitive to pain, while the visceral pleura are not, due to lack of sensory innervation. Parietal pleura  supplied by phrenic nerv.  Pain is sharp & localized.

Question: In performing a lumbar tap, this is the last penetrated layer.
Explanation: Needle pierces: skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space (internal vertebral venous plexus), dura, arachnoid, and subarachnoid space.

Question: This cell will mature to become ___ and perform which function?
Explanation: Monocytes travel to tissues where it becomes a macrophage or a dendritic cell.Macrophages surround and kill microorganisms, ingest foreign material, remove dead cells, and boost immune responses.

Question: Which is which?
Explanation: The forearm muscles are broadly divided into two compartments: the anterior flexor compartment and the posterior extensor compartment.

Question: Pleural effusion happens when fluid enters between these layers.
Explanation: Between the parietal and visceral layers is a potential space that may be filled with a small amount of fluid.

Question: Where is the lesion if the patient is suffering from bitemporal hemianopia?
Explanation: Bitemporal hemianopia is caused by damage to the optic chiasm and can occur from including tumors, aneurysms, and, less frequently, inflammatory and ischemic diseases.

Question: This is caused by the lack of this vitamin.
Explanation: Bitot's spots are buildup of keratin located  in the conjunctiva of eyes. They can be oval, triangular or irregular. The spots are a sign of vitamin A deficiency & associated with drying of cornea.

Question: Which part(s) shorten(s) when the muscle contracts?
Explanation: The H zone contains only thick filaments and is shortened during contraction. The I band contains only thin filaments and also shortens. The A band does not shorten—it remains the same length.

Question: At which point does ventricular repolarization happen?
Explanation: The T wave is the positive deflection after each QRS complex. It represents ventricular repolarisation.

Question: Removal of this lobe can lead to memory problems.
Explanation: Hippocampus has a major role in learning,  memory, and emotional response. It is located in the inner (medial) region of the temporal lobe.

Question:
Pause. Relax. Inhale. Exhale. Breathe in. Breathe out. Focus on your breathing. Everything will be okay, okay. 🧘‍♂️

Which structure was mainly responsible for what you just did?
Explanation:
The medulla oblongata is the primary respiratory control center. 
The ventral respiratory group stimulates expiratory movements.
The dorsal respiratory group stimulates inspiratory movements.

Question: You see your crush and your heart starts beating fast. All of these other responses happen, except for?
Explanation: Sympathetic: “fight-or-flight” responses, prepares the body for strenuous physical activity. The parasympathetic system regulates “rest and digest” functions, such as producing saliva.

Question: What makes up the anterior rectus sheath in the level between the costal margin and arcuate line?
Explanation: Above costal margin, ant. wall is by EO aponeurosis. Bet. costal & arcuate, anterior is from EO and IO aponeuroses. Below arcuate, anterior sheath is from EO, AO, & TA aponeuroses. (P. 289 snell)

Question: Which supplies blood to the fundus of the stomach?
Explanation:
L. gastric supplies upper right.
R. gastric supplies lower right.
Short gastric supplies fundus L. gastroepiploic supplies upper left. R. Gastroepiploic supplies lower left.

Question: Which of the ff. correctly differentiates jejunum and ileum?
Correct Answer: Jejunum has lesser number of arcades and longer vasa recta than ileum.
Explanation:
Duodenum receives the ducts.
Ileum usually has the Peyer’s patches.
Jejunal wall is thicker because of larger and more plicae circulares. Jejunum is at LUQ, ileum at RLQ.
Option 1: Jejunum receives the bile duct and pancreatic duct, ileum does not.
Option 2: Jejunum usually has the Peyer’s patches more than ileum does.
Option 3: Walls of ileum are thicker than the walls of jejunum.
Option 4: Jejunum has lesser number of arcades and longer vasa recta than ileum.

Question: Where is this auscultation point of this valve? Intercostal space (ICS)
Explanation:
5th L ICS medial to midclavicular line - Mitral 
4th and 5th ICS near lower sternal border - Tricuspid 
2nd L ICS near upper sternal border- Pulmonary 2nd R ICS near upper sternal border - Aortic

Question: Where does the involved cranial nerve here exit?
Explanation: Damage to hypoglossal nerve (9) causes paralysis of tongue. The person sticks out their tongue, it deviates to damaged side. Cranial nerves that exit the medulla are CN 9, 10, 12.  Pons - CN 6, 7, 8

Question: Which is which?
Explanation: Erb's palsy - damage to C5 and C6. Partial/ full paralysis of arm and loss of sensation, waiter's tip. Klumpke's palsy causes paralysis of forearm & hand muscles damage to C8 & T1 nerves, claw hand.

Question: Which is which?
Explanation: Eparterial (upon or above artery) bronchus is a right lung, whereas a lung with a hyparterial (below artery) bronchus is a left lung.

Question: Which of the following is a characteristic of female pelvis?
Correct Answer: Angle of the pubic arch is greater than 90 degrees.
Explanation:
Male pelvis: narrower, less flared, oval/ heart-shaped pelvic inlet, heavier, thicker, pubic arch < 90°. 
Female pelvis: broader, round pelvic inlet, pubic arch > 90°. Favorable for vaginal birth.
Option 3: Angle of the pubic arch is greater than 90 degrees.

Question: Which of the following have valves?
Explanation: Like veins, lymphatic tributaries have valves to prevent backflow of blood. There is no pump in the lymphatic system. Due to high pressure of blood flowing in arteries, they do not require valves.

Question:
A patient suffered from acute ischemic stroke and now has poor or absent grammar and
difficulty forming complete sentences. Which artery was most likely occluded?
Explanation: A dominant, most commonly left-sided, hemisphere stroke results in Broca aphasia if the superior division of MCA is affected. Wernicke's aphasia may be seen if inferior division of  MCA is affected.

Question: Which muscle is not innervated by CN XII?
Explanation: Palatoglossus is the only muscle of the tongue that is not innervated by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII). It is innervated by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).

Question: Which is not innervated by CN X?
Explanation: All the muscles of the pharynx receive innervation from the tenth cranial nerve (vagus nerve) except the stylopharyngeus, which is innervated by the ninth cranial nerve (glossopharyngeal nerve).

Question: Mean arterial pressure is primariy influenced by?
Explanation: Arterioles are the site of the highest resistance across the vascular tree and thus act as the most significant contributor to total peripheral resistance and eventually mean arterial pressure.

Question: A pianist came to consult after a brain surgery. He cannot play the piano anymore because he has problems with hand-eye coordination between the right and left sides of the body. You think he has split-brain syndrome, which means his _ was injured.
Explanation: Split-brain syndrome, arising from partial or complete severing of the corpus callosum, the bundle of nerves that connects the right and left hemispheres of the brain.

Question: Which is the correct amino acid change that lead to these abnormal blood cells?
Explanation: Sickle mutation causes substitution of valine for glutamic acid as the 7th amino acid of the beta globin chain. The resulting hemoglobin tetramer (alpha2/betaS2) is poorly soluble when deoxygenated.

Question: Which is correctly paired?
Correct Answer: Brain (white inside, grey outside), Spinal cord (grey inside, white outside)
Explanation: In the brain, grey matter is mainly found in the outer layers, while in the spinal cord it forms the core 'butterfly' shape. White matter refers to the areas of CNS which host majority of axons.
Option 1: Brain (grey inside, white outside), Spinal cord (white outside, grey inside)
Option 2: Brain (white inside, grey outside), Spinal cord (grey inside, white outside)

Question: If these neuropores do not close, then this will happen.
Correct Answer: Caudal pore - Spina bifida, Rostral neuropore - Anencephaly
Explanation: Spina bifida occulta: failure of caudal neuropore to close. Anencephaly: failure of rostral neuropore to close; the brain and cranial vault are grossly malformed with normal hindbrain development.
Option 1: Caudal neuropore - Anencephaly, Rostral neuropore - Spina bifida
Option 2: Caudal pore - Spina bifida, Rostral neuropore - Anencephaly

Question: Which of the follow does not originate from glioblasts?
Explanation: Microglia from yolk sac macrophages that arise during the first wave of primitive hematopoiesis. Glioblasts: mature ependymal cells, astrocytes, and oligodendroglia are derive.

Question: Which structures will dilate if the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius) is blocked?
Explanation: Obstruction of CSF flow at aqueduct of Sylvius results in dilation of the lateral & 3rd ventricles and increased intracranial pressure. 1 lateral 2 3rd 3 4th ventricle 4 Monroe 5 Sylvius 6-9 Cisternae

Question: The patient is positive for Babinski sign, you think that there is an upper motor lesion. The patient shows muscle weakness, increased muscle tone with spasticity, increased muscle stretch reflexes. Specifically, which gyrus was affected?
Explanation: Precentral gyrus is anatomical location of the primary motor cortex and is responsible for the control of voluntary movement. Lesions occurring within the precentral gyrus affect upper motor neurons.

Question: Which of the following cannot affect the cardiac output?
Explanation: Cardiac output is heart rate (HR) x stroke volume (SV). Stroke volume calculated by subtracting the end-systolic volume from the end-diastolic volume. Pulmonary pressure is not in the equation.

Question: Which is correctly paired?
Correct Answer: S1 - AV valves closed - low pitch - longer; S2 - semilunar valves closed - high pitch - shorter
Explanation: S1 is a single sound because mitral & tricuspid valve closure occurs almost simultaneously. S2 closure of semilunar valves. S1 is longer, louder, duller, & lower-pitched than the second heart sound.
Option 1: S1 - semilunar valves closed - low pitch - longer; S2 - AV valves closed - high pitch - shorter
Option 2: S1 - AV valves closed - high pitch - longer; S2 - semilunar valves closed - low pitch - shorter
Option 3: S1 - AV valves closed - low pitch - longer; S2 - semilunar valves closed - high pitch - shorter
Option 4: S1 - AV valves closed - low pitch - shorter; S2 - semilunar valves closed - high pitch - longer

Question: Which of the following heart defect will most likely lead to cyanosis?
Explanation: Baby with Tetralogy of Fallot develop cyanosis. Acyanotic lesions: ventricular septal and atrial septal defect, atrioventricular canal, pulmonary stenosis, PDA, aortic stenosis & coarctation of aorta.

Question: Which is/are responsible for phase 2 of this ventricular action potential?
Explanation: The plateau phase is maintained by a finely tuned balance between two types of inward Ca2+ currents and at least four types of outward K+ currents.

Question: Your patient is bleeding heavily because of a car accident. Which of the following will not happen to maintain his cardiac output?
Explanation: Blood loss of moderate degree causes fall in blood pressure, which is compensated to an extent by baroreceptor mediated rise in heart rate, vein vasoconstriction & increased vascular resistance.

Question: Which of the following does not belong to the group?
Explanation: Only TGA is a cyanotic heart defect. Acyanotic: ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary valve stenosis, aortic valve stenosis, and coarctation of aorta.

Question: Which are unique structures in the fetus that allow for shunting of blood?
Explanation:
3 shunts: 3 ductus venosus, 5 foramen ovale, 11 ductus arteriosus 
 2 umbilical artery, 10 umbilical vein

Question: Which factor is the most important in determining blood flow?
Explanation: Determine the resistance to blood flow: vessel diameter (or radius), vessel length, and viscosity of the blood. The most important quantitatively and physiologically is vessel diameter.

Question: You want to increase the blood pressure of your patient. Which of the following should not be given to the patient?
Explanation: Vasoconstriction: norepinephrine, dopamine, endothelin. Nitric oxide vasodilator. Vasoconstriction reduces volume of blood vessels. Blood flow is reduced, resistance raised so higher blood pressure.

Question: Which of the following is true?
Explanation: 60% of blood is present in veins, capillaries have the largest total cross-sectional & surface area. Net filtration occurs near arterial end of the capillary, net reabsorption occurs near venous end.
Option 1: Arteries contain majority of the blood volume.
Option 2: Veins have the largest surface area.
Option 3: In capillaries, the arterial end favors absorption while the venous end favors filtration.

Question: This is dangerous because
Explanation: Ventricular fibrillation: Chaotic irregular deflections without identifiable P-QRS-T waves can cause death within minutes. Rapid, erratic heartbeats cause heart to stop pumping blood.

Question: Which is the gold standard for diagnosing coronary heart diseases?
Explanation: Coronary angiography, also called cardiac catheterization, is a minimally invasive study that is considered the gold standard for

Question: Which is good for listening to S1 and S2 when doong chest examination?
Explanation:
Diaphragm: High frequency 
Systolic murmurs, S 1, S 2, Ejection clicks. 
Bell: Low frequency  Diastolic murmurs, S3, S4 are low frequency sounds. Bell with applied pressure behaves like diaphragm.

Question: You should not do this while measuring blood pressure.
Correct Answer: Use cuff with length that is 40% of the upper arm circumference
Explanation: Cuff bladder length should be approximately 80% of the circumference of the upper arm and the cuff bladder width should be optimally 40% of the circumference of the upper arm. All are correct.
Option 1: Use cuff with length that is 40% of the upper arm circumference
Option 2: Do palpatory method before auscultatory method
Option 3: Use the bell to hear Korotkoff sounds
Option 4: Record diastolic pressure when the Korokoff sounds go silent

Question: Atrial fibrillation shows
Explanation: Atrial fibrillation is a rapid, irregularly irregular atrial rhythm.

Question: Which is true?
Correct Answer: Stable angina - pain during exertion, Unstable angina - pain during rest
Explanation: Stable angina pain is predictable. chest pain typically lasts a short time, perhaps five minutes or less, more common form. Unstable angina (a medical emergency) is unpredictable and occurs at rest.
Option 1: Stable angina - pain during exertion, Unstable angina - pain during rest
Option 2: Stable angina - least common form  Unstable angina - more common form
Option 3: Stable angina - an medical emergency, Unstable angina - can be relieved using nitrates
Option 4: Stable angina - pain lasting about 30 minutes, Unstable angina - pain lasting about 5 min

Question: You should be alert when this is elevated in a patient with previous myocardial infarction.
Explanation: Levels of cTn (cardiac troponin) are frequently elevated in patients with heart failure (HF) and reduced ejection fraction (EF) and correlate with the risk for mortality.

Question: Which of the following indicates a myocardial infarction that involves the full thickness of the myocardium?
Explanation: Acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction is an event in which transmural myocardial ischemia results in myocardial injury or necrosis. 1 - normal, 3&4 NSTEMI:  depressed ST wave or T-wave inversion.

Question: Which is the most common cause of STEMI (ST elevation myocardial infarction)?
Explanation: The most serious form of acute coronary syndrome, ST segment elevation myocardial infarction, or STEMI, most often results from complete thrombotic occlusion of a major epicardial coronary artery.

Question: Which is the most commonly occluded artery?
Explanation: The Left Anterior Descending artery is most commonly occluded of coronary arteries. It supplies interventricular septum & bundle branches of conducting system. 1 aorta 2 RCA 3 RMA 4 LCA 5 LCircumflex

Question: Which of the following does not belong to the superior mediastinum?
Explanation: Superior mediastinum Organs: thymus, trachea, esophagus. The middle mediastinum contains the heart, and its protective sheath, the pericardium.

Question: Thanks to these cells the alveoli do not collapse. Happy breathing!
Explanation: Type II pneumocytes: synthesizing cells of the alveolar surfactant, which reduce surface tension and prevent alveolar collapse. 1 macrophage, 2 type 1, 3 type 2. Type 2 shorter, fatter, paler nuclei.

Question: Which finger should you use for percussion and which part should it hit?
Explanation: The middle finger of the left hand is placed on the part to be percussed and pressed firmly against it, with slight hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint.

Question: Blockage towards these structures will cause communicating hydrocephalus?
Explanation: This type of hydrocephalus is caused by inability to reabsorb CSF by the arachnoid granulations, which occur from meningeal scarring as a result of bacterial meningitis or intraventricular hemorrhage.

Question: Which can be found in the fovea?
Explanation: The fovea is a depression in the inner retinal surface, about 1.5 mm wide, the photoreceptor layer of which is entirely cones and which is specialized for maximum visual acuity.

Question: Which is responsible for decompressing sound energy, allowing outward motion of vibration?
Explanation: Round window decompress acoustic energy that enters cochlea via stapes against the oval window. Inward motion of oval window leads to outward motion of round window. 1 oval 2 round 3 auditory tube

Question: Which is which?
Explanation: Epidural hematoma: convex, “lens-shaped” collection of blood that does not cross the suture lines of the skull. Subdural hematoma: concave, “crescent-shaped” density that crosses the suture lines.

Question: Which can happen if the patient has an overreactive vagus nerve?
Explanation: An overactive vagus nerve can also result in an abnormally low heart rate, or bradycardia. 1 normal 2 tachycardia 3 bradycardia 4 irregular rhythm

Question: Which is the correct sequence? Full shade means no agglutination. Anti means antigen.
Explanation: Group A if agglutination occurred with Anti-A test serum; group B with the Anti-B test serum; group AB with both test serums, and O if no agglutination. Same procedure for Rh factor.

Question: The patient experienced sharp chest pain with pain radiating in the trapezius. You suspected pericarditis. Which nerves are involved for the sensation of pain?
Explanation: Phrenic nerve is from C3, C4, and C5. if pain radiates to one or both trapezius muscle it is likely due to pericarditis because the phrenic nerve that innervates these muscles traverses pericardium

Question: Which suture connect frontal and parietal bone?
Explanation: The coronal suture is a dense and fibrous association of connection tissue located in between the frontal and parietal bones of the skull.

Question: Which fontanelle takes the longest time to close?
Explanation: Typically, fontanelles close by the time your baby is 18 months old. The posterior fontanelle usually closes first — within 2 months of birth. The anterior fontanelle closes between 7 and 18 months.

Question: You want to measure the pressure in the right atrium of your patient. You use this vein as a reference.
Explanation: The right internal jugular vein has traditionally been felt to most accurately reflect the right atrial pressure. JVP tracing can provide the status of a patient’s intravascular volume.

Question: Where should you ausculate when you suspect mitral valve stenosis?
Explanation:
1 aortic 2 pulmonic 3 erb's point 4 tricuspid 5 mitral 
The fifth left intercostal space medial to the midclavicular line (apex): Mitral valve area

Question: Refer to quiz 189, which should you use to better hear mitral valve stenosis?
Explanation: The bell is used to hear low-pitched sounds. Use for mid-diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis or S3 in heart failure.

Question: Increase in the following factors leads to an increase in diffusion, except for
Explanation: The rate of diffusion is proportional to both the surface area and concentration difference and is inversely proportional to the thickness of the membrane.

Question: Which pair is correct?
Correct Answer: CO2 - low pressure gradient, high solubility; O2 - high pressure gradient,  less solubility
Explanation: Carbon dioxide is highly soluble in water unlike oxygen. Po2 in oxygenated blood (95 mm Hg)>in body cells (40 mmHg) and Pco2 in oxygenated blood is 40 mm Hg of <Pco2 in body cells (45 mm Hg).
Option 1: CO2 - low pressure gradient, less solubility; O2 - high pressure gradient more soluble
Option 2: CO2 - high pressure gradient, high solubility; O2 - high pressure gradient more soluble
Option 3: CO2 - low pressure gradient, high solubility; O2 - high pressure gradient,  less solubility
Option 4: CO2 - low pressure gradient, high soluble; O2 - low pressure gradient, high solubility

Question: Which of the following cannot be directly measured in spirometer?
Explanation:
Residual Volume(RV)
It is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal exhalation. Normal adult value is averaged at 1200ml. It can't be measured by spirometry.

Question: You are exercising. These muscles will help in expelling CO2, except
Explanation: Active exhalation: rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, external & internal oblique. Internal intercostals bring ribs down in forced expiration. External intercostals elevate ribs in inspiration.

Question: Which of the following happens during inspiration?
Explanation: During inhalation: The intrapleural pressure (which is usually -4 mmHg at rest) becomes more negative, decrease in the intra-alveolar pressure to a value below atmospheric pressure about -1 cmH2O.

Question:
The patient came with the following ABG results: pH = 7.45, PaCO2 = 32 mm Hg, PaO2 = 138 mm Hg, HCO3 = 23 mEq/L

Normal values reference:  pH (7.35-7.45) PaO2 (75-100 mmHg) PaCO2 (35-45 mmHg) HCO3 (22-26 meq/L)  The patient has?
Explanation:
pH >7.40, so alkalemia is present.
The PaCO2 is decreased, indicating a respiratory alkalosis, and the HCO3 is normal. 
The value consistent with pH is PaCO2. This is primary respiratory alkalosis.

Question: You are climbing Mount Apo, the following processes happen in your body, except
Explanation: All are physiological effects of acclimization to high altitudes.

Question: You are exercising and breathing heavily. You expect your oxygen-hemoglobin curve to shift to the
Explanation: The shift of the oxygen dissociation curve to the right occurs in response to an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide, decrease in pH, or both, Bohr Effect.

Question: Most of the CO2 that is found in the body is in what state?
Correct Answer: Dissolved in water and dissociate as HCO3-
Explanation: In the blood, CO2 is carried in several different forms. Approximately 80% to 90% is dissolved in water, 5% to 10% is dissolved in the plasma, and 5% to 10% is bound to hemoglobin.
Option 1: Dissolved in water and dissociate as HCO3-

Question: Also known as the love hormone
Explanation: As oxytocin is associated with trust, sexual arousal and relationship building, it's sometimes referred to as the “love hormone". Happy Valentine's Day!

Question: Which of the following CANNOT be known using spirometry?
Explanation: FRC is the sum of expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and residual volume (RV) The total lung capacity (TLC)  = RV+IVC, or from: TLC = FRC+IC.

Question: Which of the following correctly describes the flow of O2 in the body?
Correct Answer: Atmosphere (159 mmHg), alveoli (104 mmHg), arterial blood (100 mmHg), tissues (40 mmHg)
Explanation: PO2 in tissues is low (40 mmHg) relative to arterial blood (100 mmHg). In the atmospheric air, pO2 is about 159 mm Hg. In the alveolar air, it is about 104 mm Hg.
Option 1: Tissues (159 mmHg), arterial blood (104 mmHg), alveoli (100 mmHg), atmosphere (40 mmHg)
Option 2: Atmosphere (159 mmHg), alveoli (104 mmHg), arterial blood (100 mmHg), tissues (40 mmHg)
Option 3: Tissues (104 mmHg), arterial blood (40 mmHg), alveoli (154 mmHg), atmosphere (100 mmHg)
Option 4: Atmosphere (104 mmHg), alveoli (159 mmHg), arterial blood (40 mmHg), tissues (100 mmHg)

Question: The PCO2 in tisssues is 45 mmHg and 40 mmHg in venous blood. As you noticed, the pressure gradient is not so high, but this is not a problem because
Correct Answer: The CO2 is very soluble in water
Explanation: A much smaller diffusion gradient is needed for CO2 because CO2 is much more soluble than oxygen.
Option 2: The CO2 is very soluble in water
Option 3: The CO2 molecular weight is small
Option 4: The pressure gradient only plays a very small influence

Question: You have an exam tomorrow. You slept early to feel energized for the exam. Which stage is very critical for body recovery and growth? Look at graph for colors.
Explanation: stage 3 may also be called delta sleep or slow-wave sleep (SWS). Experts believe that this stage is critical to restorative sleep, allowing for bodily recovery and growth.

Question: Inhale. Exhale. The quiet exhalation is mainly caused by
Explanation: normal expiration is passive, energy is not required to push air out of lungs. the elasticity of the lung causes the lung to recoil, as diaphragm and intercostal muscles relax following inspiration

Question: Where is the structure responsible for your respiratory rate located?
Explanation: The pneumotaxic center, located in the upper pons, sends inhibitory impulses to the inspiratory center, terminating inspiration, and thereby regulating inspiratory volume and respiratory rate.

Question: Which is which?
Correct Answer: Carotid bodies -> CN 9, Aortic bodies -> CN 10
Explanation: The aortic bodies are supplied by fibers of the vagus nerve (X) whereas the carotid body receives fibers primarily from the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX).
Option 1: Carotid bodies -> CN 9, Aortic bodies -> CN 10
Option 2: Carotid bodies -> CN 10, Aortic bodies -> CN 9

Question: A woman presented with sudden onset of speech disturbance and confusion. She spoke hesitantly and non-fluently, she seemed not to be able to find words to respond & showed impairment in repetition & comprehension to questions with complex syntax. She has
Explanation: Broca aphasia in which the output of spontaneous speech is markedly diminished and there is a loss of normal grammatical structure. Specifically, conjunctions and the use of prepositions are lost.

Question: Which quadrant is most commonly affected by breast cancer?
Explanation: Most breast cancers develop in the upper outer quadrant of the breast, closest to the armpit. This is because this area has a lot of glandular tissue.

Question: Which is which?
Correct Answer: Utricle - horizontal orientation, Saccule - vertical orientation
Explanation: Utricle is most sensitive to tilt when head is upright. saccule is most sensitive to tilt when head is horizontal. Macula of utricle is relatively horizontal, macula of saccule is vertically placed.
Option 1: Utricle - horizontal orientation, Saccule - vertical orientation
Option 2: Utricle - vertical orientation, Saccule - horizontal orientation
Option 3: Utricle - right orientation, Saccule - left orientation
Option 4: Utricle - left orientation, Saccule - right orientation

Question:
Your patient shows the following ABG results:
pH= 7.33
PaCO2= 25 HCO3=12 PaO2= 89  Normal values reference:  pH (7.35-7.45) PaO2 (75-100 mmHg) PaCO2 (35-45 mmHg) HCO3 (22-26 meq/L)  The proper compensation for this is?
Explanation: Compensation for a metabolic acidosis is hyperventilation to decrease the arterial pCO2. The pH is acidotic,PaCO2 is 25 (low) which should create alkalosis. This is metabolic acidosis.

Question: Which organs are mainly responsible for modulating acid base balance?
Explanation: The renal system and the pulmonary system are the two main modulators. The pulmonary system adjusts pH using carbon dioxide. The renal system by reabsorbing bicarbonate and excreting fixed acids.

Question: All of these are signs of respiratory distress, except for
Explanation: Crackles: If the air sacs in the lungs fill with fluid and there's air movement in the sacs. The air sacs fill with fluid in pneumonia or heart failure. The rest are signs of respiratory distress.

Question: The sensors found in the bifurcation of the common carotid artery are very sensitive to
Explanation: The carotid and aortic bodies have high blood flow, and their chemoreceptors are primarily sensitive to decreases in the partial pressure of O2 (Po2).

Question: Which is which?
Correct Answer: Bohr effect - release O2, Haldane effect - release CO2
Explanation: The Bohr effect helps the metabolizing tissues release oxygen from oxyhemoglobin, while the Haldane effect helps the lungs release carbon dioxide from carboxyhemoglobin
Option 1: Bohr effect - release O2, Haldane effect - release O2
Option 2: Bohr effect - release CO2, Haldane effect - release CO2
Option 3: Bohr effect - release O2, Haldane effect - release CO2
Option 4: Bohr effect - release CO2, Haldane effect - release O2

Question: These are good substitutes for cigarette when you are trying to quit smoking, except
Explanation: Nicotine replacement therapy gives nicotine – form of gum, patches, sprays, inhalers, or lozenges – can help relieve physical withdrawal symptoms. Vaping is linked to chronic lung disease and asthma.

Question: This is due to
Explanation: Peau d'orange (French for orange peel) is characterized by edema and pitting and results from blockage of lymphatic drainage with or without associated stromal infiltration.

Question: Which structures are involved here
Explanation: Suspensory ligaments of Cooper: involvement of these ligaments in the malignant process draws the skin toward the tumor, resulting in skin dimpling, which may be accentuated by raising the arm upward.

Question: If breast cancer metastasizes, which lymph nodes are affected first?
Explanation: Axillary lymph nodes are in the armpits, which are close to the breasts. Because the axillary lymph nodes are so close, breast cancer usually spreads to them before other lymph nodes.

Question: Which shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve is correct?
Correct Answer: Shift to right - tissues, Shift to left - lungs
Explanation: Left shift of the curve is a sign of hemoglobin's increased affinity for oxygen (e.g. at the lungs). Similarly, right shift shows decreased affinity (tissues).
Option 1: Shift to right - lungs, Shift to left - tissues
Option 2: Shift to right - tissues, Shift to left - lungs

Question: You studied for your exam all night long. You did not even consider a nap 😭. Your hormones are in these levels.
Explanation: Sleep-deprived adults tend to have higher ghrelin levels, more hunger, and less feeling of fullness. Prolonged sleep loss decreases the circadian amplitude of leptin. So sleep!!!

Question: All are innervated by oculomotor nerve, except
Explanation: LR6(SO4)3 LR6: Lateral rectus CN 6, SO4: Superior oblique CN 4. The rest innervated by CN 3.

Question: Damage at this level, the patient will need a mechanical ventilator for breathing.
Explanation: C3-C4-C5 are responsible for innervating the diaphragm, patients with complete spinal cord injuries above C4, would have an impaired diaphragmatic function and would usually need ventilatory support.

Question: Dysphagia can be caused by the enlargement of which chamber?
Explanation: The esophagus comes in contact with the left atrium hence, left atrial dilatation displace the esophagus and resulted in dysphagia.

Question: Choose the best answer.
Explanation:
No, nicotine does not cause cancer.
Nicotine is an addictive drug that keeps you smoking, but it is the other harmful chemicals in cigarettes that make smoking so dangerous.

Question: Enlargement of this organ is usually associated with loss or problems in this special sense.
Explanation: Tumors of the pituitary can compress optic nerves leading to a gradual loss of vision. This vision loss usually begins with a deterioration of peripheral vision on both sides.

Question: The patient is asthmatic you expect A, and is expected to give B to manage the patient.
Correct Answer: A- Contract of smooth muscles, B - Give bronchodilators
Explanation: Bronchodilators make breathing easier by relaxing the muscles in the lungs and widening the airways, used to treat asthma - inflammation of the airways & bronchial muscles tighten and contract.
Option 1: A- Dilation of smooth mucles, B- Give bronchodilators
Option 2: A- Dilation of smooth muscles, B- Give bonchoconstrictors
Option 3: A- Contract of smooth muscles, B - Give bronchodilators
Option 4: A- Contract of smooth muscles, B- Give bronchoconstrictors

Question: Which conduct the fastest?
Explanation: Purkinje fibers distributing to ventricular contractile cells conduct impulses the fastest since they are thin filaments having the most voltage-gated Na+ channels in the sarcolemma-like neurons.

Question: Which pacemaker cell will lead to very slow heart rate?
Explanation: The primary pacemakers of the SA node fire at a rate of about 60–90/s. Ancillary pacemakers fire at slower rates: AV node (40–60/s) > His–Purkinje (20–40/s) > ventricular myocytes.

Question: You are destressing after the exam. You dance your heart out, which tract is very active every time you make your dance moves?
Explanation: The corticospinal tract carries motor signals from the primary motor cortex in the brain, down the spinal cord, to the muscles of the trunk and limbs so involved in voluntary movement of muscles.

Question: Gold standard ✨️for diagnosing asthma
Explanation: Spirometry. The presence of an obstructive picture, with a ratio of FEV1/FVC <70%, and associated reversibility following administration of bronchodilator is in keeping with asthma.

Question: Music is life 🎺 thanks to your cochlea that detect sound frequencies. Which is the right pairing?
Correct Answer: Base - high frequency, Apex - low frequency
Explanation: high frequency sounds stimulate the base of the cochlea, whereas low frequency sounds stimulate the apex.
Option 1: Base - high frequency, Apex - low frequency
Option 2: Base - low frequency, Apex - high frequency

Question: Your strongest elbow flexor 💪
Explanation: The brachialis is the only pure flexor of the elbow joint–producing the majority of force during elbow flexion.

Question: The baby's O2 sat is low so you decide to give O2 support. After 20 minute exposure to oxygen supplementation, the O2 sat is still below normal. The problem is most likely
Explanation: The most likely causes of profound cyanosis unresponsive to oxygen supplementation in infants are congenital heart disease (CHD) and persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).

Question: Which is sign of coarctation of aorta?
Correct Answer: Femoral pulse is weaker than carotid pulse.
Explanation: Pulse in femoral area or feet weaker than pulse in the arms or neck (carotid). Sometimes, femoral pulse may not be felt at all. The blood pressure in the legs is usually weaker than in the arms.
Option 1: Femoral pulse is stronger than radial pulse.
Option 2: Femoral pulse is weaker than carotid pulse.
Option 3: Blood pressure in legs is stronger than arms.

Question: Your auscultating a 3 year old child, normally you find the point of maximal impulse at the
Explanation: In children under age 7, apex is located in their fourth intercostal space and with increasing age gradually moves into the 5th space in most children.

Question: Hyperresonance upon percussion is typical for these cases, except
Explanation: Hyperresonant sounds may be heard when percussing lungs hyperinflated with air, such as in COPD, acute asthmatic attack, pneumothorax. Decreased resonance is noted with pleural effusion.

Question: This is caused by
Explanation: Vitamin D Deficiency: Swelling may also occur at the costochondral junctions of the sternum (rachitic rosary sign), due to a deficiency of calcium Caused by rickets or hypoparathyroidism.

Question: You are measuring the respiratory rate of a newborn. You measured 57 breaths/min. You interpret this as
Explanation: Normally, the newborn's respiratory rate is 30 to 60 breaths per minute. Tachypnea is defined as a respiratory rate greater than 60 breaths per minute.

Question: You are measuring the heart rate of a newborn. The heart rate is 80 bpm. You interpret this as
Explanation: Infant (to 12 months): 100-160 beats per minute (bpm) Toddler (1-3 years): 90-150 bpm. Preschooler (3-5 years): 80-140 bpm. School-aged child (5-12 years): 70-120 bpm.

Question: All of these happen, the moment the baby takes his or her first breath, except
Explanation: Inflation of lungs decreases blood pressure in the right atrium and ventricle. The flow of blood, from left to right atrium, blocking the shunt, decrease lung pressure & resistance to blood flow.
Option 1: Decrease blood flow resistance to lungs

Question: A newborn baby was immediately referred to you because of murmurs in the left upper parasternal border. It has been 20 hours since her birth and you decide to intepret the case as _.
Correct Answer: Need to be closely monitored for 2 weeks
Explanation: The ductus arteriosus functionally close by 12 to 24 hrs of age in healthy, full-term newborns, with permanent closure occurring within 2-3 weeks. So too soon to diagnose a congenital heart disease.
Option 4: Need to be closely monitored for 2 weeks

Question: Which sound is heard when this shunt is not fully closed?
Explanation: PDA is an abnormal connection between aorta and pulmonary artery, which normally should be closed in infancy. Since aortic pressure is higher than pulmonary pressure, a continuous murmur occurs.

Question: Which sound is heard in most parts of the lung?
Explanation: Vesicular breath sounds (1) are soft, low-pitched sounds that doctors can hear throughout the lungs, primarily when a person breathes in. 2 - bronchovesicular, 3 - bronchial, 4- tracheal

Question: Which breathing pattern is typical for patients with uncontrolled sugar levels?
Explanation: Kussmaul breathing is characterized by rapid, deep breathing at a consistent pace. It's a sign of diabetes-related ketoacidosis (DKA), which affects people with diabetes.

Question: Which of the following does not pass through the level T12 of the diaphragm?
Explanation: aortic hiatus are the aorta, the azygous vein and the thoracic duct. It is located approximately at the level of the twelfth thoracic vertebra (T12). Contents of esophageal hiatus:vagus nerves (T10).

Question: Which is incorrectly paired in terms of the starting point of chemical digestion?
Explanation: The digestion of lipids begins in the oral cavity via lingual lipases. Digestion begins in the mouth with salivary amylase released during the process of chewing.  Protein begins in stomach.

Question: Which is the largest part of the stomach?
Explanation: The body is the largest and main part of the stomach. This is where food is mixed and starts to break down.

Question: Which is not indicated by this structure?
Correct Answer: IV disc between T3 and T4
Explanation:
Sternal angle: RATPLANT
Rib 2nd, Aortic arch,Trachea & Pulmonary trunk bifurcation, Left recurrent laryngeal (Ligamentum arteriosum), Azygos vein, Nerves–cardiac plexus,Thoracic duct,IV disc bet T4&T5
Option 2: IV disc between T3 and T4

Question: The pointed structure is important in
Explanation: muscle spindles are stretch detectors, and sense how much and how fast a muscle is lengthened or shortened. When muscle is stretched, this change in length is transmitted their intrafusal fibers.
Option 3: Sliding of myosin and actin filaments

Question: Which is the correct arrangement?
Explanation: myofilaments are arranged in myofibrils which are bundled in a fascicle and fascicles make a muscle. Muscle covered by perimysium, fascicle-epimysium, myofibrils- endomysium, myofilament - sarcolemma.

Question: The fetal hemoglobin has
Explanation: Like adult Hg, HbF is made up of four units, of which include two alpha and two gamma units, the latter of which replaces the beta units of adult Hg.

Question: You define vein as
Correct Answer: Blood vessel that carries blood to the heart
Explanation: A blood vessel that carries blood to the heart from tissues & organs in the body. Generally, veins carry deoxygenated blood. The exception is pulmonary veins take oxygenated blood from lungs to heart.
Option 1: Blood vessel that carries blood to the heart
Option 2: Blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart
Option 3: Blood vessel that carries deoxygenated blood
Option 4: Blood vessel that carries oxygenated blood

Question: You are right heart dominant, if your right coronary artery gave rise to
Explanation: Heart “dominance” is determined by which  coronary arteries supplies the PDA which supplies the AV node. The heart is right dominant (85%) if by RCA, left dominant (7.5%) if circumflex branch of LCA.

Question: Which is correct?
Explanation: The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated fetal blood toward the placenta and the umbilical vein carries newly oxygenated blood. Pulmonary veins oxygenated blood, pulmonary artery deoxygenated blood

Question: Odd one out
Explanation: Celiac trunk arises from the abdominal aorta and commonly gives rise to three branches: left gastric artery, splenic artery, and common hepatic artery.

Question: Which is correctly paired?
Explanation: Foregut is supplied mainly by the celiac artery. The other two arteries that supply the gut are the superior mesenteric artery (for the midgut) and inferior mesenteric artery (for the hindgut).

Question: Majority of the pancreatic enzymes are drained into the
Correct Answer: A - papilla of Vater, B - papilla of Santorini
Explanation: Pancreas divisum - drained through accessory pancreatic duct into the minor duodenal papilla (papilla of Santorini). Normal pancreas to major duodenal papilla (papilla of Vater).
Option 1: A - papilla of Vater, B - papilla of Santorini
Option 2: A - papilla of Santorini, B - papilla of Vater

Question: This is very common in the
Explanation: Duodenal ulcers occur most frequently in the first portion of the duodenum (over 95%), with approximately 90% located within 3 cm of the pylorus.

Question: The spleen is mostly found in
Explanation: The spleen is an organ shaped like a shoe that lies relative to the 9th and 11th ribs and is located in the left hypochondrium and partly in the epigastrium.

Question: Odd one out
