Option 1: Small pox - centrifugal, Chicken pox - centripetal
Option 2: Small pox - centripetal, Chicken pox - centrifugal

Question: Which of the following is correctly paired for atopic dermatitis distribution?
Correct Answer: Infants - extensor surfaces; Adults - flexural areas
Explanation: In infants, lesions occur on the face, scalp, neck, eyelids, and extensor surfaces of the extremities. In older children and adults, lesions occur on flexural surfaces such as the neck and the antecub
Option 1: Infants - extensor surfaces; Adults - flexural areas
Option 2: Adults - extensor surfaces; Infants - flexural areas

Question: Acne during this stage of life is very uncommon and should raise suspicion for an endocrinopathy.
Explanation: This occurs during 1-7 years of age. Serologic testing (total and free testosterone, DHEA, LH/FSH, bone age) may be done to test for endocrinopathy.

Question: In the aVR lead, pericarditis manifests as:
Correct Answer: ST segment depression, PR segment elevation
Explanation: All depolarizations are going away from lead aVR, thus all waves (P, QRS, T) are negative. For the other leads, pericarditis manifests with ST segment elevation and PR segment depression.
Option 1: ST segment elevation, PR segment depression
Option 2: ST segment depression, PR segment elevation

Question: Which of the following is the least potent sodium channel blocker?
Explanation: Potency of Class I Antiarrhythmic Drugs: IC > IA > IB; IA - quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide; IB - lidocaine, phenytoin; IC - flecainide, moricizine

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched (failure of specific process - defect):
Correct Answer: fusion of septum primum, septum secundum - ASD; formation of membranous septus - VSD
Option 1: fusion of septum primum, septum secundum - ASD; formation of membranous septus - VSD
Option 2: fusion of septum primum, septum secundum - VSD; formation of membranous septus - ASD

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched (risk factor-congenital heart defect)?
Correct Answer: Congenital Rubella - PDA; Gestational Diabetes - TGA
Option 1: Congenital Rubella - TGA; Gestational Diabetes - PDA
Option 2: Congenital Rubella - PDA; Gestational Diabetes - TGA

Question: Pertains to a prenatal decrease in volume and mass of a cardiac chamber
Explanation: Shunt: abnormal communication; Atresia: complete obstruction; Atrophy - postnatal decrease

Question: This radiologic finding is due to hypertrophy of which of the four chambers?
Explanation: A characteristic radiologic finding of Tetralogy of Fallot is a boot-shaped heart called Couer en sabot which is attributed to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Question: Babies with hypoplastic left heart syndrome are dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus and an ASD. What is administered to keep the ductus arteriosus open?
Explanation: Indomethacin, a prostaglandin inhibitor, closes the ductus arteriosus.

Question: Which of the following describes the embryological etiology of an Ebstein Anomaly?
Correct Answer: Failed/aberrant delamination of the tricuspid valve
Explanation: Choice A: TAPVR; Choice B: Truncus Arteriosus; Choice D: Tetralogy of Fallot
Option 1: Failure of the pulmonary venous plexus and veins to link to the LA
Option 2: Absence or incomplete partitioning of the truncus arteriosus by the spiral/conotruncal septum
Option 3: Failed/aberrant delamination of the tricuspid valve
Option 4: Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum

Question: Which layer is responsible for elastic recoil of the valve?
Explanation: Fibrosa: dense collagenous core for structural support; Spongiosa: central core of loose connective tissue; Ventricularis/Attrialis: rich in elastin, for elastic recoil

Question: A hallmark finding of mitral valve prolapse is the deposition of myxomatous matrix at what layer?
Explanation: Hallmark finding of MVP: Deposition of myxomatous matrix at and marked thickening of the spongiosa layer with associated attenuation of the fibrosa layer

Question: Chronic rheumatic heart disease (CRHD) virtually always presents as stenosis of which heart valve?
Explanation: In chronic rheumatic heart diseases which present as valvular stenosis, the mitral valve is always virtually involved. In isolation, MV in 66% of RHD cases; MV + AV in 25%; TV infrequent; PV rare

Question: Which of the following is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in patients with prostethic valves?
Explanation: S. epidermidis is the most common agent in prosthetic valve IE; S. aureus: in IV drug users; S. viridans: IE involving abnormal native valves; P. aeruginosa not implicated in IE

Question: Carcinoid heart disease most commonly affects which side of the heart?
Explanation: The right side of the heart is first exposed to blood with the bioactive compounds secreted by carcinoid tumors. These are degraded by the pulmonary vascular bed before reaching the left side.

Question: In which of the following histological cross-sections would microinfarcts be more likely produced?
Explanation: B: unstable angina; Thin precarious layer of tissue covers necrotic core. Easily disrupted >> macrophages exposed to bloodstream >> thrombus formation >> can break up >>  microinfarcts

Question: Although MI has a majorly male predilection, postmenopausal women are equally at risk due to a sudden decrease in estrogen (has protetctive effect on epithelium). With this, it is necessary for women to undergo postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy.
Explanation: Postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy (HRT) has not been shown to be protective against MI. In some cases, it may even aggravate the risk.

Question: This type of necrosis is due to the sudden influx of which ion?
Explanation: Contraction Band Necrosis: sudden influx of blood brings Ca which enters the damaged myocytes. Ca stimulates actin, myosin to interact, resulting in an exaggerated contracted appearance of myofibrils.

Question: In which of the following ruptures would an acute onset of severe mitral regurgitation occur?
Explanation: A: ventricular free wall >> cardiac tamponade; B: ventricular septum >> VSD + LtR shunt; C: papillary muscle >> acute onset of severe mitral regurgitation

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched?
Correct Answer: infarcted areas - volume overload - dilation; viable areas - pressure overload - hypertrophy
Option 1: infarcted areas - volume overload - dilation; viable areas - pressure overload - hypertrophy
Option 2: infarcted areas - pressure overload - dilation; viable areas - volume overload - hypertrophy
Option 3: infarcted areas - volume overload - hypertrophy; viable areas - pressure overload - dilation
Option 4: viable areas - volume overload - dilation; infarcted areas - pressure overload - hypertrophy

Question: Which of the following rates or health indices is incorrectly defined?
Correct Answer: Perinatal Mortality Rate : (# of stillbirths & deaths in the 1st year of life per 1000 live births)
Explanation: It should be “1st *week of life” not “1st year of life”
Option 1: Case Fatality Rate : proportion of patients who die of the disease (rarely reported as percent)
Option 2: Infant Mortality Rate : (# of deaths in a yr of children <1 yo) / (# of live birth in the same year)
Option 3: Perinatal Mortality Rate : (# of stillbirths & deaths in the 1st year of life per 1000 live births)
Option 4: All of the above are correctly defined.

Question: Peripheral resistance vessels pertain to which of the following?
Explanation: Peripheral resistance is regulated primarily at the level of the arterioles

Question: Renin is secreted by the kidneys in response to:
Explanation: Choice A should be low BP at afferent arterioles while Choice C should be low sodium at DCT
Option 3: High sodium at distal convoluted tubules (DCT)

Question: While examining a histologic slide of a kidney, you observed arteriolar lumens narrowed by concentric, laminated, thick walls. This is most consistent with what finding?
Explanation: Hyaline Arteriosclerosis: homogenous, pink hyaline thickening; Hyperplastic Arteriosclerosis: concentric, laminated (onion-skin) thickening; Pulmonary Hypertension: medial hyperplasia of pulmonary a.

Question: In systemic hypertensive heart disease, an increase in interstitial connective tissue imparts stiffness to the wall which leads to impaired left ventricle filling during diastole. This leads to enlargement of which heart chamber?
Explanation: Impaired left ventricle filling during diastole leads to volume overload in the left atrium, resulting in left atrial enlargement.

Question: A 65/M with known HTN is referred to PGH due to cardiomegaly in X-ray. He has been hypertensive since 50 y.o. and reported taking medications only when his wife tells him to. Correlating the Hx and imaging findings, gross findings in his heart would be?
Correct Answer: LV has concentric thickening of walls
Explanation: Hypertensive heart disease (HHD) results from pressure overload from HTN. Minimum pathologic criteria of HHD includes presence of LV hypertrophy (concentric) in the absence of other CV pathology.
Option 1: RV has thickened walls and is dilated
Option 2: LA enlargement due to water retention
Option 3: Dilated RA due to water retention
Option 4: LV has concentric thickening of walls

Question: Which of these deviations commonly refers to when the eye of the patient turns inward?
Explanation: Esotropia (inward), Hypotropia (downward), Hypertropia (upward), Exotropia (outward)

Question: Which of these pertains to partial loss of vision, with blind spots in otherwise normal visual field, and can be central, peripheral, or scintillating?
Explanation: Oscillopsia (apparent "movement" of images), Photopsia (experiencing “flashes” of light), Iridescent vision (halo or rainbows around source of light)

Topic: Anatomy of the Eye and Orbit
Question: Based on the spiral of Tillaux, which of these EOMs is the farthest from the limbus?
Explanation: Arrangement of EOMs in the Spiral of Tillaux (i.e. the recti muscles from nearest to farthest from the limbus): MR, IR, LR, SR

Question: Which of the following is incorrect about hyperopia?
Correct Answer: Refractive hyperopia is due to steeper corneal curvature
Explanation: Refractive hyperopia is due to FLATTER corneal curvature
Option 1: Light rays focus on a point behind the retina
Option 2: Axial hyperopia is due to shorter eyeball (by 1-3mm)
Option 3: Refractive hyperopia is due to steeper corneal curvature
Option 4: Can be corrected by converging lens

Question: A patient presented with red itchy eyes without pain, but with watery discharge. Which condition/s can you most likely suspect?
Explanation: By algorithm for red eye without pain: (+) red eye, (-) pain, (+) watery discharge, (+) itchy, the condition is most likely Allergic Conjunctivitis compared to the other choices.

Question: A 23-year-old man with palpitations was observed with the following 12-lead resting ECG. There is suspected right-sided accessory pathway involvement. Which of the following differentials is most likely?
Explanation: During sinus rhythm (when Px is not having an episode of tachycardia), the Wolff-Parkinson-White pattern may be observed in the resting 12-lead ECG.

Question: All of the following are possible underlying etiologies for multifocal atrial tachycardia EXCEPT:
Explanation: MAT occurs in people with one or more other health problems, which include any of the following: e.g., COPD, CHF, CAD, diabetes, CKD, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, sepsis

Question: Keratoconus often presents with
Explanation: Keratoconus is a condition that causes the cornea to gradually thin and bulge into a cone shape. The cone shaped cornea usually causes myopia and astigmatism.

Question: The strongest part of the orbital wall is the
Explanation: The lateral orbital wall is formed by two bones: the zygomatic bone and the greater wing of the sphenoid. This is the strongest of the walls of the orbit.

Question: You are suspecting severe orbital trauma. To examine the orbital fracture, you order
Explanation: Computed Tomography (CT) is the gold standard for orbital trauma assessment. CT enables evaluation of orbital fractures, soft tissue injuries, foreign bodies.

Question: In general, systolic pressure _______ and diastolic pressure ______ when measured in more distal arteries
Explanation: Reference: HPIM p. 1669

Question: 25/M arrives at the emergency room. His eyes appear to have multiple pupils. Which of these can you suspect from the patient?
Explanation: Iridodialysis is when the iris becomes disinserted from its root, and this is characterized by polycoria i.e. appearance of multiple pupils.
Option 3: C. Iris might be disinserted from its root

Question: Ocular tuberculosis most commonly presents with which of the following signs or symptoms:
Explanation: Ocular tuberculosis most commonly presents with blurred vision and light sensitivity; whereas the Dalrymple’s sign is most common in Thyroid Eye Disease (TED).

Topic: History Taking in Adult Patients with CVD
Question: All of the following are warning signs for peripheral artery disease EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Poorly healing or non-healing wounds of the arms and legs
Explanation: Any poorly healing or non-healing wounds of the legs or feet.
Option 2: Any first degree degree relative with abdominal aortic aneurysm
Option 3: Poorly healing or non-healing wounds of the arms and legs
Option 4: Fatigue, aching, numbness or pain that limits walking

Topic: History Taking in Adult Patients with CVD
Question: Which of the following cases can be classified as cardiac syncope?
Correct Answer: JVG (23/M) faints and experiences acute jerking movements on his arms and legs.
Explanation: Hysteria, hyperventilation, and psychogenic causes of fainting are NOT classified as syncope. Brief clonic movements can occur during an episode of cardiac syncope.
Option 1: RUA (26/F) experiences lightheadedness while having a panic attack.
Option 2: RSC (17/F) faints at the sight of blood dripping.
Option 3: RGF (30/M) faints upon recalling his experience being trapped during a typhoon.
Option 4: JVG (23/M) faints and experiences acute jerking movements on his arms and legs.

Question: Which of the following drugs is contraindicated for patients post-myocardial infarction?
Explanation: Class 1C Na-channel blockers are contraindicated for patients with ishcemic conditions and patients with structural heart diseases.

Question: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of Torsades de pointes?
Explanation: Magnesium (typically given intravenously as magnesium sulfate) is the drug of choice that is used to mitigate increased Ca levels in patients presenting with Torsades de pointes.

Question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
Correct Answer: The best laboratory markers for MI are the cardiac enzymes troponin and creatine-kinase MB.
Explanation: Increased cardiac enzymes in the blood are the most distinctive markers for MI.
Option 1: During the early phase of the myocardial response, ATP increases while lactate levels decrease.
Option 2: Once blood supply to the myocardium is restored, this is followed by immediate recovery.
Option 3: After 30 minutes, the actin-myosin complex will relax, followed by depletion of myocyte glycogen.
Option 4: The best laboratory markers for MI are the cardiac enzymes troponin and creatine-kinase MB.

Question: Which of the following is the most common differential for claudication?
Explanation: Atherosclerotic peripheral artery disease (PAD) is the most common etiology for claudication, manifesting as pain or discomfort in affected muscle groups with exercise, usually resolving with rest.

Question: All of the following are signs of endocarditis EXCEPT:
Explanation: Tendon xanthomas are typically suggestive of familial hypercholesterolemia.

Question: Which of the following is INCORRECTLY matched?
Correct Answer: PMI: apex is palpable with the fingertips when palpating for the RV
Explanation: The point of maximal impulse (PMI) is palpable over the LV apex beat, located in the 5th ICS left midclavicular line
Option 1: RV: palpate with the heel of the hand at the left parasternal area
Option 2: LV: palpate with the fingers across the chest at the 5th ICS, left midclavicular line
Option 3: PMI: apex is palpable with the fingertips when palpating for the RV
Option 4: All of the above are true

Question: A patient came to you complaining about her contact lens that have gone behind the eye. You tell her that this is not possible because of the
Explanation:
While contact lenses can slide in any direction from our cornea, the conjunctival fornix prevents lenses from going "behind the eye."
Contact lens can only go as far as the crease in the conjunctiva.

Question: Injury or damage to this layer will lead to corneal scarring
Explanation: The Bowman cells do not regenerate; therefore, an injury to the Bowman membrane will result in a permanent corneal scar. Take good care of your cornea!

Question: This is the patient's visual field. You think the lesion is in the
Explanation: A superior quadrantanopia results from an insult to the optic radiation inferiorly in the temporal lobe while an inferior quadrantanopia is caused by damage to the parietal lobe optic radiation.

Topic: Congenital Heart Diseases + Basic Biology of the CVS
Question: Transposition of the great vessels is most directly related to abnormal development of which of the following?
Explanation: During development, the truncal ridges spiral, getting the aorta and pulmonary trunks in proper orientation. If they fail to spiral, transposition of the great vessels can occur.

Question: As you are looking at your phones right now (near object), the following occurs
Correct Answer: Contract ciliary muscles > relax suspensory ligaments > thicker lens
Explanation: Accommodation. Contraction of ciliary muscles reduces the tension in suspensory ligaments and allows the lens to contract into a more spherical shape.
Option 1: Contract ciliary muscles > relax suspensory ligaments > thinner lens
Option 2: Relax ciliary muscles > contract suspensory ligaments > thiner lens
Option 3: Contract ciliary muscles > relax suspensory ligaments > thicker lens
Option 4: Relax ciliary muscles > contract suspensory ligaments > thicker lens

Topic: Congenital Heart Diseases + Basic Biology of the CVS
Question: In aortic valvular atresia, blood passes into the aorta through a patent ductus arteriosus.
Explanation: In order for a patient with an atretic aortic valve to survive, there must be a patent ductus in order for blood to reach the systemic circulation.

Question: All of the following are homeostatic properties of endothelial cells EXCEPT:
Explanation: Physiologically, endothelial cells are antiproliferative and only produce growth factors and chemoattractants during injurious states.

Question: All of the following increases ventricular preload EXCEPT:
Explanation: During a maintained increase in intrathoracic pressure, venous return is interrupted, and cardiac output falls.

Question:
The summary of the patient's history is the following.
Chief complaint - red eye
Pain - no Discharge - watery Itch - yes You proceed to PE and expect to see this on conjunctiva.
Explanation: Follicular reactions in viral and chlamydial infections. Papillary reactions in chronic blepharitis, allergic and bacterial conjunctivitis, contact lens wear. Itchy points to allergy.

Question: All of the following are examples of congenital heart diseases with R to L shunts EXCEPT:
Explanation: The foramen ovale is a physiologic fetal structure which allows shunting of oxygenated blood from the right atrium to left atrium. It becomes functionally open when right-sided pressure increases.

Question: Which of the following has the lowest chance of termination for the management of ventricular tachycardia:
Explanation: Vagal maneuvers only have a 40-50% chance of termination. Modified Valsalva maneuver is generally considered as the more effective alternative.

Question: Which of the following is incorrectly matched:
Explanation: For the subcostal window, the transducer is placed beneath the xiphoid process, orienting ridge towards the patient’s left shoulder.

Question: Former drinkers are defined as…
Correct Answer: People have previously consumed alcohol but have not done so in the previous 12-month period
Option 1: People who have never consumed alcohol
Option 2: People have previously consumed alcohol but have not done so in the previous 10-month period
Option 3: People have previously consumed alcohol but have not done so in the previous 12-month period
Option 4: People who were currently consuming alcohol during the survey period

Question:
Arrange the following in the correct chronological sequence:

A. Loss of contractility B. Onset of ATP depletion C. Microvascular injury D. Irreversible cell injury
Explanation:
Onset of ATP depletion: seconds
Loss of contractility: <2 minutes
Irreversible cell injury: 20-40 minutes Microvascular injury: >1 hour

Question: This type of RCT is more prone to bio-creep:
Explanation: In a non-inferiority trial, bio-creep is where a new therapy is slightly worse than the preceding drugs, an ineffective or harmful therapy might be incorrectly declared efficacious.

Question: Which of the following is INCORRECTLY matched?
Correct Answer: Recurrence: % of patients entering a phase in which the disease is no longer detectable
Explanation:
Remission: % of patients entering a phase in which the disease is no longer detectable
Recurrence: % of patients who have return of disease after a disease-free interval
Option 1: 5-year survival: % of patients surviving 5 years from some point in the course of their disease
Option 2: Recurrence: % of patients entering a phase in which the disease is no longer detectable
Option 3: Disease-specific mortality: # of people/10,000 population dying of a specific disease
Option 4: Response: % of patients showing some evidence of improvement following an intervention

Question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
Correct Answer: C. Justice is to be treated fairly, regardless of circumstance.
Explanation:
A. Can have positive AND negative contributions
B. Describes health equality
D. Describes sickness
Option 1: A. Commercial entities have negative contributions to human health and planetary health and equity.
Option 2: B. Health equality emphasizes the importance of reducing disparities to achieve fairness.
Option 3: C. Justice is to be treated fairly, regardless of circumstance.
Option 4: D. In a sociological perspective, disease refers to the subjective experience of illness.

Question: Which part of the airway has the greatest air resistance?
Explanation: Site of most airway resistance is the medium-sized bronchi. Smallest airways contribute very little to resistance, because combined cross-sectional area is much larger than the intermediate bronchi.

Topic: Heart Disease in Children (Overview and Clinical Manifestations)
Question: Which of the following findings is used to identify supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous return?
Explanation: Snowman sign refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It indicates a indicates a supracardiac type total anomalous pulmonary venous return.

Question: This congenital problem most likely happen because of an error in the lung development during
Explanation: Diagnostic feature of Esophageal atresia: inability to pass a catheter into the stomach. Failure of esophageal endoderm to proliferate rapidly during Week 4 to 5 due to SHH signaling mutations.

Question: For the patient with partial anomalous pulmonary venous return, which of the following is the most recommended management strategy?
Explanation: Surgical patch closure remains as the gold standard for patients with PAPVR. Advantages include fewer complications, shorter hospitalization, and reduced need of blood products.

Topic: Rheumatic Fever and Rheumatic Heart Disease
Question: Which of the following is TRUE about management of rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease?
Correct Answer: D. 1 week before termination of steroids, aspirin must be administered to patients with RF or RHD.
Explanation:
A. orally -> intramuscularly
B. 3 weeks -> 10 days
C. 10 years -> 5 years
Option 1: A. Penicillin V is more effective when administered orally.
Option 2: B. The treatment duration for primary prevention of rheumatic heart disease is 3 weeks.
Option 3: C. The treatment duration for patients with rheumatic fever without carditis is 10 years.
Option 4: D. 1 week before termination of steroids, aspirin must be administered to patients with RF or RHD.

Topic: Rheumatic Fever and Rheumatic Heart Disease
Question: Which of the following is present in rheumatic fever but NOT in viral infections?
Correct Answer: Presence of tender, enlarged cervical nodes
Explanation: The rest are characteristics of viral infections.
Option 4: Presence of tender, enlarged cervical nodes

Question: Which of the following is considered a normal finding in the pediatric ECG:
Correct Answer: C. The QRS duration lengthens with age.
Explanation:
A. NOT considered pathologic
B. Present with prominent R waves
D. NOT considered pathologic
Option 1: A. T wave inversion is always considered pathologic.
Option 2: B. Right precordial leads present with prominent S waves.
Option 3: C. The QRS duration lengthens with age.
Option 4: D. Q waves are suggestive of ischemic heart disease in neonates.

Question: Beck's triad is comprised of which of the following symptoms:
Correct Answer: Hypotension, diminished heart sounds, elevated CVP
Explanation: Beck's triad consists of the presence of low blood pressure, distension of the jugular veins, and muffled or diminished heart sounds on cardiac auscultation.
Option 1: Hypotension, diminished heart sounds, elevated CVP
Option 2: Decreased CVP, hypotension, diminished heart sounds
Option 3: Hypertension, increased CVP, diminished heart sounds

Question: A 10/F presents with fever, fatigue, and irregular nontender hemorrhagic macules on the palms and soles. Hx revealed mitral valve implantation. If the PE showed the presence of dental caries in the Px oral cavity, what is the most likely etiologic agent?
Explanation: Streptococcus mutans, a pathogen of dental caries, is known to be associated with infective endocarditis (IE).

Question: Maria has been coughing for 7 weeks now. You classify this as
Explanation: Cough: acute, defined as lasting less than 3 weeks; subacute, lasting 3–8 weeks; and chronic, lasting more than 8 weeks.

Question: The most potent drugs for TB are
Explanation: Multidrug-resistant TB (MDR TB) is caused by TB bacteria that are resistant to at least isoniazid and rifampin, the two most potent TB drugs. These drugs are used to treat all persons with TB disease.

Question: A person with latent TB infection will test --- in a tuberculin skin test.
Explanation: The only sign of TB infection is a positive reaction to the tuberculin skin test or TB blood test. Persons with latent TB infection are not infectious and cannot spread TB infection to others.

Question: Pursed lip breathing can help people with
Explanation: Pursed lip breathing is a technique that helps people living with asthma or COPD when they experience shortness of breath.

Question: A baby presents with dyspnea, cyanosis, and dextrocardia. This triad is most commonly seen in
Explanation: Dyspnea, cyanosis, and dextrocardia comprise the classic clinical presentation of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, a congenital lung problem associated with neural tube, cardiac, and midline defects.

Question: All of the following are defense mechanisms at the alveolar level except
Explanation: Mucociliary clearance is not a mechanism for lung defense in the alveoli. It is the most important lung defense in the upper airway.

Question: This test is crucial to find the lesion causing severe hemoptysis
Explanation: Bronchoscopy can be crucial for patients with hemoptysis, can help detect the bleeding source (particularly in moderate-severe hemoptysis cases).

Question: The ECG of a 2-month-old infant shows a QRS axis of 150 degrees. Interpret. Take note that the normal axis in ages 1-3 months is +70° (+10° to +125°).
Explanation:
If value goes beyond normal range: right axis deviation
If value falls below normal range: left axis deviation

Question: Unlike unfractionated heparin, LMWH only acts on this factor.
Explanation:
Unfractionated heparin - intrinsic factors
LMWH - only Xa

Question: Which of the following can be considered as the primary difference between in-hospital and out-of-hospital arrest in the pediatric chain of survival?
Correct Answer: Using seatbelts is a classic example of out-of-hospital prevention to reduce the risk of injury.
Explanation:
In-hospital arrest: first step is early recognition
Out-of-hospital arrest: first step is prevention
Option 1: High-quality CPR can only be provided in an in-hospital setting.
Option 2: As healthcare providers, calling for help is not routinely done out-of-hospital.
Option 3: Using seatbelts is a classic example of out-of-hospital prevention to reduce the risk of injury.
Option 4: Post-cardiac arrest care is provided only when the patient has been admitted for strict monitoring.

Question: Drugs used for hypertension and heart failure, EXCEPT:
Explanation: Should be aldosterone ANTAGONISTS

Question: Which of the following is NOT an important aspect in providing high quality chest compressions?
Correct Answer: For a child, use 2 fingers to provide compressions.
Explanation: For children, the heel of one hand is typically used to provide compressions or both hands (for those with smaller-sized hands).
Option 1: For every 30 compressions (or 15 compressions if there are 2 rescuers), you give 2 breaths.
Option 2: For a child, use 2 fingers to provide compressions.
Option 3: Interruptions must be kept to less than 10 seconds to minimize complications.
Option 4: Avoid overinflation of the lungs to allow blood flow to the heart.

Question: Which of the ff. drugs can be used to prevent long-term cardiac remodeling and deterioration of cardiac function, thereby reducing mortality and morbidity?
Explanation: ACE inhibitors, along with ARBs, beta blockers, and aldosterone antagonists, are drugs that antagonize the neurohormones that cause cardiac remodeling - angiotensin II, aldosterone, and norepinephrine

Question: The pressure-natriuresis phenomenon consists of the following pathophysiologic changes EXCEPT:
Explanation:
All choices are TRUE.

Pressure natriuresis refers to the concept that increased renal perfusion pressure leads to a decrease in tubular reabsorption of sodium and an increased sodium excretion.
Option 1: Increased GFR leading to increased urinary sodium excretion
Option 2: Increased production of atrial natriuretic factor
Option 3: Increased arterial pressure to achieve natriuresis to maintain sodium balance

Question: A 30/M bodybuilder has been experiencing tight bursting pain recently in his calf muscles recently during training. Which of the following is the most probable cause of his leg pain?
Explanation: CCS occurs most commonly in heavily muscled athletes during exercise

Question: You are asked for advice on the optimal dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) for a 67/F with a history of STEMI 1 year ago. You assess that she is at high ischaemic risk, but not high bleeding risk. Which of the following is the best treatment choice?
Correct Answer: Aspirin 75-100 mg once-daily plus clopidogrel 75 mg once-daily
Explanation:
PX is 1 year after an MI and has tolerated DAPT for this duration. Given she is at high ischemic
risk but not high risk for bleeding, long-term DAPT with aspirin and clopidogrel should be considered.
Option 1: Aspirin 75-100 mg once-daily plus prasugrel 5 mg once-daily
Option 2: Aspirin 75-100 mg once-daily plus ticlopidine 250 mg twice-daily
Option 3: Aspirin 75-100 mg once-daily plus clopidogrel 75 mg once-daily
Option 4: Aspirin 75-100 mg once-daily plus tirofiban 25 mg once-daily

Question: A 56/M patient with a Hx of intracranial hemorrhage and severe arterial hypertension is admitted to the ER. His chief complaint is chest pain. Coronary angiography reveals stenosis of the medial RCA. Which fo the following is the best treatment choice?
Explanation: The best treatment option for the patient is clopidogrel since it is safer and better tolerated. Both prasugrel and ticagrelor are contraindicated in patients with a Hx of intracranial hemorrhage.

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched?
Explanation: All correct 🤩
Option 1: Aortic stenosis: RUSB: Systolic ejection murmur radiating to the neck
Option 2: Pulmonic stenosis: LUSB: Systolic ejection murmur radiating to the back

Question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
Correct Answer: D. Transposition of the Great Arteries is the most common cyanotic heart disease in newborns.
Explanation:
A- Not dependent on PDA
B- Should be tricuspid atresia AND pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum
C- Easier to perceive cyanosis if higher Hb D- TRUE. vs TOF (most common in childhood)
Option 1: A. Patients with TAPVC are dependent on PDA to survive.
Option 2: B. The only cyanotic defect w/ dec. pulmo. blood flow & left heart enlargement is tricuspid atresia.
Option 3: C. In polycythemic patients, cyanosis only becomes clinically apparent at lower oxygen saturations.
Option 4: D. Transposition of the Great Arteries is the most common cyanotic heart disease in newborns.

Question: RSC (61/F) walked to her workplace 2 blocks away from her home. She then climbed up a flight of stairs due to elevator maintenance. She began to feel a heavy, squeezing sensation on her chest. What is the CCS Functional Classification of her angina?
Explanation: Grade III: Angina occurs on walking 1 to 2 blocks on the level and climbing 1 flight of stairs at a normal pace and under normal conditions.

Topic: Heart Diseases in Children (Overview and Clinical Manifestations)
Question: KFS (10/F) complains of chest pain after running around the playground in her school. The most likely cause of the patient's chest pain is:
Explanation: Musculoskeletal causes is the most common etiology for chest pain among younger children. Px also presents with chief complaint after doing an activity, which supports the likelihood of this etiology.

Question: The most common trigger of asthma in infants is
Explanation: Viruses are the most common cause of acute asthma episodes in infants 6 months old or younger.

Question: An asthmatic patient with a "silent chest" means that she is experiencing
Explanation: Silent chest is the absence of wheezing and coughing due to fatigue and severely constricted bronchioles. Silent chest usually precedes respiratory failure and is a life-threatening medical emergency.

Question:
Which tracheal shift is correctly matched? 

Contralateral (to the diseased side), Ipsilateral (to the diseased side)
Explanation:
Deviated away from diseased side: Pneumothorax, Pleural effusion.
Deviated towards diseased side: Atelectasis, Agenesis of lung.

Question: This is the complete failure of both airway and parenchymal development.
Explanation: Pulmonary agenesis: complete failure of airway and parenchymal development. Pulmonary aplasia: incomplete parenchyma supplied by a rudimentary bronchus. Pulmonary hypoplasia: underdeveloped parenchyma

Question: An asthmatic patient came to check if her medications are working. She said that she still has night awakenings due to asthma, uses SABA reliever 3x/week, and experiences daytime symptoms 3x/week. But no activity limitation due to asthma. Her asthma is
Explanation:
Well controlled - 0 yes. Partly 1–2 yes. Uncontrolled: 3–4 yes. 
Qs: Daytime asthma symptoms >2x/week? Night awakening due to asthma. SABA reliever for symptoms >2x/week. Any activity limitation.

Question: Which of the following is TRUE?
Correct Answer: KD - has coronary artery involvement; Myocarditis - has NO coronary artery involvement
Option 1: KD - has coronary artery involvement; Myocarditis - has NO coronary artery involvement
Option 2: KD - has NO coronary artery involvement; Myocarditis - has coronary artery involvement
Option 3: Coronary arteries are involved in both KD and myocarditis.

Question: In ____, swelling may extend to the feet, resulting in the formation of dorsal hump, in contrast to ____ where the feet are spared.
Explanation: In lipedema, the feet are spared because of the retinaculum, which limits the deposition of fat.

Question: An infant noted to have marked diaphoresis upon feeding, prolonged feeding times, and growth failure would be classified under what class based on the Ross classification for heart failure in children?
Explanation:
Clues:
I - asymptomatic
II - mild III - marked IV - symptoms at rest

Question:
Given the following:

R arm: 110 mmHg L arm: 100 mmHg R ankle posterior: 92 mmHg R dorsalis pedis: 98 mmHg L ankle posterior: 94 mmHg L dorsalis pedis: 92 mmHg  What is the correct interpretation for the Px's right ABI?
Explanation:
The Px's right ABI is 0.89, which is within the abnormal range.

Noncompressible: >1.4 Normal: 1.0 to 1.4 Borderline: 0.91 to 0.99 Abnormal: < or = 0.90

Question: Patient started with a sore throat then leading to difficulty swallowing and drooling. Lateral radiograph of the neck demonstrates the thumb sign. You are worried about risk of airway obstruction. The subtype of the pathogen responsible is
Explanation: Epiglottitis is usually caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria. Type b most virulent, commonly causing bloodstream invasion and meningitis in children younger than 2 years.

Topic: Approach to Articular and Musculoskeletal Disorders
Question: Which of the following is an ARTICULAR structure?
Explanation: Articular structures include the synovium, synovial fluid, articular cartilage, intraarticular ligaments, joint capsule, and juxtaarticular bone.

Topic: Approach to Articular and Musculoskeletal Disorders
Question: This is described as loss of full movement resulting from a fixed resistance caused either by tonic spasm of muscle or by fibrosis of periarticular structures:
Explanation:
Dislocation: abnormal diplacement
Deformity: abnormal shale or size
Crepitus: palpable vibratory or crackling sensation

Topic: Approach to Articular and Musculoskeletal Disorders
Question: Which of the following is the most common cause of septic arthritis?
Explanation: Septic arthritis can be caused by bacterial, viral or fungal infections. Bacterial infection with Staphylococcus aureus (staph) is the most common cause.

Question: Which of the following is a cartilage-attached molecule that decreases coefficient of friction?
Osteoclast differentiation can be blocked by a decoy receptor known as:
Explanation: RANKL signals used for osteoclast differentiation can be blocked by osteoprotegerin (OPG).

Question: All of the following are parameters used to measure the level of participation in Rifkin pentagram model except
In a stakeholder analysis, a high influence and low stake stakeholder should be
In a people-centered primary care, this concept refers to the stable, long-term, personal relationship between the population and the professionals who are their entry point to the health system

In a complex adaptive system, simple unidirectional relationships may reach critical points with unpredicted effects. Such is demonstrated when herd immunity is achieved at a certain critical vaccination rate. This feature of the CAS refers to
A good health service delivery offers a complete range of health services with no undue barriers of cost, language, culture, or geography. What measures are being described here?
Explanation: Comprehensiveness refers to a complete range of health services while accessibility pertains to the absence of undue barriers of cost, language, culture, or geography.

Question: Which of the following historical event is correctly matched to its thrust/theme
Correct Answer: Commission on Social Determinants of Health Report: Neoliberalism poses a threat to health
Explanation: One of the value of the CSDH Report is the emphasis put on neoliberalism and the threat it poses to health.
Option 1: Community-Based Initiatives: Health care facilities should be publicly funded
Option 2: Commission on Social Determinants of Health Report: Neoliberalism poses a threat to health
Option 3: Alma Ata Declaration: Attaining UHC through PHC
Option 4: Astana Conference: Health is a right

Topic: Impact of Illness on the Family
Question: The following stages of the family life cycle demonstrate centrifugal forces except
Explanation: Centrifugal forces refer to forces in the family that move you out. A family in later life exhibit centripetal forces as illness among aging parents or family members tend to pull family members in.

Topic: Impact of Illness on the Family
Question: In this particular stage in the family illness trajectory, the primary role of the physician includes dealing with emotionally critical misperceptions and rallying the family.

Topic: Principles of Imaging Techniques in Musculoskeletal Disease
Question: Describe the lesion in the radiographic image shown:
Explanation: The radiograph shows a sclerotic lesion in osteosarcoma.

Topic: Approach to Articular and Musculoskeletal Disorders
Question: How would you classify the disorder shown?
Explanation: Achilles tendinitis is an example of an non-articular disorder, involving the Achilles tendon.

Topic: Principles of Imaging Techniques in Musculoskeletal Disease
Question: Structure B seen in ultrasound corresponds to which structure under X-ray:
Explanation: Structure B is the femur under ultrasound, while the femur under the X-ray pertains to structure Y.

Topic: Principles of Imaging Techniques in Musculoskeletal Disease
Question: (Using the same image in Quiz 1129) Identify structure A.
Which anti-TB drug has not been associated with hepatotoxicity?
Explanation: While isoniazid, rifampicin and pyrazinamide are known to cause hepatotoxicity, ethambutol and streptomycin are considered not to be hepatotoxic.

Question: Decrease in visual acuity and disturbance in red-green discrimination is a side effect of this drug.
Explanation: The first sign of an ocular toxic reaction to ethambutol is a red/green colour vision disturbance, followed by a reduction in visual acuity and finally, in some cases, a central scotoma.

Question: This drug can kill the bacteria residing in macrophages.
Explanation: Pyrazinamide is bactericidal for M. tuberculosis when organisms are located in an acid environment such as the macrophage, exerts maximum effect during the early phase (2 months) of therapy.

Question: Who is the patient with low to no risk for obstructive sleep apnea?
Correct Answer: All raises suspicion for obstructive sleep apnea
Explanation: The STOP-BANG is an assessment tool used to help diagnose Obstructive Sleep Apnea. Snore, Tired Daytime, Observed apnea, high BP, high BMI >35, older than 50, large neck size (>43 cm M, 41 F), male
Option 1: Sir Teddy who is 50 years old
Option 2: Sir Manuel who has uncontrolled hypertension
Option 3: Sir Mike with a BMI of 36
Option 4: Ma'am Tessa who has been observed to snore loudly and gasps multiple times while sleeping

Question: Transient tachypnea of the newborn happens in
Explanation: TTN present in infants of any gestational age shortly after birth. Fetal risk factors include male, perinatal asphyxia, prematurity, small for gestational age, and large for gestational age infants.

Question: Meconium aspiration syndrome can most commonly happen among
Explanation: Meconium aspiration usually affects term and post-term newborn babies that are born with amniotic fluid stained with meconium. Meconium is rarely found in the amniotic fluid prior to 34 weeks AOG.

Question: AB (50/F) complains of early morning joint stiffness but is eased with physical activity. Upon PE, the PIP is hyperextended while DIP is flexed. What do you call this finding?
Explanation: All are manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis.

Question:
Match the following terms to their corresponding definitions. 

I - Subluxation II - Dislocation III. Contracture  A. Loss of full movement B. Incomplete approximation of articulating surfaces  C. Surfaces not in contact
Characteristics of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Pain spontaneously resolves after 2-4 weeks even without treatment
Explanation: JIA persists beyond 6 weeks even with medication
Option 2: Pain spontaneously resolves after 2-4 weeks even without treatment
Option 4: May manifest with uveitis and band keratopathy

Topic: Physical Examination of the Musculoskeletal System
Question: During PE, no pain was noted upon passive flexion of the patient’s knee. However, when asked to flex his knee on his own, patient reported pain. You suspect:
Explanation: Articular: both active and passive ROM are limited; extra-articular: active only (Bates)

Question: Which of the following is TRUE about a spinal injury caused by hyperextension?
Correct Answer: C. Both anterior and posterior ligaments may break.
Explanation:
A. caused by a rear-end collision
B. due to an anterior force
D. osteophytes can impinge on the cord
Option 1: A. It is usually caused by a head-on collision.
Option 2: B. It is caused by whiplash, which involves acute backward bending due to an anterior force.
Option 3: C. Both anterior and posterior ligaments may break.
Option 4: D. Among geriatric patients, osteocytes can impinge on the cord even without vertebral displacement.

Question: A 17/M comes to the ER with a stab wound. He was stabbed at T12 in the back. On PE, there is muscle weakness affecting the whole R LEx, impaired proprioception sense of the R leg & loss of pain and temp. sense of the L leg. What is the most likely Dx?
Explanation: Brown-Séquard syndrome is due to hemisection of the spinal cord, manifesting with weakness & proprioceptive deficits on the ipsilateral side & loss of pain and temperature sensation contralaterally.

Question: All of the following are normal findings in evaluating the hand, EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Flexing of digits during passive wrist flexion
Explanation: Flexing of digits is normal in passive wrist extension (Tenodesis effect)
Option 1: 5th digit is the most flexed in resting hand
Option 2: Flexing of digits during passive wrist flexion
Option 3: Digits in resting state point towards scaphoid tubercle

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched?
Correct Answer: Nail bed: visible edge of the eponychium
Explanation:
Lunula: germinal matrix for nail growth
Sterile matrix: nail plate adherence
Eponychium: cuticle, extension of stratum corneum for protection
Option 3: Nail bed: visible edge of the eponychium
Option 4: Eponychium: potential space between distal skin & nail plate

Question: Describe the soft tissue injury.
Explanation:
Abrasion: scraping off of outermost layer of the skin
Laceration: a cut caused by impact with a sharp object
Puncuture wound: injury made by a pointed object Avulsion: forcible tearing off of skin

Question: Tuft fractures are typically associated with _ injuries.
Explanation: Fractures of the tuft or flare at the tip of the finger or distal phalanx are typically associated with nail bed injuries.

Question: In a patient with flexor tendon injury, you note that the flexor tendon zone affected is Zone 5. Which of the ff. structures would you expect to be involved?
Explanation: Zone 5 is proximal to the carpal tunnel and can involve the major arteries supplying the hands.

Question: All of the following are indications for replantation surgery EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Individual finger amputations in an adult at a level proximal to the FDS insertion
Explanation: Individual finger amputations in an adult at a level proximal to the FDS insertion is a contraindication for replantation surgery, especially in the index or small fingers.
Option 2: Almost any part in a child
Option 3: Individual finger amputations in an adult at a level proximal to the FDS insertion

Question: Identify the Neer Classification of the fracture shown.
Explanation: In a Neer III fracture, fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts and two parts are displaced. These fractures account for approximately 5% of proximal humeral fractures.

Question: Identify the Neer classification of the fracture shown.
Explanation: In a Neer IV fracture, fracture lines involves all 4 parts and three parts are displaced. This pattern has poor non-operative results.

Question: 25/M comes in to the ER with open fracture after a car accident. You noted extensive soft-tissue loss and periosteal stripping and bone damage. According to the Gustilo Open Fracture Classification, this falls under:
Explanation: IIIB - extensive soft tissue injury, periosteal stripping, more often would require flap coverage with an addtl skin grafting

Question: Together with her guardian, a 5/F comes in to the ER complaining of a possible fracture. X-ray shows fracture line twisting around the bone with very sharp angulation. What is the MOST likely cause?
Explanation: Always rule out child abuse in spiral fractures.

Question: In evaluating possible fractures of long bones of the extremities, what is/are the standard radiographic view/s?
Describe the fibrotic pattern shown.
Explanation: The histopathologic image shows an example of hyperparathyroidism. This manifests as osteitis fibrosa cystica, comprised of peritrabecular fibrosis and cystic brown tumors (formed by blood pigments).

Question: Describe the disease stage of the histopathologic specimen:
Explanation: The presence of a mosaic pattern or "jigsaw-puzzle"-like appearance of lamellar bone indicates a burned-out osteosclerotic stage of Paget's disease.

Question: Which of the following is TRUE about the pointed structure/s?
Explanation: Green corresponds to woven bone deposition or callus formation whereas blue corresponds to fibrous tissue and osteoid deposition, also known as collagenous procallus formation.
Option 1: The structure pointed in blue corresponds to the formation of mineralized, woven bone.
Option 2: Deposition of fibrous tissue and osteoid produces a procallus, which is pointed in blue.

Topic: Pathologic Findings of Musculoskeletal Diseases + MSK Neoplasms
Question: Which of the following tumors poses the LEAST concern?
Explanation:
A & B: Osteosarcoma (malignant)
C: Giant cell tumor (locally aggressive neoplasm)
D: Chondroma (benign)

Question: This principle describes the relationship between exercise adaptations and the nature of the stimulus, forming the basis for sports-specific exercise.
Explanation:
Adaptation: changes of the body in response to exercise
Reversibility: beneficial effects are only transient and reversible
Overload: greater stress than normal is necessary for adaptation

Question: All of the following are factors associated with post-exercise syncope EXCEPT:
Explanation: Increased catecholamine release is associated with post-exercise syncope, leading to increased risk of developing dysrhythmia and cardiac ischemia.

Question: Neurogenic tumors are usually found at this part of the mediastinum.
Explanation: In the thorax, neurogenic tumors are found most commonly in the posterior mediastinum (63%–96%). In fact, neurogenic tumors account for 75% of all posterior mediastinal neoplasms.

Question: Strongest risk factor for COPD is
Explanation: Smoking: Main risk factor for COPD. Most people who have COPD smoke or used to smoke. People who have a family history of COPD are more likely to develop the disease if they smoke. STOP SMOKING!

Question: Which has a worse prognosis?
Explanation: The outlook for NSCLC is better than SCLC. Most people find out they have SCLC when it's already spread to other parts of their body.  With SCLC, the 5-year survival rate is less than 5%.

Question: Which is true about this X-ray?
Explanation: The major difference between male and female chest x-rays is caused by differences in the amount of breast tissue (see lateral white). This is a normal chest radiograph.

Question: Patient is 60 years old with 20 pack-year smoking history. You screen lung cancer via
Explanation: The only recommended screening test for lung cancer is low-dose computed tomography (a low-dose CT scan). Screening is recommended only for adults who have no symptoms but are at high risk.

Question: All of the following are emergency situations, except
Explanation: Tracheitis, epiglottitis, and diphtheria - medical emergency. Doctors first ensure that the airway isn't blocked or reduced. May need to place a breathing tube in the throat to keep the airway open.

Question: You should slowly drain the fluid in a patient with pleural effusion to avoid
Explanation: If a large pleural effusion is drained quickly and volumes of more than 1.5 L are removed, the rapid re-expansion of the collapsed lung may occasionally lead to re-expansion pulmonary edema.

Question: A pleural effusion due to congestive heart failure is expected to be
Explanation: Transudative pleural effusion, most often brought on by congestive heart failure, is caused by increased pressure in the blood vessels or a low blood protein count.

Topic: Pathologic Findings of Musculoskeletal Diseases + MSK Neoplasms
Question: Give the most likely cellular origin of the pointed cell.
Explanation: Giant tumor cell or osteoclastoma are caused by the osteoblasts, formed by precursors with mutations in the H3F3A gene.

Question: There is accumulation of _ in the histopathologic specimen shown.
Explanation: Tophi, the pathognomonic hallmark of gout, presents with large aggregations of urate crystals.

Question: A 57/M patient presents w/ low blood O2 supply and rapidly progressing dyspnea. The only pertinent finding in his history is that he inhaled a large amount of quartz powder after visiting a glass manufacturing area. His CT scan is shown below. Diagnosis?
Explanation: Quartz is one of the most common forms of crystalline silica. The CT scan shows acute silicosis with characteristic “crazy paving” of the lungs.

Question: An 87/M presents with dull pain below his right knee with insidious onset starting 2-months PTC. On X-ray, abscess showed well-circumscribed osteolysis with sclerotic margins. What is the most likely Dx?
Explanation: Subacute osteomyelitis is characterized by mild-to-moderate pain, insidious onset, and a long delay between the onset of pain and the diagnosis. Brodie abscess is one type of subacute osteomyelitis.

Question: Which is TRUE about the skeletal disease characterized by the histopathologic specimen shown above?
Correct Answer: It is divided into 3 phases: osteolytic, mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic & burned-out osteosclerotic
Explanation:
Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone pathognomonic of Paget disease
A - describes osteomyelitis
B - Paget is acquired D - describes AVN
Option 1: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism
Option 2: It is an inherited disorder of bone
Option 3: It is divided into 3 phases: osteolytic, mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic & burned-out osteosclerotic
Option 4: Gross specimen would show geographic necrosis of the medullary cavity and marrow.

Question: Which carcinoma is more commonly found among non-smokers?
Explanation: About 50% to 60% of lung cancers found in people who never smoked are adenocarcinomas (cancer that begins in the cells that line the lung's tiny air sacs and make substances such as mucus).

Question: Mesothelioma is primarily associated with
Explanation: Asbestos exposure causes mesothelioma. Asbestos exposure to 80% of all cases. Exposure often happens at work or in old buildings. Inhaling or ingesting asbestos, the fibers settle in organ linings.

Question: Which COPD can be a result of antitrypsin deficiency?
Explanation: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is congenital lack of a primary lung antiprotease, alpha-1 antitrypsin, which leads to increased protease-mediated tissue destruction and emphysema in adults.

Question: A patient told you that his sputum is like that of a "currant jelly". His pneumonia is likely caused by
Explanation: Currant jelly” sputum is a hallmark of infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae. K. pneumoniae infections carry high degree of antibiotic resistance and lead to a significant amount of patient mortality.

Question: Which of the following is least effective in reducing incidence of occupational asthma?
Explanation: PPE is considered the least effective option because it only protects the individual user and does not eliminate or reduce the hazard itself.
Option 1: Create isolation rooms to isolate people from the product
Option 3: Schedule rotation in working with product

Question: Your COPD patient had 3 moderate exacerbations this year, all of which required hospitalization. His blood eosinophil is less than 300. He should be given
Explanation: Group E – For patients with a high risk of exacerbation (ie, ≥2 exacerbations per year or one or more exacerbation leading to hospitalization), we suggest initial treatment with LAMA-LABA therapy.

Question:
Your COPD patient has the following values. 
Spirometry FEV1 = 60%, 1 moderate exacerbation this year, complaining that he becomes breathless when dressing or brushing his teeth. The assessment is
Explanation: GOLD 2: FEV1 50-79%, 0-1 exacerbation with mMRC dyspnea scale > or equal 2, with COPD Assessment Tool > or equal 10 is Group B. See GOLD 2023 for more details.

Question: Which Aspergillus species produces aflatoxin that with chronic exposure can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma?
Explanation: Aflatoxins are produced by fungi in the genus Aspergillus, mainly species A. flavus and A. parasiticus. Chronic exposure may result in liver cirrhosis and ultimately lead to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Question: Which Aspergillus species is resistant to amphotericin B?
Explanation: Aspergillus terreus is an opportunistic causative agent of invasive aspergillosis and, in most cases, it is refractory to amphotericin B (AMB) therapy.

Question: Which parasite can cause Wakana disease?
Explanation: Wakana disease is characterized by nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, pharyngeal irritation, cough, and hoarseness. This disease occurs after oral ingestion of a large number of infective A duodenale larvae.

Question: Eating which of the following can lead to Paragonimiasis?
Explanation: Paragonimiasis is transmitted primarily by freshwater crabs Sundathelphusa philippina. Cercariae invade the crab or crayfish where they encyst and become metacercariae (the infective stage).

Question: 30 year old patient presents with the following: RR=21, HR=105, BP=120/80, 3 day history of high fever and productive cough. She has no comorbidities. You heard crackles at right lower lung field. You should give
Explanation: This is low risk CAP. Only Amoxicillin is recommended. The rest are for high risk CAP.

Question: 30/F Patient presents with headache, myalgia, low-grade fever, dry cough, and sore throat.  She started feeling sick 3 weeks ago but overall still feels capable of going to work. You think it is pneumonia. Which etiologic agent is likely responsible?
Explanation: Patients present with prolonged constitutional symptoms. Present gradually a sore throat, headache, nonproductive cough, and low-grade fevers. M. pneumonia most common cause of atypical pneumonia.

Question: All of the following are recommended to be used in patients with severe COVID-19 infection, except for
Explanation: Remdesivir, tocilizumab, dexamethasone therapy for the treatment of severe COVID-19. Azithromycin is currently not recommended for the treatment of COVID-19.

Question: Which of the ff. is TRUE regarding the normal gait?
Correct Answer: D. Small children have no heel strike
Explanation:
A. Swing phase is 40%
B. This is cadence
C. This is pre-swing
Option 1: A. Swing phase comprises 60% of the gait cycle
Option 2: B. Walking or gait speed is defined as the number of steps over a period of time
Option 3: C. Terminal stance begins with the opposite limb foot contact and ends with ipsilateral tow off
Option 4: D. Small children have no heel strike

Question: Hallmark of chronic dermatomyositis:
Explanation: Cases with calcinosis are usually forgotten or undertreated dermatomyositis or misdiagnosis w/ other dse w/ similar manifestations

Question: In pediatric patients with palpable purpura suspected of having IgA vasculitis, ITP must be ruled out first. Which of the ff. can be used as a reason for ruling out ITP?
Correct Answer: Platelet count is normal to elevated
Explanation:
Difference between IgA vasculitis and ITP is platelet count
IgA vasculitis - normal to elevated
ITP - low
Option 2: Platelet count is normal to elevated
Option 3: Lesions are found on dependent or pressure-bearing areas

Question: Nail trephination is currently recommended for the treatment of:
Explanation: Even if nail is completely black but there is no pain, no need for trephination
Option 1: A. Subungual hematoma involving at least 50% of nail plate

Question: To evaluate the tendon injury of an unconscious patient, you gently glide the smooth surface of the pen across the px's finger and noticed that it glided smoothly. Interpret:
Explanation: Tactile adherence is a test for light touch. Pen gliding smoothly across the finger indicates no resistance/friction d/t absence of sweating d/t loss of autonomic function => digital nerve injury

Question: Patient with acute spinal injury due to car crash is brought to the ER. He has low BP, irregular breathing, strong pulse, high body temperature, and high capillary refill time. This is indicative of:
In anterior cord syndrome, which of the ff. function/s remain/s intact below the level of injury?
Explanation: Manifests as complete motor paralysis, sensory anesthesia, with intact proprioception and vibratory sensation

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched?
Explanation:
skin: Langerhans
liver: von Kupffer cell
kidney: mesangial phagocytes

Question: This characteristic of phagocyte is defined as the movement toward a stimulus?
Explanation:
Cytopepsis: digestion of engulfed materials in phagolysosome
Opsonization: process of enhancing phagocytosis

Question: An example of artificial active immunity is immunity acquired through:
Which hypersensitivity reaction is not mediated by antibodies?
Explanation: Type IV hypersensitivity is mediated by T cells and macrophages while other types are mediated by antibodies. Therefore, this reaction, which occurs at least 1–3 days after the initial exposure.

Question: Which hypersensitivity reaction is primarily present in this patient?
Explanation: A malar rash is present in 50% of children with SLE. SLE is a prototype type III hypersensitivity reaction in which immune complex depositions cause inflammation and tissue damage in multiple organs.

Question: Which hypersensitivity reaction is present in this patient? Note the area and character of the lesion.
Explanation: Type I hypersensitivities include atopic diseases, which are an exaggerated IgE mediated immune responses (i.e., allergic: asthma, rhinitis, conjunctivitis, and dermatitis).

Question: The positive result of this test relies on this type of hypersensitivity reaction.
Explanation: Tuberculin/PPD test diagnoses type IV hypersensitivity caused by tuberculosis bacillus infection by intradermal injection of tuberculin and according to the skin condition of the injection site.

Question: Which lymph node follicle is likely neoplastic?
Explanation: A - The neoplastic follicles in follicular lymphoma usually lack mantle zones and tingible body macrophages and have a monomorphic appearance due to predominance of centrocytes. Compare to image B.

Question: Expected laboratory results of a patient with Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Explanation: The most common laboratory findings demonstrate elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of free thyroxine (fT4), coupled with increased antithyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies.

Question: HIV is mainly spread by
Explanation: HIV is mainly spread by having anal or vaginal sex without a condom or without medications to prevent or treat HIV.

Question: The patient had recurrent staphylococcus infection and skin abscess. Serratia marcescens was one of the reported pathogens. You suspect
Explanation: Recurrent cutaneous abscesses in infancy may point towards a neutrophil defect (chronic granulomatous disease). Pathogens: S. aureus, Burkholderia cepacia, Serratia marcescens, Nocardia, Aspergillus

Question: An anaphylactic reaction can be as simple as developing a rash after exposure to an allergen.
Explanation: Anaphylaxis typically involves >1 symptom in more than one part of the body at the same time. A serious reaction could involve developing rashes & vomiting or diarrhea.

Question: Which of these are not likely to cause anaphylaxis:
Explanation: Out of this group, pollen is not known to cause life-threatening reactions. Medications, foods, latex and stinging insects are allergens most likely to cause anaphylaxis.

Question: Epinephrine should be injected into the:
Explanation: Evidence shows that epinephrine should be given in the anterior thigh muscle.

Question: Antihistamines and corticosteroids are good substitutes for epinephrine in treating anaphylaxis.
Explanation: Antihistamines and corticosteroids can sometimes used in addition to epinephrine, but these medications are not a substitute for epinephrine.

Question: The results of food-specific IgE tests (skin prick test, serum levels) reliably predict the severity of future reactions to the food.
Explanation: Newer diagnostic methods detecting serum IgE to specific components of food allergens may enhance current testing & identify patients at risk but these cannot predict the severity of future reactions.

Question: At adulthood, the most prevalent allergic disease based on the atopic march is...
Explanation: The concept of the atopic march was developed to describe the progression of atopic disorders from atopic dermatitis in infants to allergic rhinitis and asthma in children and adults.

Question: Allergy tests, such as skin prick tests and blood tests are very useful in diagnosing the cause of eczema.
Explanation: These tests may support the diagnosis of allergies. However, they are  likely to produce false results if used to investigate the etiologic agent.

Question: Foods are a common cause of eczema flares in school-age children and adults.
Explanation: Foods rarely cause eczema flares in school-age children and adults. They may cause flares in young infants and pre-school children. Many children outgrow their allergies to dairy, soy, wheat, and egg.

Question: Moisturizers are the mainstay of treatment for children with mild eczema.
Explanation: Moisturizers, particularly oil-based moisturizers promote a better barrier and keep the skin moist.

Question: Antihistamines are useful for treating the itchy skin in eczema.
Explanation: Although antihistamines may be helpful for allergic reactions causing hives and superficial swellings, they do not reduce the itch of eczema.

Question: AAF (23/F) presents with crusty, oozing, painful skin which is not responding to normal creams and ointments.
Correct Answer: Consider antibiotics and ask the patient to keep their nails short.
Explanation: Crusty, oozing, painful skin suggests a bacterial infection of the skin. It is not because the patient has suddenly become immune to the eczema treatment.
Option 1: Keep applying the treatment but more frequently.
Option 2: Stop treatment and observe for changes.
Option 3: Consider antibiotics and ask the patient to keep their nails short.
Option 4: Consider corticosteroids to increase potency of treatment.

Question: Which of the ff. is TRUE regarding topical corticosteroids (TCS) vs. topical calcineurin inhibitors (TCI)?
Correct Answer: TCS is not recommended for use in sensitive areas
Option 1: TCI is the 1st line anti-inflammatory agent for AD
Option 2: TCS is not recommended for use in sensitive areas
Option 3: TCI is more potent than TCS
Option 4: TCS has minimal skin absorption as compared to TCI

Question: What is the most common cause of chronic hives?
Explanation: Most cases of chronic urticaria have no identifiable trigger or cause. Chronic hives rarely have an identifiable external cause and are almost never caused by an allergy.

Question: What medications are usually used as the first choice for treatment of hives?
Explanation: Antihistamines decrease the itching, frequency and severity of hives. Antihistamines are usually well tolerated, with drowsiness being the most common side effect.

Question: What testing should be routinely done for a patient with chronic hives?
Explanation: Since hives are not caused by an allergy and do not suggest the presence of underlying health concerns, testing is rarely needed. Most cases can be confirmed by PE.

Question: What can individuals with chronic hives expect?
Correct Answer: Symptoms to get better on their own in months to years
Explanation: Roughly 50% of cases of hives will resolve within a year, and more than 80% will resolve by five years. Appropriate treatment typically controls symptoms and improves quality of life.
Option 1: Symptoms to get better on their own in months to years
Option 3: Use of topical steroids for treatment
Option 4: Controlling symptoms by following a limited diet

Question: Delayed umbilical cord separation may be a symptom of what immunodeficiency disorder?
Suspected severe IgE-mediated penicillin allergy can be safely confirmed or refuted by
Correct Answer: Skin testing, followed by oral challenge if negative
Explanation: Blood testing for penicillin allergy is very inaccurate. History can be helpful, but testing is needed to confirm a true allergy.
Option 1: Blood testing, followed by skin prick testing if negative
Option 2: Skin testing, followed by oral challenge if negative

Question: In a drug allergic response, the primary effector cell involved in sensitization is
Explanation: Symptoms of drug allergy arise if a certain amount of specific T cells is homing to the tissue and exerts effector functions

Question: Which one of the following is least likely to trigger asthma?
Explanation: Exposure to irritants (i.e., tobacco smoke, allergens) is likely to trigger asthma. Viral & bacterial infections (i.e., common cold sinusitis) and continuous exercise are also common triggers.

Question: After intake of sulfonamides, the patient was observed to have fever, sore throat, and cough, along with cutaneous manifestations involving the mouth, conjunctiva, ocular, and genitalia. Which of the ff. would tell you that it is SJS and not TEN?
Quick-relief or rescue medications for asthma, such as bronchodilators, may be taken on a daily basis to control frequent symptoms.
Explanation: Quick-relief medications are used to provide temporary relief of symptoms, but they are not meant to be taken daily unless for pre-treatment for exercise.

Question: Which of the following is currently the only FDA-approved biological used for the Tx of allergic asthma?
Explanation: There are currently five FDA-approved biologics for treating allergic asthma, but only one -- omalizumab (Xolair) -- is specific to allergic asthma.

Question: Both children and adults can receive immunotherapy (allergy shots).
Explanation: Both children and adults can receive allergy shots, although it is not typically recommended for children <5. For adults, medical conditions such as cardiac disease should be considered

Question: Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosis of AR, according to the WAO?
Explanation: The gold standard in local allergic rhinitis diagnostics is primarily the patient's history taking and nasal allergen provocation testing.

Question: For a hypersensitivity response to occur, two bound IgE molecules on a mast cell must react with a specific antigen.
Explanation: Two bound IgE molecules on a mast cell react with specific antigen to give a hypersensitivity response.

Question: Activated T helper cells produce cytokines, which stimulate B cells to proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells capable of producing IgE.
Explanation: B cells stimulated by cytokines become plasma cells, which can make IgE antibody.

Question: IgE molecules attach to:
Correct Answer: mast cells via the Fc region
Explanation: IgE molecules attach to mast cells by their constant region.
Option 1: mast cells via the Fv region
Option 2: mast cells via the Fc region
Option 3: T helper cells via the Fv region
Option 4: Plasma cells via the Fc region

Question: AAF (40/F) has a history of chronic inflammation of the small joints of the hands bilaterally. You suspect rheumatoid arthritis. Which one of the following statements is the MOST accurate regarding the pathogenesis of this disease?
Correct Answer: It is caused by antibody against human IgG-forming immune complexes within the joints.
Option 1: It is caused by antibody against human IgG-forming immune complexes within the joints.
Option 2: It is caused by mast cell degranulation when allergens cross-link adjacent IgEs within the joints.
Option 3: It is caused by sensitized CD4-positive T lymphocytes and macrophages invading the joints.
Option 4: It is caused by superantigens inducing lymphokine release from CD4 T cells within the joints.

Question: The principal difference between cytotoxic (type II) and immune complex (type III) hypersensitivity is:
Correct Answer: Whether the antibody reacts with the antigen on the cell or reacts with antigen before it interacts
Option 1: The participation of T cells in the effector response
Option 2: The involvement of complement in the formation of the immune complex
Option 3: The antibody isotype predominantly involved in the reaction
Option 4: Whether the antibody reacts with the antigen on the cell or reacts with antigen before it interacts

Question: MCP (77/F) with enterococcal endocarditis needed to be treated with penicillin G but had a Hx of drug allergy. She was therefore tested using penicilloyl-polylysine as the antigen. Which one of the following is MOST likely to occur in a (+) skin test?
Correct Answer: The antigen cross-links IgE on the mast cells and causes the release of histamine.
Option 1: The antigen activates CD8-positive T cells by binding to class I MHC proteins.
Option 2: The antigen activates CD4-positive T cells and macrophages.
Option 3: The antigen cross-links IgE on the mast cells and causes the release of histamine.
Option 4: The antigen forms immune complexes with IgG.

Question: Hypersensitivity to penicillin and hypersensitivity to poison oak are both:
Explanation: Haptens are small molecule irritants that bind to proteins and elicit an immune response.
Option 2: Mediated by IgG and IgM antibody

Question: Histology of lymph nodes revealed large, ovoid, prominent germinal centers with an abundance of tingible-body macrophages and a distinct mantle zone. Which of the ff. would you suspect?
Explanation: These morphological characteristics are indicative of follicular hyperplasia, one of the predominant patterns found in chronic nonspecific lymphadenitis.

Question: Which of the following is not a major symptom of eye allergy?
Explanation: A gritty or dry sensation is more commonly caused by irritants or debris in the eye, or excessive dryness due to wind, sun or tiredness.

Question: The presence of peri-limbal focal white limbal dots consisting of degenerated epithelial cells and eosinophils is highly indicative of:
Explanation: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a common bilateral atopic disease clinically characterized by limbal papillae (Horner Tranta dots) having papillary, limbal, and mixed forms.

Question: Which of the following is correctly matched to its inhibited antibody?
Explanation: Omalizumab is a humanized, monoclonal anti-IgE antibody. Mepolizumab is an anti-IL-5 IgG1 kappa monoclonal antibody. Dupilumab inhibits signaling of both IL-4 and IL-13.

Question: You are checking if the patient is suffering from a drug-induced liver injury. Which enzyme level is may not be compatible with a  hepatocellular injury?
Explanation: ALP increase suggests cholestasis. Elevations in ALT and AST in out of proportion to ALP indicates a hepatocellular disease. R ratio >5  hepatocellular, <2 cholestatic,  2–5 mixed.

Topic: History and PE of the Renal Patient
Question: Which of the following signs is most suggestive of nephrotic syndrome?
Explanation: Swelling around the eyes is the most common sign of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Topic: History and PE of the Renal Patient
Question: This is described as crystallized urea deposits found on the skin of patients with CKD who are chronically uremic:
Explanation:
Uremic frost is described as flaky lesions seen in patients with advanced kidney disease (e.g., CKD)
not yet on dialysis, resulting to scaling due to high levels of uremic toxins.

Question: Measurement of arterial blood gas shows pH 7.0, PaO2 90 mm Hg, PaCO2 23 mm Hg, and HCO3 12 mmol/L; other results are Na+ 126 mmol/L, K+ 5 mmol/L, and Cl- 95 mmol/L. What is your assessment?
Explanation: The results show metabolic acidosis (low HCO3-) with respiratory compensation (low CO2).

Question: Measurement of arterial blood gas shows pH 7.5, PaO2 85 mm Hg, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, and HCO3 34 mmol/L. What acid-base disorder is shown?
Explanation: The primary disorder is uncompensated metabolic alkalosis (high HCO3 -). As CO2 is the strongest driver of respiration, it will not allow hypoventilation as compensation for metabolic alkalosis.

Question: KFS (7/F) consulted for irritability, difficulty breastfeeding, and diarrhea (3 days PTC). The infant’s RR is elevated and the fontanels are sunken. The results from the ABG results show pH 7.39, PaCO2 27 mmHg, and HCO3 19 mEq/L. What does this mean?
Explanation: KFS has metabolic acidosis due to decreased HCO3 and slightly acidic pH. Her pH value is within the normal range which made the result fully compensated.

Question: Which of the following would likely lead to hyponatremia?
Explanation:
This causes inc. water reabs. -> dec. Na+ conc.

B, C, and D - hypernatremia E - no major changes in plasma osmolarity
Option 4: D. Administration of 2 liters of 3% NaCl solution

Question: Which of the following would be expected to cause hypokalemia at least in part by stimulating potassium uptake into the cells?
Explanation:
Metabolic alkalosis cause hypokalemia due to a shift of K+ from the ECF into the cells.

All other choices lead to hyperkalemia due to a shift of K+ out of the cells into the ECF.

Question: Which of the ff. is TRUE in a situation where the renal clearance is less than the filtration?
Correct Answer: There is more reabsorption than secretion
Option 1: Filtration is the only one functioning
Option 2: Secretion and reabsorption cancel each other out
Option 3: There is more secretion than reabsorption
Option 4: There is more reabsorption than secretion

Question: Mitral regurgitation is heard as
Explanation: Holosystolic murmurs of mitral regurgitation (MR), tricuspid regurgitation (TR), and ventricular septal defects (VSD). High immediately after the onset of S1 and it extends to just before the S2.

Question: You answer in the previous quiz is best heard at the
Explanation: Mitral regurgitation is a systolic murmur, best heard at the left 5th midclavicular line with possible radiation to the left axilla.

Question: Which heart sound is always pathologic?
