Question: It aims to enhance or improve the normal form and function of tissues.
Explanation: Aesthestic: enhancement; reconstructive: back to normal

Question: A human cadaveric skin is used to dress wounds of burn patients. Which type of graft is this?
Explanation: Autograft: same person; isograft: identical twin; allograft: same species; xenograft: different species

Question: Which of the following is considered part of step 4 in the analgesic ladder?
Explanation: Step 4 uses interventional approaches to management; created d/t limited opioids in other countries

Question: Chemotherapy after a curative resection
Explanation: Neoadjuvant - chemotherapy before operation; eradicates only those that are rapidly dividing

Question:
A: Plastic surgery is the restoration or enhancement of form and function due to congenital and acquired deformities.
B: It is unrestricted by organ system and patient age, but is restricted by disease process.
Explanation:
Plastic surgery is a field in surgery where it is unrestricted by organ 
system, disease process, or patient age.

Question:
Advatanges of Oncologic Reconstruction

A: If reconstruction is successful, it has a significant effect in timing for adjuvant therapy B: It should have no effect in monitoring and increasing risk for recurrence
Explanation: If reconstruction is successful, it has little to no effect in timing for adjuvant therapy

Question: Involves incising the wound endge and repairing with sutures; usually done with benign tumors
Explanation: Secondary Interntion: Natural wound contraction; allowing the wound to heal itself without stitches

Question: A requirement for secondary intention wound closure includes maintaining a dry environment so that it can heal faster.
Explanation: Maintain moist wound healing by applying different dressings for optimal healing

Question: Tilapia skin is used to dress wounds of burn patients. Which type of graft is this?
Explanation: Autograft - same person; Isograft - same genetic makeup; Xenograft - diff subj, diff species; Allograft; same species, diff person

Question: Type of grafting (based on skin thickness): all parts of epidermis + reticular dermis
Explanation: Thin STSG: Epidermis + part of the papillary dermis; FTSG: Full thickness of the dermis is taken

Question: FTSG Harvest harvest uses Dermatome, a machine used to shave off needed parts of the skin.
Explanation: STSG - Dermatome; FTSG Harvest requires an incision of the full thickness of the skin (usually in an elliptical manner) and primary closure of defect

Question: Flap indicated for coverage of infected, radiated or traumatic wounds
Explanation: Muscle and myocutaneous flaps are composed of muscle +/- skin, fat, and fascia, and is based on muscle blood supply + perforators.

Question: Which of the following is not a distant/regional flap?
Explanation: Z-Plasty (Triangular Transposition flap): a combination of flaps where tissues are rearranged to improve function and appearance of the scar. This is considered a local flap.

Question: If the patient receives a score of under 3 in the Nutritional Risk Screening (NRS 2002), rescreening at _____ intervals is advised
Explanation: Weekly screening is recommended. If the patient e.g. is scheduled for a major operation, preventive nutritional care plan is considered to avoid associated risk status.

Question: Global Leadership Initiative for Malnutrition (GLIM) Criteria requires at least __ phenotypic criterion and __ etiologic criterion to diagnose malnutrition.
Explanation:
→ Phenotypic criteria: Weight loss, Low BMI, Reduced muscle mass 
→ Etiologic criteria: Reduced food intake, Inflammation

Question: AW, 70M, was diagnosed with malnutrition using the Global Leadership Initiative for Malnutrition (GLIM) criteria. Weight loss was 2% within the last 6 months, BMI was 21, but there was no reduction of muscle mass. What stage of malnutrition is this?
Explanation: Stage 1 (at least 1 should be met): 5-10% w/in the past 6 months, 10-20% beyond 6 months, Low BMI <20 (below 70 y/o), <22 (70 and older) and mild to moderate deficit

Question: Approach to palliative care professionals provide separate evaluations and assessments and members communicate on a less frequent and less formal basis.
Explanation: Multidisciplary: separate evaluations and assessments, set own discipline-specific goals and implement individual intervention plans, team communicates less frequently and on a less formal basis

Question: Most prevalent approach to palliative care where one team member provides the interventions
Explanation: Transdisciplinary: Calls for one team member to provide the interventions so other members must teach the service provider aspects of their discipline

Question: Care started while patient is on curative treatment
Explanation: Palliative care: any stage of life-threatening/limiting disease; started while patient is on curative treatment; in any healthcare setting; use of life prolonging medications

Question: Sipuleucel-T is treatment for
Explanation: It is used to treat prostate cancer that has spread to other parts of the body. It is used in patients who have few or no symptoms and whose cancer is castration resistant.

Question: These are the most common sites of metastasis, except
Explanation: The most common sites where cancer spreads are bone, liver, and lung.

Question: Chronic exposure to high amounts of aflatoxin from molds can lead to
Explanation:
Acute intoxication may result in fulminant hepatic failure & rhabdomyolysis. Chronic 
exposure may result in liver cirrhosis & hepatocellular carcinoma or gall bladder carcinoma.

Question: This chemotherapy is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis.
Explanation: Pulmonary fibrosis is the most severe toxicity associated with Bleomycin. cytotoxic drugs implicated in lung toxicity: bleomycin, methotrexate, taxanes, cyclophosphamide, gemcitabine, bevacizumab.

Question: Cyclophosphamide is given with Mesna to reduce the risk of having
Explanation: Mesna is prophylactic medicine to reduce incidence of cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis. Serves as inactive chemical to which acrolein can bind instead of attacking the bladder mucosa.

Question: The monoclonal antibody for HER2 + breast cancer.
Explanation: Trastuzumab is the standard of care treatment. Other treatment: pertuzumab, tucatinib and trastuzumab deruxtecan, contribute to survival improvements in patients with HER2-positive (HER2+) BC4.

Question: Target lesion of patient before chemotherapy: R lobe liver 2.5x1 cm, L lobe liver 5.0x2.5 cm, LLL lung 2.5x2 cm. After chemotherapy: R lobe liver 2x1 cm, L lobe liver 1x1 cm, LLL lung 2x2 cm. Evaluate the response.
Explanation: Using longest dm. Before: 2.5+2.5+5=10; After: 2+2+1=5; 50% reduction = partial response. Complete=disappear all. Partial >30% decrease. Progressive >20% increase or w/ new lesions.

Question: The standard of care for chronic myeloid leukemia is
Explanation: CML with a well-defined genotypic anomaly ― the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (known as TKIs) are the standard therapy for CML.

Question: The Warburg effect is a phenomenon in which cancer cells rely primarily on glycolysis rather than oxidative phosphorylation, even in the presence of _.
Explanation: The Warburg effect is defined as a shift from oxidative phosphorylation to rapid aerobic glycolysis that goes along with a high rate of lactate production.

Question: A patient with colorectal cancer was found to have intestinal obstruction. You need to upbuild this patient for surgery. Nutrition should be given via
Explanation: High output GI fistulas, bowel obstructions, paralytic or prolonged ileus, & mesenteric ischemia preclude the ability to provide EN and require parenteral nutrition.

Question: All of the following are TRUE about non-coding (nc) RNAs and cancer EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Non-coding RNAs only function as oncogenes in cancers.
Explanation: Non-coding RNAs can function as both oncogenes or tumour suppressors in cancer.
Option 1: Overexpression of the long ncRNA ANRIL is related to cancer progression and poor tumour prognosis.
Option 2: Exosomes can carry long ncRNAs and mediate drug resistance.
Option 3: Non-coding RNAs only function as oncogenes in cancers.
Option 4: Overexpression of miR-21 can contribute to invasion and metastasis in some cancers.

Question: All of the following are mechansims used by cancer cells to evade immune destruction EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Increased expression of MHC class I proteins on the surface of tumour cells
Explanation: Cancer cells evade immune destruction by downregulating the expression of MHC class I proteins on the surface of tumour cells, resulting in the reduction or loss of tumour antigen presentation.
Option 1: Increased expression of MHC class I proteins on the surface of tumour cells
Option 3: Inappropriate expression of PDL-1 on tumour cells

Question: Hypoxia stimulates which of the following cellular processes?
Explanation: Hypoxia stimulates several cellular processes associated with cancer.

Question: Most important factor/s to consider in patients undergoing radiation therapy:
Explanation: These 3 factors have been the major subjects of radiation therapy research.

Question: All of the following describe cancer cachexia, except
Explanation: cachexia: increased insulin & IGF-1 resistance to induction of mitochondrial uncoupling proteins and fat tissue browning resulting in increased energy expenditure, even at rest.

Question: This type of energy is used in radiation therapy of patients with superfically-located tumors like that of skin cancer.
Explanation: Photons are used for deep-seated tumors; electrons are used for superficial tumors.

Question: The dose distribution of this enegy used in radiation therapy is characterized by waves that peak quickly but descend slowly — suitable for deep-seated tumors.
Explanation: Photons peak quickly but descend slowly; electrons peak quickly and descend quickly.

Question: In the cancer awareness calendar, what cancer campaign is highlighted during the month of September?
Explanation: March: Colorectal, May: Cervical, Aug: Lung, Oct: Breast

Question: Which biologic treatment is correctly matched to its target?
Explanation: All are correct! Memorizing biologics be like 😵‍💫!

Question: This is a 26s proteasome inhibitor for multiple myeloma.
Explanation: A-P13k inhibitor. C-BCR-ABL inhibitor. D. RAF inhibitor. E. Small molecule TKI. Bortezomib is proteasome inhibitor used to treat multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma.

Question: Which of the following can be used to treat castration-resistant prostate cancer?
Explanation: common treatments for mCRPC include chemotherapy (docetaxel), androgen synthesis inhibitors (abiraterone) or androgen signal blockers (enzalutamide, apalutamide). BCD for breast CA.

Question: Brachytherapy can be done on the following, EXCEPT:
Explanation: Brachytherapy is often used to treat cancers of the head and neck, breast, cervix, prostate, and eye.

Question: Most radiosensitive phase of the mammalian cell cycle
Explanation: G2/M (most susceptible), G1 (less sensitive), S (least sensitive)

Question:
A: Radiation therapy uses ionizing radiation to treat cancer.
B: Direct action is the main method by which radiation damages DNA.
Explanation: Radiation therapy makes use of ionizing radiation in treating malignant neoplasms (and occasionally benign disease). Indirect action is the main method by which radiation damages DNA.

Question: Ionizing radiations, EXCEPT:
Explanation: Ionizing radiations = high energy radiation ➡️ cause chemical changes by breaking chemical bonds

Question: Which of the following can be used to kill cancer cells at any point of the cell cycle?
Explanation: ​Cyclophosphamide is a nitrogen mustard, acts by alkylation. ​Alkylating agents cross-links strands of DNA, particularly at the N-7 position of guanine. Active during most parts of the cell cycle.

Question: The following are part of the core palliative care team, EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: All are part of the core team
Explanation: All are part of the core team but other specialists and allied-health professionals can be part of the team depending on patient's need.

Question: The following are general approaches to palliative care in cancer patients, EXCEPT:
Explanation: Interdisciplinary Team, not multidisciplinary // Multi: separate evaluations, and has their own goals vs Inter: required continuous interactiong among team members is the best method
Option 4: All are general approaches to pallative care in cancer patients

Question: Type of pain that is sudden, of short duration and may be intense, occuring despite medication intake:
Explanation: Breakthrough: occurs despite medications, or when medications wear off

Question: Pain management involves pharmacological treatments, but may also include psychosociospiritual care.
Explanation: Pain management is a merge between pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic approaches.

Question: Objective pain assessment tool for the cognitivelt impaired:
Correct Answer: Revised Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (R-FLACC)
Explanation: VAS & NRS - Adults; FLACC - Children
Option 2: Revised Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (R-FLACC)

Question: Objective pain assessment tool where patients grade their pain using a straight line that is calibrated 0-100 mm
Explanation: NRS - rate pain on a scale of 1-10; Categorical - mild/moderate/severe

Question: Which of the following antimetabolites is NOT S-phase specific?
Explanation: Cladribine is cell cycle non-specific (can affect both dividing and resting cells).

Question: A patient with osteosarcoma was found to have NAGMA, hypokalemia, hypouricemia, and hypophosphatemia. Urine tests also showed aminoaciduria, glucosuria, and phosphaturia. Which of the following may have caused this?
Correct Answer: Side effect of an alkylating agent
Explanation: The constellation of metabolic abnormalities suggests Fanconi syndrome (RTA II with impaired glucose, amino acid, and phosphate reabsorption in PCT), which can be caused by ifosfamide and cisplatin.
Option 1: Rapid destruction of tumor cells after initiating chemotherapy
Option 2: Excessive nutrition in a malnourished patient
Option 3: Side effect of an alkylating agent
Option 4: Metastatic lesions in the lungs and kidney

Question: All of the following statements about the treatment of breast cancer is true EXCEPT:
Correct Answer: Radiotherapy is NOT routinely given to male breast cancer patients after mastectomy.
Explanation: Radiotherapy should be given to all male breast cancer patients after mastectomy.
Option 1: Breast conservation surgery is equal in survival outcomes when compared to radical mastectomy.
Option 2: Mastectomy is the only adequate surgical treatment for Paget's disease of the nipple.
Option 3: Radiotherapy is NOT routinely given to male breast cancer patients after mastectomy.
Option 4: Chemotherapy is contraindicated in pregnant women during their 1st trimester of pregnancy.

Question: Which of the following treatments confer an overall survival benefit for patients with hormone refractory prostate cancer?
Explanation: Docetaxel & prednisolone increases median survival by 2 months. Although withdrawing anti-androgen therapy confers a benefit to a small number of patients, this has yet to be proven in larger groups.

Question: Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents is expected to cause the LEAST amount of myelosuppression?
Explanation: Bleomycin is associated with minimal myelosuppresion.

Question: To facilitate invasion and metastasis, cancer cells tend to undergo Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition or EMT. Which of the following is not likely a consequence for cancer cells undergoing EMT?
Explanation: Statement B should be “more” fibroblastic. EMT can lead to conversion into a spindly/fibroblastic morphology.
Option 3: C. There is loss of adherens junctions
Option 4: D. There will be an increase in motility

Question: Which fluid is not recommended to be used in resuscitating hypotensive patients?
Explanation: Crystalloid is the first fluid of choice for resuscitation. Immediately administer 2 L of isotonic sodium chloride solution or lactated Ringer's solution in response to shock from blood loss.

Question: T/F. You need a chest X-ray to diagnose tension pneumothorax.
Explanation: A strong clinical suspicion of tension pneumothorax is enough to initiate emergency treatment, which should not be delayed by any imaging studies.

Question: Which of the following signs occurs in tension pneumothorax and not in open pneumothorax?
Explanation:
Tension pneumothorax following additional findings are seen: Tachycardia > 134 bpm,
Hypotension, Jugular venous distension, Cyanosis, Respiratory failure, Cardiac arrest.

Question:
To manage tension pneumothorax, you should insert the needle at the ___ MCL. 
ICS - intercostal space
Explanation: 2nd intercostal space in MCL (ICS2-MCL) and the 4th/5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line (ICS 4/5-AAL) have been proposed as preferred locations for needle decompression of a TP.

Question: This is
Explanation: A large biconvex epidural hematoma in the left frontotemporal region causing mass effect, midline shift and sub-falcine herniation.

Question:
Cushing's Triad, a sign of increased intracranial pressure manifest as ____. 
HR (heart rate), RR (respiratory rate)
Explanation: Cushing’s triad of widened pulse pressure (increasing systolic, decreasing diastolic), bradycardia, and irregular respirations.

Question: Classify the severity of the head injury with the following Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) findings: opens eyes to voice, makes inappropriate words, and withdraws from painful stimuli.
Explanation:
Eyes - 3; Verbal - 3, Motor - 4 = 10.
Severe, GCS 3 to 8. Moderate, GCS 9 to 12. Mild, GCS 13 to 15.

Question: Give the appropriate triage color. 36/F in a motorcycle crash is breathing with RR of 40, capillary refill of <2s and can follow simple commands. She cannot walk due to a suspected knee fracture.
Explanation: BLACK: Deceased/expectant. RED (Immediate) >30 RR, >2s CRT, can follow.  Severe but high potential for survival. YELLOW: Delayed, not immediately life-threatening. GREEN: Walking wounded.

Question: Which information is not part of the Simple Triage And Rapid Treatment (START) algorithm?n
Explanation: The START system is based on three observations: RPM--Respiration, Perfusion and. Mental Status.

Question: 12/M in moderate pain with 2x2 cm contusion in R forearm after a 1.5m fall from a tree. He is alert, oriented in space, person, and time with stable vital signs. You think he will need an X-ray and CBC. Emergency Severity Index (ESI) is
Explanation: ESI 1: life-saving. Stable, high-risk ESI level 2. Use of resources none ESI 5, 1 ESI 4, > 1 ESI 3. To classify ESI 3, vital signs must be stable. If exceed defined limits, re-assignment to ESI 2.

Question: Allowed blood alcohol concentration (BAC) for a public utility vehicle driver in the Philippines is
Explanation: For drivers of trucks, buses, motorcycles and public utility vehicles, a BAC of more than 0.0% shall be conclusive proof that said driver is driving under the influence of alcohol.

Question: JJ, 40/M, was rushed to the ER after getting involved in a car crash on Taft Avenue at 9:15 PM. Upon assessment, his BP is 130/82, ICP is 15 mmHg, and MAP is 98 mmHg. Determine the cerebral perfusion pressure of JJ.
Explanation: CPP = MAP - ICP ; hence CPP = 98 - 15, which gives CPP= 83 mmHg.

Question: Which of the following is not part of  the management for open fractures?
Explanation: Emergency room urgent IV antibiotics, tetanus prophylaxis, and extremity stabilization and dressing. Surgical fixation, external, or internal, is the best way to stabilize an open fracture.

Question: It is recommended to solely give 1st generation cephalosporins to patients with this type of open fracture (using Gustilo classification).
Explanation:
type I and II: 1st gen ceph; type III
1st gen ceph + aminoglycoside or 3rd gen ceph, With farm injury / bowel contamination: 1st gen cephalosporin + aminoglycoside + PCN, add PCN for clostridia.

Question: The earliest sign that will raise clinical suspicion for compartment syndrome is
Explanation: The classic sign of acute compartment syndrome is severe pain, especially when the muscle within the compartment is stretched. The Five P's": pain, pulselessness, paresthesia, paralysis, and pallor.

Question: This is a
Explanation: There is buckling of the distal metaphyseal region of radius on the dorsal aspect. The volar cortex is intact. Associated ulnar styloid avulsion. No dislocation.

Question: What is the Salter-Harris Classification for this fracture?
Explanation: White arrow points to fracture of the epiphysis and yellow arrow to a fracture of the distal tibial metaphysis in this Salter-Harris IV fracture of the ankle.

Question: 1/M rushed to ER due to seizures. When doing the PE, you noticed several bruises in the cheek and arms of the child. When asked about the injuries, the mother said they were from playing with his older brother. This case warrants a
Explanation: skeletal survey (SS) is standard screening tool for detecting clinically unsuspected fractures. AAP recommends for all children <2 yo for whom abuse is suspected and for selected children 2 to 5 yo.
Option 3: Ionizing radiation should not be used in children.

Question: The violent shaking of a 3-month-old baby lead to the rupture of bridging veins causing
Explanation: Shaken baby syndrome (SBS) is a form of child abuse that can cause head injuries, of which, SDH is the most common manifestation. A subdural hematoma develops when bridging veins tear and leak blood.

Question: Which is not part of the triad of findings in shaken baby syndrome?
Explanation: SBS: subdural hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhages, & hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy in absence of scalp and/or skull fracture that indicate head injury in infant or young child caused by violent shaking.

Question: Fracture in this part of the long bone is very specific for child abuse.
Explanation: No injury is considered more specific for child abuse than the metaphyseal fracture. shearing injury is a peculiar injury since it is from differential motion across the metaphysis.

Question: RS, 2/M, presented with bruised pattern markings as shown. His father narrates vague history and  changes details. With suspicion of physical child abuse, what object might have been used in this case? (image from: Dr. Abhinav Raj, Forensic Odontologist)
Explanation: Looped pattern markings are seen within the bruising on this child's back. They indicate looped/extension cord, belt, or similar object to punish him. The color is red, indicating few day old injury.

Question: You should have a high suspicion of child abuse in case
Explanation: A. Accidental scalds found on the head, neck, trunk, face and upper body from the pull down mechanism. B. Inflicted scalds on lower limbs, buttock & perineal regions & may be unilateral or bilateral.

Question: Which of the following wound is most likely from a blunt object?
Explanation: 2. Laceration (blunt force trauma), mimicking a sharp force injury, presence of “tissue bridging” (arrows). 3. An incised wound of the face. The wound is longer on the skin surface than it is deep.

Question: Pain alone is sufficient to start management for compartment syndrome.
Explanation: Do NOT wait for other symptoms before managing the patient.

Question: Which one is the exit wound?
Explanation: B. Bullet entry point shows a clean break outside with beveling on the inside. A. Exit wound leaves a clean break on the inside and beveling on the outside of the skull.

Question: Estimate the range of fire from this injury.
Explanation: Intermediate-range wound with an abrasion collar and more than 100 punctate abrasions, or tattooing, from unburned pieces of gunpowder impacting the skin.

Question: For the wound to heal faster and with a finer scar, you should cut ____ to the Langer lines.
Explanation: Where possible, closure should be performed parallel to tension lines; wounds closed perpendicular to tension lines are subject to greater tension and are harder to close.

Question: 32/M recovering post-surgery for long bone fracture suddenly develops dyspnea. He is agitated and anxious, with altered sensorium. You also notice petechial rashes on his chest and conjunctivae. Which is TRUE about its management?
Correct Answer: Supportive care is the mainstay treatment
Explanation: This is a case of fat embolism syndrome. Treatment is mainly supportive. Once symptoms are present, there is no definitive treatment to reverse it.
Option 2: Supportive care is the mainstay treatment
Option 3: Patient would likely need a 6-week course of antibiotics
Option 4: Elevate limb that underwent surgery and apply cold compress

Question: Which is not part of Beck's triad for diagnosis of cardiac tamponade?
Explanation: The classic physical findings in cardiac tamponade included in Beck's triad are hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

Question: You are about to do tube thoracostomy in a patient with pneumothorax. Insertion of the chest tube should be performed
Correct Answer: Above the superior edge of the rib
Explanation: A thoracostomy tube is usually placed between the mid to anterior axillary line in the fourth or fifth intercostal space, tracking above the rib so as not to injure the intercostal bundle.
Option 1: Above the superior edge of the rib
Option 2: Below the inferior edge of the rib

Question: Which of the following are the accepted methods in managing patients with pulmonary contusion?
Explanation: Fluid restriction, mechanical ventilation, and operative stabilization are NOT used in managing pulmonary contusion.

Question: 70/M present to the ER like this (see picture above) after a mechanical fall from a standing height with right-side chest injury. The patient then noticed facial swelling and a worsening cough. You should suspect
Explanation: Classic signs that have been described, which should trigger the suspicion of tracheobronchial injury in the appropriate settings, include subcutaneous emphysema, pneumomediastinum, and pneumothorax.

Question: Loss of p16 protein will lead to
Explanation: Loss of p16 results in increased activity of the CDKs and subsequent Rb protein phosphorylation, leading to unchecked cellular proliferation.

Question: Which of the following carpal bones is most susceptible to avascular necrosis and non-union if fractured?
Explanation: Scaphoid bone has a retrograde blood supply from the branches of the radial artery, making it more susceptible to complications from fractures.

Question: Subclinical infections are not detected by serological tests.
Explanation: Subclinical infections (i.e. no symptoms) are detected through a serological test — used as basis for screening.

Question: All of the following are airborne, except:
Explanation: Rubella is transmitted via droplets.

Question: This is the main anatomic site of carriage for chronic S.typhi carriers.
Explanation: Most chronic S. Typhi carriers (shedding for ≥12 months) harbor infection in their gallbladder wherein cholelithiasis, provide an environment that fosters persistence.

Question: One polio case was confirmed on 2019 in a 3-year-old girl from Lanao del Sur. Because of this, DOH announced at that time that there is a
Explanation: Outbreak: one or more cases of polio in an area that has been polio-free for at least six months. When a new polio outbreak occurs, it is critical to maximise vaccine coverage.

Question: You are suspecting typhoid fever in a 20/M with flu symptoms and diarrhea for 5 days. Typhidot results show IgM(-) and IgG(+). This means that the patient has
Explanation:
IgM-: Acute typhoid fever
IgM + IgG-: Acute typhoid fever, persistent, convalescent
IgG + and IgM -: Past infection

Question: Which of the following disease is incorrectly paired to its viral agent?
Explanation: Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV; also known as human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8)) is the infectious cause of this neoplasm. HH7 may also cause roseola infantum.

Question: 50/F complains of local tenderness and pain in her left leg. She has been experiencing fever, chills, and malaise for 3 days. When inspecting the lesion above, you see that the margins are indistinct and not palpable. This is
Explanation: An infection of only the upper layers of skin is  erysipelas. If deeper layers are infected, it is cellulitis. Erysipelas has more defined borders, cellulitis can cause more systemic symptoms.

Question: Epstein-Barr virus is linked to the development of the ff. malignancies, EXCEPT:
Explanation: All of these are linked to EBV

Question: Major target cell of Epstein-Barr virus.
Explanation: EBV can induce B cell proliferation, leading to transformation of these cells — a key feature of infectious mononucleosis.

Question: Majority of leptospira-infected persons:
Explanation: Only 10% of all cases are symptomatic (i.e. fever, conjunctival suffusion)

Question: Most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis
Which of the following is not a warning sign in dengue infection?
Explanation: Critical phase. Around the time of defervescence, when the temperature drops to 37.5–38°C or less. The rest are warning signs.

Question: Match the spot to the correct virus.
Correct Answer: Koplik spots - Rubeola; Forchheimer spots - Rubella
Explanation: Forchheimer spots: rose coloured spots on soft palate may coalesce into a red blush - Rubella. Koplik spots: clustered white lesions on buccal mucosa - Rubeola/Measles.
Option 1: Koplik spots - Rubella; Forchheimer spots - Rubeola
Option 2: Koplik spots - Rubeola; Forchheimer spots - Rubella

Question: A patient diagnosed to have a dengue with warning signs of abdominal pain and pleural effusion. CBC will most likely show
Explanation:
Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100 x 109/L), Leukopenia. In patients with severe dengue, the following may be present:
Increased hematocrit level secondary to plasma extravasation.

Question: This viral infection is associated with the birth defect seen above.
Explanation: Zika virus infection during pregnancy can cause infants to be born with microcephaly and other congenital malformations as well as preterm birth and miscarriage.

Topic: Pedia IDS - Fever with Mucocutaneous Lesions
Question: The following are included in the triad for Congenital Rubella Syndrome, except:
Explanation: Bluberry Muffin Rashes are not part of the triad, but are very recognizable in Congenital Rubella Syndrome

Question: Which viral infection is associated with aplastic anemia as a rare complication?
Explanation: Human parvovirus B19 frequently associated with erythema infectiosum, or joint symptoms. Aplastic anemia as a complication of human parvovirus infection is rare in healthy adults.

Question: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive, disabling, and deadly brain disorder related to ____ infection.
Explanation: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive, disabling, and deadly brain disorder related to measles (rubeola) infection.

Question: Herman's rash is characterized as confluent, erthematous or petechial rash usually seen in what phase of dengue infection?
Explanation: Seeing isles of white in the sea of red means the patient is recovering.

Topic: Pedia IDS - Fever with Mucocutaneous Lesions
Question: True about Neonatal Varicella, except:
Explanation: Neonatal Varicella is life threatening so they are admitted and given IV Acyclovir.
Option 1: Can be acquired from months who develop Varicella 5 days before delivery
Option 2: Can be acquired from months who develop Varicella 2 days after delivery

Topic: Pedia IDS - Fever with Mucocutaneous Lesions
Question: What is a herpetic infection that is often seen in contact sports such as wrestling or rugby?
Explanation: Herpes gladiatorum (HSV-1) is also known as mat herpes because it is most often found in wrestlers and other contact sports.

Topic: Pedia IDS - Fever with Mucocutaneous Lesions
Question: Parvovirus B19 is transmissble through the following mechanisms, except:

Topic: Pedia IDS - Fever with Mucocutaneous Lesions
Question: Which condition is described to have lace-like reticular maculopapular lesions spreading to the trunk and proximal extremities and have facial flushing with a "slapped-cheek" appearance?
Explanation: some notable key words: Scarlet fever - sandpaper-like; Varicella - vesicular, starry sky; Rubeola - koplik spots

Question: A medical student will have her ward rotation next week (Sept 19). She had her MMR booster last week (Sept 5). She is asking if she can have her Varicella booster today (Sep 12)? You advise her to
Correct Answer: Wait at least 4 weeks before getting the Varicella vaccine
Explanation: Two or more injectable or nasally administered live vaccines not administered on the same day should be separated by at least 4 weeks.
Option 2: Wait at least 4 weeks before getting the Varicella vaccine
Option 3: Should not get the Varicella vaccine since she already have a MMR booster

Question: A healthy 65/F with no comorbidities is asking you if she should get the Pneumococcal PPSV23 vaccine. She got the PCV20 a year ago. What should you recommend?
Correct Answer: No, 1 dose of PCV20 is enough
Explanation: Routine vaccination. Administer PCV15 or PCV20 for all adults 65 years or older. PCV20: Additional vaccination not recommended. If PCV20 is used, a dose of PPSV23 isn't indicated.
Option 3: No, 1 dose of PCV15 needed instead
Option 4: No, 2 doses of PCV15 needed instead

Question: A 40/M immunocompromised patient with leukemia is asking about the Herpes zoster (Shingrix) vaccine. He had an episode of post-herpetic neuralgia 6 months ago and is afraid of getting another bout of shingles. You recommend
Explanation: ACIP: 2 doses of RZV for prevention of shingles in ≥19 yo who are or will be immunodeficient or immunosuppressed. 2 doses necessary regardless of previous history of shingles. Varicella is live vax!

Question: 30/M was clinically diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis. If you want to confirm using culture, you should use
Explanation: LJ medium, is a selective egg-based medium specifically used for the culture and isolation of Mycobacterium species.

Question: 26/F with history of wading in flood waters came to consult for calf pain, fever (Tmax 39.5C), chills, and abdominal pain. You see conjunctival suffusion. Symptoms started 3 days ago. You are suspecting leptospirosis so you request immediate
Explanation: Blood and CSF specimens may be + during the 1st 10 days of the illness. Urine cultures may become + during the 2nd week and remain + for up to 30 days after resolution of symptoms.

Question: 26/M with history of wading in flood waters came to consult for high fever (Tmax 40C), calf pain, chills, and abdominal pain. Vitals signs are stable with good urine output. If this is leptospirosis, management is
Explanation: For outpatients with mild disease, we favor treatment with doxycycline (adults: 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days).

Question: Appropriate prophylaxis given to 15/M student with a single history of wading in flood waters with a minor cut in left foot.
Correct Answer: Doxycycline, 2 capsules of 100 mg OD for 3-5 days started immediately
Explanation:
MODERATE RISK: single history  
of wading in flood or contaminated water +  presence of open lesions of the skin, OR accidental ingestion of contaminated water. A: low risk. C: high risk.
Option 1: Doxycycline, 2 capsules of 100 mg OD single dose started immediately
Option 2: Doxycycline, 2 capsules of 100 mg OD for 3-5 days started immediately
Option 3: Doxycycline, 2 capsules of 100 mg OD once weekly

Question: A patient comes in with rash on his face, palms & soles. Upon inspection, you notice that the lesion is only in one stage of development. What is the most likely causative agent?
Explanation: Monkeypox rash is often in one stage of development only.

Question: The primary reason why influenza vaccine must be carefully evaluated and updated annually to cover evolving strains.
Explanation: Antigenic drift: primary reason why the composition of flu vaccines for use in Northern and Southern Hemispheres is reviewed annually and updated as needed to keep up with evolving flu viruses.

Question: The intermediate host of MERS CoV.
Explanation: MERS-CoV can be transmitted from dromedary camels to humans via respiratory droplets as well as the fecal/oral route.

Question: 26/F has a positive self-administered rapid antigen test. She has no symptoms and no history of contact with someone who is a probable or suspected case of COVID-19. This is ____ of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
Explanation: Suspected: With no clinical signs or symptoms, NOR meeting epidemiologic criteria but With a positive professional use or self-test SARS-CoV-2 antigen-RDT.

Question: 75/F tested positive in RTPCR, with mild symptoms of fever (Tmax 38.8C), cough, and muscle pain. No signs of pneumonia. Has been on metformin and losartan for 5 years, with good blood glucose and blood pressure control. Classify the severity.
Explanation:
Moderate: Without pneumonia but with  
risk factors for progression: elderly (aged 60 and above) and/or with co-morbidities.

Question: Prophylaxis antibiotic for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in a HIV positive patient.
Explanation: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is also the recommended first-line regimen for primary and secondary prophylaxis against PCP.

Question: If resource is not a problem, will you recommend breastfeeding in a HIV positive mother?
Explanation: Breastfeeding doubles the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. Avoidance of breastfeeding has been suggested to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

Question: What test should you perform to diagnose HIV in a 1-month-old female infant born to a HIV positive mother?
Explanation: Virologic assays (HIV RNA / HIV DNA nucleic acid tests [NATs]) that directly detect HIV must be used to diagnose HIV in infants and children aged <18 months with perinatal and postnatal HIV exposure.
Option 4: Any of the three is valid

Question: Viral suppression is defined as less than ___ copies of HIV per milliliter of blood.
Explanation: Viral suppression is defined as having less than 200 copies of HIV per milliliter of blood.

Question: What is the risk of HIV transmission through sex if the HIV viral load is less than 200?
Explanation: People cannot pass HIV through sex with undetectable levels of HIV. 100% effective as long as the person living with HIV takes medication as prescribed. Undetectable = Untransmittable.

Question: AIDS diagnosis when the CD4 cell count is less than ____ cells/mm^3.
Explanation: Per the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), one of the indications for the diagnosis of AIDS is when CD4 cell count drops below 200 cells/mm^3.

Question: HIV post-exposure prophylaxis should be taken within ___ hours. (The sooner, the better.)
Explanation: PEP means taking HIV medicines within 72 hours (3 days) after a possible exposure to HIV to prevent HIV. The sooner PEP is started after a possible HIV exposure, the better. Every hour counts.

Question: 12/M with a puncture at left hand from a street dog bite. The wound is spontaneously bleeding. He said that the dog licked his wound. Management should be ___. RIG - Rabies Immunoglobulin
Explanation: Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG) is given in combination with anti-rabies vaccine to provide immediate protection to patients with Category III exposure.

Question: Which test can be used to quantify the anti-rabies antibodies in high-risk individuals?
Explanation: DFA test is the gold standard for routine sensitive and specific lyssavirus post-mortem diagnosis. RFFIT for detecting and quantitating rabies virus neutralizing antibodies (RVNA) in human serum.

Question: 26/F a dog owner came to consult for a bite in her right ear. She informed you that she had a complete pre exposure rabies prophylaxis 6 months ago. You should give her
Explanation: People who have been previously vaccinated or are receiving pre-exposure vaccination for rabies should not receive HRIG.

Question: The mosquito species responsible for malaria transmission.
Explanation: Only female Anopheles mosquitoes can spread malaria from one person to another. For the Anopheles mosquito to become infective, they must bite from a person already infected with malaria parasites.

Question: Most virulent plasmodium species.
Explanation: P. falciparum infect all types of RBCs found at different stages of development (from immature young to old RBCs), making it most deadly of the human malaria parasites.

Question: Gold standard diagnostic test for laboratory confirmation of malaria.
Explanation: Microscopic examination of blood films is the gold standard for laboratory confirmation of malaria parasites.

Question: Which of the following plasmodium species has dormant hypnozoites as part of life cycle?
Explanation: Primaquine is the only antimalarial that effectively kills the dormant hypnozoites of P. vivax and P. ovale.

Question: Match the drug to its target plasmodium stage.
Correct Answer: Artemether-Lumefantrine at erythrocytic stage; Primaquine at exoerythrocytic stage
Explanation: Primaquine acts on exo-erythrocytic stage in the liver and eradicates dormant hypnozoites. Artemisinin acts at an early stage of the erythrocytic and gametocyte stage.
Option 1: Artemether-Lumefantrine at erythrocytic stage; Primaquine at exoerythrocytic stage
Option 2: Primaquine at erythrocytic stage; Artemether-Lumefantrine at exoerythrocytic stage

Question: Infective stage of plasmodium is
Explanation: The stage infective for humans is the uninucleate, lancet-shaped sporozoite. Merozoite is invasive stage.

Question: CMV infections are most common during this period after transplantation.
Explanation: Early phase infections are most commonly due to donor-derived & nosocomial pathogens. Middle phase includes opportunistic pathogens like CMV. Late phase infections are commonly from the community.

Question: All of the following are associated with lower risk of hospital-acquired infections, EXCEPT:
Explanation: Drip chamber lowers UTI risk. Sedation holiday lowers pneumonia risk. Femoral catheterization is AVOIDED, if possible, due to it being more hidden than other sites (i.e. hard to monitor infections).

Question:
Which of the following pairs are TRUE?

PEP: Post-exposure prophylaxis RIG: Rabies Immunoglobulin
Correct Answer: Pet dog licks intact skin: Wash wound only
Explanation: Casual contact: no PEP; PLHIV: vaccine + RIG (full-course PEP); Abrasions: need vaccine also
Option 1: Casual contact with patient with rabies: Give RIG only
Option 2: Pet dog licks intact skin: Wash wound only
Option 3: PLHIV bitten by stray dog: Give vaccine only
Option 4: Abrasions with no spontaneous bleeding: Wash wound only

Question: Correct sequence to donning personal protective equipment (PPE):
Explanation: Don gloves last; combination of PPE will affect sequence - it is best to be practical

Question: Care bundles are a set of evidence-based practices that improve patient outcomes when performed collectively and reliably. Which of the following is NOT part of the CLABSI (Central Line-Associated Bloodstream Infection) Bundle?
Correct Answer: Elevation of head of bed to 30-45 degrees
Explanation: Elevation of head of bed is under the Ventilator Associated Pneumonia (VAP) Bundle
Option 4: Elevation of head of bed to 30-45 degrees

Question:
TRUE of resuscitation in the management of sepsis and septic shock:

(HES: hydroxyethyl starches; MAP: mean arterial pressure)
Correct Answer: B. Vasopressin should be used with the intent of reducing the norepinephrine dose.
Explanation:
A: within 3h

C: HES and gelatins are NOT recommended; statement refers to dopamine (for px at highest risk of tachyarrhythmias OR relative bradycardia)  D: 65 mmHg
Option 1: A. Resuscitation with IV crystalloid fluid should begin within the first 12 hours.
Option 2: B. Vasopressin should be used with the intent of reducing the norepinephrine dose.
Option 3: C. HES & gelatins should be avoided except in patients at highest risk of tachyarrhythmias
Option 4: D. In patients with septic shock requiring vasopressors, the recommended target MAP is 75 mmHg.

Question:
TRUE of respiratory support in the management of sepsis and septic shock:

(PEEP: positive end-expiratory pressure)
Correct Answer: D. A target tidal volume of 6 ml/kg of predicted body weight is recommended in sepsis-induced ARDS.
Explanation:
A: NOT recommended
B. higher PEEP rather than lower
C: recommended in PaO2/FiO2 < 150 (i.e. severe ARDS)
Option 1: A. Routine use of pulmonary catheter is recommended.
Option 2: B. A lower PEEP rather than a higher PEEP is used in moderate to severe sepsis-induced ARDS.
Option 3: C. Prone positioning should be avoided in those with PaO2/FiO2 < 150 mmHg.
Option 4: D. A target tidal volume of 6 ml/kg of predicted body weight is recommended in sepsis-induced ARDS.

Question: TRUE of general supportive care in the management of sepsis and septic shock:
Correct Answer: B. LMW heparin and unfractionated heparin can be used against venous thromboembolism.
Explanation:
A: > 180 mg/dL
C: adequate fluids and vasopressor first
D. should have arterial catheter placed as soon as is practical
Option 1: A. Insulin dosing should be initiated when 2 consecutive blood glucose levels are > 126 mg/dL
Option 2: B. LMW heparin and unfractionated heparin can be used against venous thromboembolism.
Option 3: C. Hydrocortisone is first-choice tx for restoration of hemodynamic stability in septic shock.
Option 4: D. Patients requiring vasopressors should not have an arterial catheter placed.

Question: All of the following are implicated in the pathogenesis of sepsis-related organ dysfunction, EXCEPT:
Explanation: All are implicated in the pathogenesis of organ dysfunction in sepsis.
Option 3: Endothelial dysfunction resulting in loss of barrier integrity

Question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding vaccine spacing?
Explanation: C & D: May be administered simultaneously or at any interval between doses
Option 1: A. Oral live vaccines may be administered simultaneously
Option 2: B. Oral live vaccines may be administered at any interval between doses
Option 3: C. 4-week interval needed when giving inactivated and live vaccines
Option 4: D. 4-week interval needed when giving inactivated vaccines

Question: The following are considered as new cases for tuberculosis (TB), except:
Correct Answer: Has taken anti-TB medications, but less than 4 months
Explanation: New patients have never had treatment for TB, or have taken anti-TB drugs for less than 1 month.
Option 1: Has never had treatment for TB
Option 2: Has taken anti-TB medications, but less than 4 months
Option 3: Both are considered new cases for TB

Question: Patient had a kidney transplant 8 months ago, now presenting with cough and fever. The infection is most likely
Explanation: Infectious risk is postoperative and nosocomial at the early phase. In the intermediate and late phases, opportunistic infections. During the late phase, community-acquired infection risk is common.

Question: Management for a patient with a blood culture positive for Gram negative bacteria, using an IV catheter site. Patient has fever (Tmax 38.5C) for 4 hours now.
Correct Answer: Give appropriate antibiotics and remove catheter
Explanation: Fungemia and gram-negative bacteremia due to an infected catheter rarely are treatable with antimicrobial agents alone. Catheters in these patients should be removed.
Option 4: Give appropriate antibiotics and remove catheter

Question: This baby (picture above) also has a patent ductus arteriosus. Maternal history revealed no vaccination against
Explanation: Babies born to mothers who had rubella (German measles) during pregnancy may have a higher risk of a PDA.

Question: 5-day-old female baby presents with the classic triad: chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. Maternal history revealed having 5 pet cats. Treatment is
Explanation: A,B: Syphilis. C - HSV. D - CMV. E. Prophylaxis for high risk groups. G - Rubella.

Question: 5/F with exposure to mother with TB. She has no symptoms, normal chest X-ray. Tuberculin skin test show 12 mm induration. She must be given
Explanation: WHO recommends 6-month isoniazid (6H) monotherapy for the treatment of LTBI in children.

Question: 4/F had to undergo TB screening. She was given BCG at birth. Which test will less likely give a false positive result for latent TB infection?
Explanation: BCG is a vaccine for TB disease. The vaccine can cause a false-positive TB skin test reaction BCG recipients. IGRA is preferred for BCG-vaccinated individuals. The rest are for TB disease.

Question: When should a HIV positive patient be screened for tuberculosis?
Correct Answer: At the time of diagnosis of HIV
Explanation: TB screening should be offered to all PLHIV enrolled in care at diagnosis and all follow-up visits, and HIV testing should be routinely offered to all patients with TB. Active case finding!
Option 1: At the time of diagnosis of HIV
Option 2: If with signs and symptoms of TB
Option 4: Has a close contact with a TB case

Question: You are caring for a patient diagnosed with Tuberculosis and has started taking medications a week ago. The best PPE to wear is
Explanation: Only N95 respirator provides promising protective efficiency for health care workers against tuberculosis.

Question: Children should be given lower doses of TB drugs compared to adults to prevent adverse side effects.
Explanation: Children receive higher dose of TB drugs than adults. Children tend to tolerate larger doses per kilogram of body weight and have fewer adverse reactions than adults.

Question: Which of the following drug is not anymore part of the recommended first-line drugs for typhoid fever due to increased resistance?
Explanation: WHO recommends azithromycin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone. Development of multiple‐drug resistance to old first‐line agents (amoxicillin/ampicillin, cotrimoxazole and chloramphenicol).

Question: Which is not a typical finding in typhoid fever?
Explanation: Symptoms: fever, chills, cough, red rash on the abdomen, watery diarrhea, a slow heart rate, and low blood pressure. Pulse-temperature dissociation..

Question: What part of the life cycle of Toxoplasma gondii is killed by pyrimethanine and sulfadiazine?
Explanation: Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine, the current standard therapy for toxoplasmosis, can suppress tachyzoite growth (the acute life cycle stage) but have no effect on bradyzoites.

Question: Definitive host of Toxoplasma gondii
Explanation: The only known definitive hosts for Toxoplasma gondii are members of family Felidae (domestic cats and their relatives). Unsporulated oocysts are shed in the cat's feces.

Question: A common pattern in the location of lesion (lymphedema) of this parasite.
Correct Answer: Below the knee - Brugia malayi; Above the knee - Wuchereria bancrofti
Explanation: Lymphoedema of the legs in Brugia infections usually does not extend above the knee, whereas both the thigh and lower leg are often involved in bancroftian filariasis.
Option 1: Above the knee - Brugia malayi; Below the knee - Wuchereria bancrofti
Option 2: Below the knee - Brugia malayi; Above the knee - Wuchereria bancrofti

Question: 50/M from Leyte came to consult for acute, repetitive attacks of pain and swelling of genitals. You inspect the genital area and noticed a hydrocele. You are suspecting filariasis. The best time to get a blood specimen is
Explanation: Microfilariae exhibit a marked periodicity.  Brugia or Wuchereria—at night, after 8 PM.

Question: 16/F just recently received platelet products and is asking you when she can get her MMR booster. You recommend to wait a minimum interval of __ months before vaccination.
Explanation:
PRBCs 6 mon.
Plasma/platelet products  7 mon.

Question: Minimum age to receive PPSV23.
Explanation: PPSV23: All adults 65 years and up. Anyone 2 years or older with conditions that can lead to increased risk for pneumococcal disease. <2yo are unable to make Ig G2 for polysaccharide vaccines.

Question: Which of the following is the MOST effective method to prevent injury?
Explanation: Considered the most effective way of preventing injury

Question: At which month does an infant typically have their first dental visit?
Explanation: At 6 months, a child would experience their first tooth eruption (usually bottom teeth)

Question: During the immediate and thorough drying step, how many seconds must be allotted for each body part?
Which of the following is FALSE about the milk chain?
Correct Answer: Limit the duration of breastfeeding to prevent dependence
Explanation: Do NOT limit the duration of breastfeeding
Option 1: Do not give supplements such as water, infant formula, or vitamins
Option 2: Limit the duration of breastfeeding to prevent dependence
Option 3: Empty the breast before offering second breast to ensure baby receives hindmilk
Option 4: When separated, collect colostrum with a syringe every 2-3 hours within 6 hours after birth

Question: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding?
Explanation: Chemotherapeutic drugs and radioisotopes are the ONLY absolute contraindications for breastfeeding
Option 3: Breast surgery leading to partial damage of the lactiferous ducts

Question: How long can breastmilk be stored in a refrigerator (0-4 degrees Celsius)?
Explanation: 6 hours: room temperature; 2 weeks: freezer; 6 months: deep freezer

Question: Which of the following is a LATE feeding cue for breastfeeding?
Explanation: Stirring: early; stretching & increased physical movement: mid

Question: At what age do the anterior fontanelles close?
Explanation: Posterior: 6 to 8 weeks; Mastoid: 6 to 18 months; Sphenoid: 6 months

Question: Which of the following is the most accurate for checking a baby’s temperature?
Explanation: A rectal temperature is 0.3 to 0.6 degrees Celsius higher than an oral temperature.

Question: Until what age does physiologic bowing is seen?
Explanation: “Physiologic” bowing is frequently seen under two years of age and will spontaneously resolve

Question: What is the average growth in head circumference (cm/month) of a 10-month child?
Interpret the growth chart:
Explanation: Below -2: underweight, below -3: severely underweight

Question: A sharp incline in a pediatric patient’s growth chart suggests:
Explanation: Expected during the refeeding period as the child experiences “catch-up” growth if a child has been ill or severely undernourished

Question:
Case: A 72/F is admitted to the ICU for diverticulitis complicated by __E. coli __sepsis. Treatment with ciprofloxacin is started. 3 days later, her serum creatinine increased from 0.7 mg/dL to 1.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows muddy brown casts.

Which of the following structures is most likely ischemic?
Explanation: The urinalysis of acute tubular necrosis shows muddy brown casts or renal tubular epithelial cells secondary to the sloughing of tubular cells into the lumen due to ischemia or toxic injury.

Topic: Histology of the Female Reproductive System
Question: Which stage of the follicle is marked by the surrounding of squamous follicular cells becoming cuboidal?
Explanation: The primary follicle is marked by the surrounding of flattened (squamous) follicular cells becoming cuboidal and the oocyte becomes bigger.

Question: How thick is the plasma membrane?
Which of the following is NOT a membranous organelle?
Explanation: Lysosomes, peroxisomes, mitochondria, and endoplasmic reticulum are all membranous organelles.

Question:
Case: A 2/M was brought to you because of failure to thrive. He had loose, foul-smelling, fatty stools and a cough lasting for 2 weeks. He is at the 30th percentile for height and 10th percentile for weight. PE is unremarkable. Laboratory shows steatorrhea and a sweat Cl concentration of 80 mmol/L. Chest x-ray shows hyperinflation. Sputum culture reveals __H. influenzae__ and __S. aureus__.

Secretion of which of the following is most likely to be decreased in the patient?
Explanation: When CFTR is dysfunctional, lack of bicarbonate secretion disrupts these normal processes & thus leads directly to the clinical symptoms and signs of CF.

Question: 27/M had a vehicular accident. Patient can't abduct right arm and has sensory deficits over the skin of the lateral deltoid. There is injury in
Explanation: Axillary nerve: motor innervation to deltoid and to the teres minor muscle. The deltoid muscle prime mover of shoulder and in ABduction and elevation of arm.

Question: 30/M had a head injury. Neuro exam showed decreased taste on the left anterior tongue. This damaged nerve is also responsible for
Explanation: facial nerve fibers to anterior two-thirds of the tongue, also control several muscles in your face, like the ones that help you smile, frown, wrinkle your nose and raise your eyebrows.

Question: In the neuro exam, the left and right pupils don't constrict when a light is shown inyo the left eye. When light is shown into the right eye, both pupils constrict. Where is the lesion? Refer to numbers in the picture.
Explanation: An afferent pupillary defect is the result of unilateral damage to the retina or optic nerve and causes pupils to respond differently to light stimuli shone in one eye at a time.

Question: The muscle involved in increasing voice pitch by stretching and tensing the vocal ligaments,  is innervated by
Correct Answer: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
Explanation: The cricothyroid muscle stretches and tenses the vocal ligaments, hence its colloquial name ‘singer’s muscle’ innervated by Innervation: External laryngeal nerve (branch of superior laryngeal).
Option 1: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

Question: This microorganism is responsible for the majority of Guillain-Barre Syndrome cases.
Explanation: The most common infectious agents that cause GBS include Campylobacter jejuni (C. jejuni), Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and cytomegalovirus.

Question: This virus has a double-stranded RNA, known to cause gastroenteritis in children. The treatment for the affected child is
Explanation: Double-stranded RNA viruses include  rotaviruses, common cause of gastroenteritis in young children. There's no cure for rotavirus, But a vaccine can prevent it.

Question: This parasite is known to cause autoinfection and disseminated infection among immunocompromised patients.
Explanation: Strongyloides infection can last the host's lifetime due to its ability to cause autoinfection of the host.

Question: Which of the following serum globulin concentrations will you expect in a patient with alcoholic liver disease?
Explanation:
Increased IgM: primary biliary cholangitis
Diffuse polyclonal increases in IgG levels: autoimmune hepatitis
 [HPIM 21st ed., p. 2555]
Option 4: Diffuse polyclonal increases in IgG levels

Question: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid may present with watery  diarrhea caused by which of the following hormones?
Explanation:
Caused by calcitonin, other secretory peptides, or prostaglandins

[HPIM 21st ed., p. 303]

Question: A type of medication error wherein a certain process was done incorrectly:
What is the best medication to prevent asthma exacerbations in patients with persistent asthma?
Explanation: Inhaled Corticosteroids are considered the most effective long-term usage medication for control and management of asthma.

Question: Which drug used in asthma management is associated with increased risk of developing oral thrush?
Explanation: Oropharnyngeal candidiasis is the most common adverse effect of ICS therapy, but causes no significant morbidity and is easily managed.

Question: The release of calcium, leading to activation of phospholipase C, most likely occurs as a result of an increase in the concentration of which of the following intracellular second messengers?
Explanation: Phospholipase C (PLC) activation leads to the cleavage of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP₂) into two second messengers: diacylglycerol (DAG) and IP₃.

Question: After fasting, a 52/M undergoes acid infusion through a catheter into the upper duodenum. This will increase pancreatic secretion mainly through the action of which of the following:
Explanation: Secretin is released by the S cells of the duodenum in response to acidic chyme entering from the stomach.

Question: Insulin is the first-line treatment of
Explanation: Insulin injected subcutaneously is the first-line treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM).

Question: Who can already be diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes? All patients had their glucose testing performed for the first time.
Correct Answer: Rey, 50/M, symptomatic (weight loss, polyuria, polyphagia, polydipsia), RBS = 210 mg/dL
Explanation: With no symptoms diagnosis should not be based on a single glucose determinatio. At least one additional glucose test result on another day with a value in the diabetic range is needed.
Option 3: Rey, 50/M, symptomatic (weight loss, polyuria, polyphagia, polydipsia), RBS = 210 mg/dL

Question: The target A1C in all patients with Type 2 diabetes is
Explanation: Target HbA1c is individualised; ≤6.5% for those young, uncomplicated, with short duration of disease; while <7.0% would be appropriate for most other adult T2DM individuals.

Question:
Case: A 22-year-old man with a history of asthma presents with a 2-day history of several small and scaling erythematous papules and plaques on his torso, back, and all four extremities. The patient reports that 3 weeks ago he had an unrelenting sore throat that just recently resolved. The patient has never had this skin condition before and denies a family history of psoriasis or any other dermatologic condition.

Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation in this question is consistent with a diagnosis of guttate psoriasis.

Question: Target LDL in all diabetes patient without overt cardiovascular disease.
Explanation: Target LDL cholesterol levels for adults with diabetes are <100 mg/dl (2.60 mmol/l); HDL cholesterol levels are >40 mg/dl (1.02 mmol/l); and triglyceride levels are <150 mg/dl (1.7 mmol/l).

Question: Which of the following if present within the past 4 weeks suggest that the asthma is not well controlled?
Correct Answer: Use of SABA reliever for symptoms 3x/week
Explanation: SABA use should not be more than 2x/week. The rest are correct. (GINA, 2024)
Option 2: Use of SABA reliever for symptoms 3x/week
Option 3: No night waking due to asthma
Option 4: No activity limitation due to asthma

Question: Appropriate treatment for a 20/F asthmatic patient with daily symptoms and waking at night 3x/week.
Explanation: If symptoms is not daily but most days, give maintenance low dose ICS-formoterol. If symptoms < 3-5 days with normal lung function, give as needed ICS-formoterol. (GINA 2024)
Option 1: As needed only low dose ICS-formoterol

Question: Appropriate treatment for 10/M with asthma symptoms 3x/week with no night awakenings due to asthma.
Correct Answer: Daily low-dose ICS + as needed SABA
Explanation: Step 2 of GINA 2024 for 6-11 child. If symptoms most days give low dose ics-LABA. If <2 days, give low dose ICS whenever SABA taken.
Option 1: Low dose ICS whenever SABA taken
Option 2: Daily low-dose ICS + as needed SABA
Option 3: Low dose ICS-LABA + as needed SABA
Option 4: Medium dose ICS-LABA + as needed SABA

Question: Appropriate asthma reliever for a 5/M with asthma.
Explanation: SABA is the preferred as needed reliever for 5 yo and younger. (GINA, 2024)

Question: 15/M rushed to ER due to severe asthma exacerbation. Which of the following drugs is not part of the acute management?
Explanation: LABA takes a longer time to provide bronchodilation. The rest canbve considered in severe asthma exacerbation.

Question: 75/M diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes has taking Metformin for 15 years. Recent dose is at 2000 mg/day. Current eGFR is 27 mL/min/1.73 m2. Urinalysis show +++ protein, +++ glucose. How will you adjust the Metformin?
Explanation: eGFR 30 - 44 mL/min/1.73 m2, metformin treatment should not be started. If metformin is already in use, a daily dose of ≤1,000 mg is recommended. Metformin is contraindicated when the eGFR is <30.
Option 1: Retain Metformin dose and combine with a new drug

Question: 60/M with Type 2 Diabetes is already taking high dose Metformin and SGLT1 inhibitor but current A1C levels are at 11%. You decide to start insulin therapy. Which of the following insulin should you prescribe for now?
Explanation: Basal insulin alone is the most convenient initial insulin treatment. Only Glargine is long-acting, the rest are prandial insulins.

Question: Your patient is taking warfarin. He is asking you if he can also take St. John's Wort, a herbal medicine. You know this plant is a CYP enzyme inducer. What is the possible effect of drug interaction?
Explanation: St John's wort induces CYP enzymes with a resultant increase in warfarin clearance and decrease in INR.

Question: Which of the following drug belongs to the class of first-line management for major depression only?
Explanation: A - TCA. B. Dopamine-norepi reuptake inhibitor. D. SNRI E. MAO inhibitor

Question: Your patient wants to switch to a different antidepressant that has less sexual dysfunction effects. What drug should you give?
Explanation: Antidepressants with the lowest rate of sexual side effects include: Atypical antidepressants bupropion, mirtazapine, vilazodone, and vortioxetine.

Question: A patient wants to switch to an antidepressant drug less likely to cause weight gain. Her current BMI is 25. You recommend
Explanation: Bupropion is an antidepressant medicine that can also decrease appetite. The rest can lead to weight gain.

Question: 30/F, diagnosed with major depressive disorder, rushed to ER due to hypertensive crisis. 4 hours before admission, patient consumed a lot of aged cheese in a buffet. It is highly likely that the patient was taking
Explanation: Hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome can occur in rare cases due to interactions between MAOIs and foods containing tyramine.

Question: 20/F came to consult for "feeling sad all the time". You diagnose her to have major depressive disorder. The dosage of your starting antidepressant is recommended to be ____ to improve tolerability.
Explanation: In general, when starting an antidepressant, consider starting at half the normal dose, titrating upward as tolerated about every 14 days.

Question: First-line treatment of major depressive disorder in children.
Explanation: For the treatment of depression in adolescents, the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) fluoxetine (Prozac) is recommended as a first-line medication over other medications.

Question: JJ, 50/M diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes. He is a busy businessman with unpredictable eating habits. He is currently taking metformin at 1500 mg/day. Current HbA1C is 8.7%. You decide to add another drug with less risk of hypoglycemia. You choose
Explanation: SGLT2 inhibitors lower blood glucose without increasing the hypoglycemia risk. The rest have higher risk of hypoglycemia.

Question: MA, 45/F with Type 2 Diabetes with a eGFR = 75. She is currently on Metformin but HbA1C is 8.2%. Urinalysis show ++ glucose + protein. You want to add another drug that has renal protection. The first-line drug for this is
Explanation: KDIGO: SGLT2i first-line therapy in patients with CKD, alongside statins, RAAS inhibitors. Can add GLP1RA if SGLT2i not tolerated / A1C target not reached.

Question: LA, 40/F with Type 2 DM. Currently on Metformin 1500mg/day. Hb1Ac is 8.5%, BMI = 28. Her main goal is to achieve glycemic control and weight loss in 6 months. Access and cost of drugs is not an issue for her. The best drug to recommend is
Explanation: SEMAGLUTIDE promotes weight loss. It works by decreasing appetite. The rest can lead to weight gain.

Question: Which of the following insulin is best for decreasing nocturnal hypoglycemia and has the longest duration of action?
Explanation: Insulin degludec is a new generation ultra-long acting basal insulin with a unique mechanism of protraction based on multi-hexamer formation.

Question: Which of the following is not matched to its proper treatment / antidote?
Explanation: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is used as an antidote for isoniazid (INH) overdose, especially in intentional ingestions.

Question: AB, 30/M, a farmer rushed to the ER because of the following symptoms: diarrhea, urinary incontinence, vomiting, and excessive salivation. Pupils are constricted. Heart rate is 40. This is
Explanation: Excessive accumulation of acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junctions and synapses causes symptoms of both muscarinic and nicotinic toxicity.

Question: Presence of large amounts of calcium oxalate in the urine is a sign of _ poisoning.
Explanation: Although not a pathognomonic, calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals supports the diagnosis of ethylene glycol poisoning in patients having a metabolic acidosis of unknown aetiology.

Question: Which of the following is TRUE?
Correct Answer: Lactated Ringer's solution is avoided in dehydrated patients diagnosed with poisoning
Explanation:
A. Hypoglycemia
C. NAC is the antidote
D. Immediate dialysis is indicated
Option 1: Hyperglycemia can increase the chance of poison to enter the blood brain barrier
Option 2: Lactated Ringer's solution is avoided in dehydrated patients diagnosed with poisoning
Option 3: N-acetylcysteine is contraindicated in paracetamol poisoning
Option 4: Dialysis is avoided in methanol poisoning

Question: 10/M, diagnosed with asthma came for a follow up consult. He has been using low dose maintenance ICS for 4 months and now has well-controlled symptoms. His mother asks if he can now stop using the ICS and use as needed SABA only. The correct response is
Correct Answer: No, low dose ICS taken whenever SABA taken is more appropriate.
Explanation: Do not completely stop ICS because risk of exacerbations is increased with SABA-only treatment. (GINA 2024)
Option 1: Yes, he has to step down the treatment to using as needed SABA only.
Option 2: No, low dose ICS taken whenever SABA taken is more appropriate.

Question: The patient's asthma therapy can be stepped down if achieving good control of symptoms for at least __.
Explanation: If good control of asthma for at least 3 months, treatment can be stepped down; however, the patient should be reassessed in 2-4 weeks to make sure that control is maintained. GINA 2024

Question: 18/F rushed to ER for moderate asthma exacerbation. 10 hours after acute management, she is now stable and being arrange for discharge. Aside from stepping up her ICS therapy, you also prescribe this drug to be taken for 5 days.
Explanation: Continue prednisolone for 5-7 days in adults and 3-5 days in children after an acute exacerbation.

Question: Which of the following is FALSE?
Correct Answer: Cow's milk introduced at 6 months of age
Explanation: Cow's milk introduced at 12 months of age
Option 1: From birth to six months of age, breastfeeding is the preferred source of nutrition
Option 2: All breastfed infants should be supplemented with vitamin D
Option 3: Preterm breastfed infants should be additionally supplemented with iron
Option 4: Cow's milk introduced at 6 months of age

Question: A cyanotic breath-holding spell is associated with all of the following EXCEPT:
Explanation: Diaphoresis is associated with pallid type of breath-holding spell

Question: Which of the following is considered an abnormal finding, requiring immediate intervention among neonates?
Explanation: All of the following conditions spontaneously resolve after the the first to second year of life.

Question:
Case: An 8/F is brought to the hospital for evaluation. It is summertime and their daughter has been playing outside much of the summer. She has had frequent mosquito bites. She has had no other animal bites or contact that she or her parents remember. She has previously been in good health. When she woke up this morning, she had complained to her mother of a headache which has become significantly worse throughout the day. Her mother reports low-grade fever as well. She has vomited once today and feels nauseous again while waiting to be evaluated. She denies photophobia or other symptoms. Several of her friends have had similar symptoms over the past several days. PE shows an uncomfortable but non-toxic appearing child who is holding her head, but is able to converse with you. She is alert and oriented appropriately and although she is uncomfortable, she is not irritable. Vital signs are as follows: T 38.0 C, pulse 88, BP 98/52, RR 20. She has mild nuchal rigidity but otherwise has normal physical examination, including normal neurologic findings. You decide to perform a lumbar puncture with the following CSF findings: CSF leukocytes 110 cells with 92% lymphocytes CSF protein 80 mg/dl CSF glucose 90 mg/dl The child is admitted for observation and recovers without incident.

What is the MOST LIKELY etiology of her infection?
Explanation: The most likely etiology is an enterovirus, suggested by the presentation of headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, & mild nuchal rigidity, which are consistent with viral meningitis.

Question:
Case: You are evaluating a 4/M in the ER for bloody diarrhea. He has been ill for about two days with fever and diarrhea. He has previously been well and has no underlying chronic health conditions. Evaluation shows a child who, although he indeed has frequent loose stools, some with spots of blood in them, is adequately hydrated and is not compromised either hemodynamically or neurologically.

In the above scenario, infection with WHICH of the following agents would NOT require treatment with antibiotic therapy?
Explanation: In the given scenario, infection with Salmonella species would not require treatment with antibiotic therapy.

Question:
Case: An 18/F is admitted to your hospital service for inpatient management of severe migraine headache. Her headache is treated and she improves. She mentions to you that she will be traveling to rural areas of Bicol following high school graduation for a summer exchange program. She expects to be spending many hours daily out in the sun. She wants to know what medications or immunizations she will need to take in order to protect herself from malaria.

Which of the following would NOT be an appropriate choice for malaria prophylaxis in this patient?
Explanation: Praziquantel is not an appropriate choice for malaria prophylaxis in this patient. Praziquantel is actually used to treat parasitic infections such as schistosomiasis, not malaria.

Question: This is
Explanation: Complete white-out of the left hemithorax due to bronchogenic carcinoma. If this is massive pleural effusion, there should have been a mediastinal shift.

Question: To see superficial structures in high resolution, like the thyroid gland, one must use this probe.
Explanation: For proper thyroid examination, a high frequency (10-15 MHz, at minimum more than 7.5 MHz) linear transducer is recommended. Curvilinear is good for deep structures.

Question: This is most likely a
Explanation: Simple renal cyst in right kidney (yellow arrow). Note the posterior acoustic enhancement.

Question: 40/M with history of fevers, cough and night sweats. Background rheumatoid arthritis, on TNF alpha inhibitor.  This disease is from the spread of infection from ____ route.
Explanation: Miliary TB is disseminated TB characterized by millet-seed-like granuloma formation in various organs. Miliary TB often arises from a primary pulmonary infection that spreads hematogenously.

Question: Which chamber of the heart is not border forming on PA Chest X-ray?
Explanation: On a posteroanterior chest radiograph, the right ventricle is normally not a border-forming structure.

Question: 60/F with shortness of breath and cough of 4 months. She smokes for 15 years now. From the X-ray above your primary working impression is
Explanation: Chest xrays demonstrates very marked hyperinflation of both lungs. Over 11 posterior ribs are seen, the diaphragms are flattened and there is enlargement of the retrosternal airspace, classic COPD.

Question: A cerebral ischemia will appear as ___ in DWI and ADC.
Explanation: DWI images, acute ischemic tissue identified as a region of bright intensity on a background of dark, normal brain tissue. On an ADC map, has the opposite appearance-a dark area.

Question: Which of the following is the hallmark of persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn?
Explanation: Labile hypoxemia is the hallmark of PPHN.

Question: Which of the following is the origin of the conus arteriosus?
Explanation: The bulbus cordis gives rise to the smooth upper part of the right ventricle, also known as the conus arteriosus.

Question: An abnormal _ is a marker for trisomy 21.
Explanation: An abnormally increased ductus venosus pulsatility index was found in a substantial proportion of early trisomy 21 fetuses.

Question: Compared to venous blood, which of the following findings would be expected in the erythrocyte hemolysate from arterial blood?
Explanation: Less CO2 in arterial blood -> Less H2CO3 -> Less intracellular HCO3 -> Less activity from Cl/HCO3 transporter (Cl in, HCO3 out) -> Less Cl going in (chloride shift) -> Less intracellular [Cl-]

Question: One of the Corneal Light Reflex tests is the Hirschberg Test. Upon doing this test, which of the following pair of degree and prism diopter measurements correctly describe the figure of the eye below?
Correct Answer: D. 15 degrees esotropia and 30 prism diopters of esotropia
Explanation: Esotropia (corneal light reflex at nasal aspect of eye); 15 degrees i.e. at the edge of the pupil; 2:1 PD thus 30PD is 15deg
Option 1: A. 15 degrees exotropia and 60 prism diopters of exotropia
Option 2: B. 30 degrees exotropia and 60 prism diopters of esotropia
Option 3: C. 30 degrees esotropia and 30 prism diopters of exotropia
Option 4: D. 15 degrees esotropia and 30 prism diopters of esotropia

Question:
The tonometry results of a patient show the following:

OD: 20 mmHg OS: 15 mmHg  Based on the presented results, which of the following statements is/are incorrect?
Explanation: The question asks for “incorrect” statements, thus all of the choices. Both eyes have NORMAL IOP (fall in the range of 10-21 mmHg). The IOP difference is NOT normal (the difference must 2 mmHg)
Option 1: A. Both eyes do not have normal IOP
Option 2: B. Only the right eye has normal IOP
Option 3: C. Only the left eye has normal IOP
Option 4: D. The IOP difference of both eyes is normal

Question: 60/M came to the OPD for a well check up. PE is unremarkable except for 30 g-prostate on DRE. The patient did not report any LUTS. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
Explanation: Hyperplasia needs histologic confirmation. Obstruction requires LUTS. Prostate cancer needs biopsy.

Question: 50/F complains of hand pain and stiffness after waking up for more than a month already. On PE, tenderness was noted on bilateral DIP but no signs of inflammation. What is your PWI?
Explanation: OA: DIP, no inflammation, morninf stiffness

Question: All of the following can be a characteristic of hyperopia, except:
Correct Answer: B. Its focus of light is anterior to the retina
